Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 9 August 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: The House met at 9.30 a.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: ABSENCE OF MR SPEAKER

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clerk-I inform the House of the ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: sence of the Speaker, who will be in atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: dance later this day. In accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 14, the Deputy Speaker, as

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Speaker, will take the chair.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Mr Nehl)

Speaker: NA
Text: thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: ECONOMIC AND FISCAL OUTLOOK

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Brand-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (9.31 a.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing and sessional or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition moving forthwith that this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) believing in open, transparent and account-

Speaker: NA
Text: able government;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) wishing to provide the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: with a reasonable opportunity to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic and fiscal outlook so as to

Speaker: NA
Text: help inform their decision at the forthcom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing federal election;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) wanting to provide all parties with the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to responsibly detail their financial Lawler, A.J.

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments prior to the calling of the

Speaker: NA
Text: election; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) noting that there is no legal impediment to

Speaker: NA
Text: the following course of conduct;

Speaker: NA
Text: calls on the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance to provide updated informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the economic and fiscal outlook prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: the calling of the federal election by:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) requiring the Secretary to the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Treasury and the Secretary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department for Finance to publish an

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and fiscal outlook report and to

Speaker: NA
Text: prepare that report as if the report were

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared in accordance with Division 7

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Charter of Budget Honesty Act

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) requiring all Ministers, Secretaries and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth bodies to provide such

Speaker: NA
Text: information, and to do all acts or things,

Speaker: NA
Text: as are necessary to enable that economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and fiscal outlook report to be so pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Acting Speaker, they are trying to hide

Speaker: NA
Text: behind that 10-day-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr MCGauran) put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the member be not further heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: WOOL INTERNATIONAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: Wide Bay-Minister for Ag-

Speaker: NA
Text: riculture, Fisheries and Forestry) (9.47

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Wool International Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001 will expedite the final stage in the dec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ade-long task of selling down the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: stockpile, winding up the company charged

Speaker: NA
Text: with its management and will maximise the

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus equity returned to its shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation to privatise Wool Interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional in 1999 provided for the final distribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to shareholders to follow the preparation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the final financial year audited accounts

Speaker: NA
Text: for WoolStock Australia Ltd.

Speaker: NA
Text: The board of WoolStock Australia has ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vised the government that the last wool in

Speaker: NA
Text: the stockpile is likely be sold down in the

Speaker: NA
Text: very near future, possibly in the next few

Speaker: NA
Text: days.

Speaker: NA
Text: This amendment will enable WoolStock

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to bring forward its winding up and

Speaker: NA
Text: final cash distribution to shareholders, with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out requiring the conclusion of these proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: esses to be after 30 June 2002. The share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders of WoolStock are essentially those

Speaker: NA
Text: wool growers that met much of the burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: the debt associated with the stockpile in the

Speaker: NA
Text: very difficult years for the wool industry

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1993-94 and 1995-96.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effect of this amendment is that wool

Speaker: NA
Text: growers will get their final payment flowing

Speaker: NA
Text: from their shareholding considerably earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: than would be possible under the current

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, and, because the overhead costs

Speaker: NA
Text: of maintaining the company until after 30

Speaker: NA
Text: June 2002 can be reduced, there will be cost

Speaker: NA
Text: savings which will maximise the surplus eq-

Speaker: NA
Text: uity to be returned to shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: The timely fashion in which the stockpile

Speaker: NA
Text: has been sold down since WoolStock Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia took over its management is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: strong reflection on the success of the Wool

Speaker: NA
Text: International privatisation. It is also a

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the excellent job WoolStock Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has done over the past two years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank Mr Donald MCGauchie and the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the WoolStock board for their

Speaker: NA
Text: important role in selling down the stockpile.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shareholders have already received two

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, with a third distribution expected

Speaker: NA
Text: in coming months. They will reap further

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits of this excellent work when they

Speaker: NA
Text: receive their final distribution payment after

Speaker: NA
Text: the remaining wool is sold and the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures taken to determine the surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: equity in WoolStock.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is indeed historic legislation. It may

Speaker: NA
Text: be only a tiny bill, but it brings to an end an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary chapter in Australian primary

Speaker: NA
Text: production history. It will mean that, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time in decades, Australian wool will be

Speaker: NA
Text: sold freely and fairly in the marketplace

Speaker: NA
Text: without having to labour under the heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: cloud of a stockpile overshadowing the mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket. This bill, I think, marks the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: a new era for the wool industry. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill to the House, and I present the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: planatory memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Swan) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: WORKPLACE RELATIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (MINIMUM

Speaker: NA
Text: ENTITLEMENTS FOR VICTORIAN

Speaker: NA
Text: WORKERS) BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Abbott, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Workplace Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business) (9.51 a.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will amend the Workplace Rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Act 1996 to enhance the legislated

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net entitlements in schedule 1A for

Speaker: NA
Text: employees in Victoria not covered by federal

Speaker: NA
Text: awards or agreements. The bill will make

Speaker: NA
Text: consequential improvements to the statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: role of inspectors under the federal act to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform, investigate and if necessary enforce

Speaker: NA
Text: rights and obligations in schedule 1A work-

Speaker: NA
Text: places. It will also confer upon the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: reflecgovernment automatic intervention rights

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Australian Industrial Relations

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission in specific circumstances, and

Speaker: NA
Text: give contract outworkers in the textile,

Speaker: NA
Text: clothing and footwear industry in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: access to enforceable minimum rates of pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bulk of these measures to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net entitlements for Victorian workers

Speaker: NA
Text: are those the government proposed in sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule 15 of the Workplace Relations Legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 1999. That bill has stalled in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: for almost two years, and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats have since called for issue-

Speaker: NA
Text: specific consideration of policy matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taking this sentiment into account, the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has since proceeded with a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of issue-by-issue workplace relations bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill dealing with Victorian workers un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der schedule 1A continues that approach. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is supplemented by a number of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: measures which I announced on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government in March this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian employees not covered by a fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral award or federal agreement are presently

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by a legislated safety net of mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum conditions contained in part XV and

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1A of the Workplace Relations Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: together with general statutory provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: applying to employees under the act such as

Speaker: NA
Text: access to unfair and unlawful termination of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment remedies, equal pay for work of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal value, non-discrimination provisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace bargaining provisions and rights

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of freedom of association. In addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, employees under schedule 1A are eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble to be regulated by federal awards made

Speaker: NA
Text: by order of the Australian Industrial Rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Commission (following relevant dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: pute findings being made), or by certified

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements or, in many cases, Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Agreements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minimum employment conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: presently legislated for in schedule 1A are

Speaker: NA
Text: largely a continuation of the safety net provithe

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that applied to these employees under

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian state law immediately prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996 referral by the state of a range of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial relations powers to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. That referral has been of substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to Victorian employers and employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ees, establishing for the first time a single

Speaker: NA
Text: framework of laws regulating industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: matters in Australia's second largest state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the introduction of the federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's More Jobs, Better Pay bill meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures in 1999, the current Victorian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has argued in-principle support for a

Speaker: NA
Text: unitary regulatory system under federal laws,

Speaker: NA
Text: but claimed that the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1A proposals are inadequate. Dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussions between the Commonwealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian governments were halted in April

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 when the Victorian government unilat-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally announced its intention to establish a

Speaker: NA
Text: state task force inquiry. In October 2000 it

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently introduced into its state parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, again without notice to or consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Commonwealth, its Fair Employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill 2000. That bill was ultimately re-

Speaker: NA
Text: jected by the Victorian upper house on 22

Speaker: NA
Text: March 2001, although the Victorian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has threatened to reintroduce it into the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Fair Employment Bill was flawed in

Speaker: NA
Text: both concept and content. The re-creation of

Speaker: NA
Text: a second layer of industrial regulation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: form of a state industrial system would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been regressive move, not in the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: employers or employees, nor the public in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest. A new system of state industrial laws,

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations, tribunals and bureaucracy would

Speaker: NA
Text: have come at a significant cost to Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces and the Victorian taxpayer. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition, the proposed Victorian system of

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial regulation would have signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly increased the cost of employment in

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1A workplaces, and threatened jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: in urban and regional areas of the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Remarkably, even the proponents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fair Employment Bill-primarily the Victo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rian government and the Trades Hall Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil-estimated 1,900 job losses would follow

Speaker: NA
Text: its introduction, as well as an increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: casual employment at the expense of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent employment. Research based on

Speaker: NA
Text: full operation of the proposed new state

Speaker: NA
Text: system by consultants ACIL and Econtech

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Victorian Employers Chamber of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce and Industry estimated job losses

Speaker: NA
Text: of 40,000 over three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Commonwealth bill is designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve dual objectives, both of which over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come the flawed approach of the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government. The Commonwealth bill en-

Speaker: NA
Text: hances, in a sensible way, the legislated

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net of minimum conditions of sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule 1A employees (without negatively im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacting on employment), and does so within

Speaker: NA
Text: the framework of a unitary system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The policy measures contained in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: are the amendments first proposed in sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule 15 of the government's More Jobs, Better

Speaker: NA
Text: Pay bill, supplemented by the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: measures which I announced on 14 March

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, the amendments would:

Speaker: NA
Text: - clarify the operation of the schedule 1A

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum entitlements to annual leave

Speaker: NA
Text: and sick leave (sick leave being incorpocess

Speaker: NA
Text: rated into carer's leave) by providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: basis upon which these leave entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are to be calculated, and setting

Speaker: NA
Text: out rules about access to, and accumula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of, such leave;

Speaker: NA
Text: - give schedule 1A employees a statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement to be paid for work per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed in excess of 38 hours a week;

Speaker: NA
Text: - provide federal inspectors with the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to enter and inspect premises

Speaker: NA
Text: where they reasonably believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1A work is being performed;

Speaker: NA
Text: - provide that a breach of the minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of employment in schedule

Speaker: NA
Text: 1A can be enforced in the same way as

Speaker: NA
Text: federal awards and agreements;

Speaker: NA
Text: - provide an employer with a statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement to stand down a schedule 1A

Speaker: NA
Text: employee where that employee cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: usefully be employed due to circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances beyond the employer's control;

Speaker: NA
Text: - provide the power to make regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring employers to keep and main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain employee records for Victorian em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees who are not employed under

Speaker: NA
Text: federal awards or agreements;

Speaker: NA
Text: - create a legislative entitlement to carer's

Speaker: NA
Text: leave for schedule 1A employees; and

Speaker: NA
Text: - create a legislative entitlement to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: reavement leave for schedule 1A em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to carer's leave, the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: poses to convert the current five-day sick

Speaker: NA
Text: leave entitlement in schedule 1A into a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal leave minimum standard of eight days

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum, which would be cumulative. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: those eight days, up to five days per annum

Speaker: NA
Text: could be taken for caring purposes. In rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to bereavement leave, the bill proposes

Speaker: NA
Text: to amend schedule 1A to introduce a mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum standard of two days bereavement

Speaker: NA
Text: leave on the death of an immediate family

Speaker: NA
Text: member or household member. These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments would provide a comparable

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum standard to carer's and bereave-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment leave as was proposed in the state bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian employees with disabilities who

Speaker: NA
Text: are not employed under a federal award or

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement do not currently have direct ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: to the supported wage system. At pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent such employees can only use section 509

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Workplace Relations Act 1996, which

Speaker: NA
Text: allows the Australian Industrial Relations

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission on a case by case basis, to issue

Speaker: NA
Text: an appropriate wages certificate for 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months duration. It would be preferable to

Speaker: NA
Text: give these employees direct access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: supported wage system, which has been de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to meet the requirements of the Dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability Discrimination Act 1992, and has the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of peak disability groups, the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Chamber of Commerce and Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, the bill proposes to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: access to the supported wage system by

Speaker: NA
Text: amending part XV to give the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: power to determine that the supported wage

Speaker: NA
Text: system applies to schedule 1A employees

Speaker: NA
Text: within a work classification in a declared

Speaker: NA
Text: industry sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Victorian government has claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that as a consequence of the Kennett gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's referral of powers the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government does not have the ability to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tervene in major industrial disputes which

Speaker: NA
Text: occur within that state. In fact, all state gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments have standing to seek leave to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tervene before the Australian Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations Commission in cases where they have

Speaker: NA
Text: a sufficient interest. However, in recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: of the specific circumstances of the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government arising from the 1996 referral of

Speaker: NA
Text: powers, the bill would amend the Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: proRelations Act 1996 to give the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government an automatic statutory right to

Speaker: NA
Text: intervene in proceedings involving an appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation under section 170MW of the act to

Speaker: NA
Text: suspend or terminate a bargaining period

Speaker: NA
Text: involving employees within the state of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria, and in applications under section

Speaker: NA
Text: 501 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to

Speaker: NA
Text: adjust minimum wages in industry sectors in

Speaker: NA
Text: that state.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also contains amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations Act 1996 to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the terms and conditions of home-based

Speaker: NA
Text: outworkers working in the textile, clothing

Speaker: NA
Text: and footwear (TCF) industry in the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill would introduce a requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: that contract outworkers in the TCF industry

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria receive at least the minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1A rate of pay applicable to em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed TCF outworkers. The bill would also

Speaker: NA
Text: authorise federal workplace inspectors to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter premises where such work is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed and empower inspectors to enforce

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum remuneration requirement and

Speaker: NA
Text: seek remedies in the courts on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: outworker where non-payment or underpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is identified.

Speaker: NA
Text: This statutory measure will complement

Speaker: NA
Text: my announcement on 14 March that, fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing the passage of these amendments, a

Speaker: NA
Text: team of federal inspectors will commence

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance activities in the Victorian TCF

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in relation to these new outworker

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements, using the proposed new in-

Speaker: NA
Text: spectorate powers. I have also announced

Speaker: NA
Text: that a ministerial report on workplace rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions compliance in the industry will be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by the federal inspectorate three

Speaker: NA
Text: months following the commencement of

Speaker: NA
Text: these amendments. The suite of measures

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in this bill will, when enacted, sigfacilitating

Speaker: NA
Text: nificantly improve the workplace relations

Speaker: NA
Text: framework in Victoria. It will unambigu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously improve minimum conditions for em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees not covered by federal awards or

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements and for TCF outworkers. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: do so in a responsible manner, retaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits of existing employment under

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1A and within the one regulatory

Speaker: NA
Text: framework. I present the explanatory memo-

Speaker: NA
Text: randum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Swan) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (TELECOMMUNICATIONS) BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr MCGauran, and

Speaker: NA
Text: read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator MCGAURAN (Victoria) (10.03

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Trade Practices Amendment (Telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications) Bill 2001 will streamline and

Speaker: NA
Text: make more efficient the telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: access regime in part XIC of the Trade Prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices Act 1974. The broad objective of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is to facilitate the timely resolution of

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications access disputes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative measures in the bill are therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to further encourage the negotiation

Speaker: NA
Text: of commercial outcomes and to speed up the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory arbitration process should com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial negotiations fail.

Speaker: NA
Text: This part of the Trade Practices Act gives

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications service providers a

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory right of access, on reasonable terms

Speaker: NA
Text: and conditions, to carriage and related serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ices that have been declared by the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Competition and Consumer Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, the ACCC. It is the clear preference of

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislative scheme that parties resolve

Speaker: NA
Text: access disputes through commercial negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. However, where commercial negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is not successful, parties to an access

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute can notify the ACCC that a dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: exists and seek arbitration of the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The access regime delivers benefits to the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and end users of telecommunica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions services by promoting competition,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘any to any' connectivity and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couraging the efficient use of, and invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in, infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, protracted delays in the arbitra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of access disputes are impeding compe-

Speaker: NA
Text: tition in the telecommunications sector, and

Speaker: NA
Text: delaying lower cost and higher quality serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ices to consumers. The Minister for Commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nications, Information Technology and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arts, Senator Alston, discussed possible

Speaker: NA
Text: measures to speed up access disputes and the

Speaker: NA
Text: timing of a reform package at an industry

Speaker: NA
Text: forum in May of this year. That forum re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flected a broad industry consensus about the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for immediate action to streamline the

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications access regime in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide certainty for critical investment by

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers and to promote the rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: development of broadband services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislative measures in this bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: about accelerating the process of resolving

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications access disputes and not

Speaker: NA
Text: about altering the outcomes of those dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: putes. The bill addresses each stage in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute resolution process under the access

Speaker: NA
Text: regime. In particular, the amendments pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to the ACCC arbitration process are

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with the Productivity Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion's draft report on telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: competition regulation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the period before regulatory arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: by the ACCC, the amendments in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will encourage parties to resolve disputes

Speaker: NA
Text: without recourse to ACCC arbitration. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, the ACCC will be required to

Speaker: NA
Text: publish pricing principles at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: as, or as soon as practicable after, the decla-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration of services, and to publish results of

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrations. This will increase the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant information to the market and fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: cilitate commercial resolution of disputes,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than lengthy arbitrations. Enabling the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCC to ‘backdate' determinations to the

Speaker: NA
Text: date when commercial negotiations com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mence will also encourage parties to attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: to resolve disputes commercially, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately notifying a dispute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCC. In exercising its powers under the

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications access regime, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCC will be required to have regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: objective of resolving disputes quickly, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding through alternate dispute resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: (ADR) mechanisms such as mediation and

Speaker: NA
Text: conciliation.

Speaker: NA
Text: To streamline the arbitration process itself, ices.

Speaker: NA
Text: the ACCC will be able to conduct multilat-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral arbitrations (to overcome the delays

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by separate hearings for common

Speaker: NA
Text: disputes) and to hear disputes with a single

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioner. Enabling the ACCC to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: close information between common arbitra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions will reduce the time taken in conduct-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing individual arbitrations, while also en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couraging commercial resolution of disputes

Speaker: NA
Text: that have already been notified to the ACCC.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ACCC will also be able to make interim

Speaker: NA
Text: determinations over the objections of an ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess seeker and to prevent unilateral with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawal from arbitrations, thereby minimising

Speaker: NA
Text: the potential for delay and procedural abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: of the arbitration process.

Speaker: NA
Text: If, following the ACCC process, an

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCC determination is reviewed, the review

Speaker: NA
Text: body, the Australian Competition Tribunal,

Speaker: NA
Text: will only be able to consider evidence avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able at the original hearing. A further minor

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment would prevent a party from

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking a stay of an ACT-Australian Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition Tribunal-decision, pending judicial

Speaker: NA
Text: review, making this consistent with existing

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for ACCC determinations.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will streamline the current ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements under which the industry oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ates. However it falls to access seekers, ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess providers and the ACCC to maximise

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits of a competitive telecommuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations sector by properly utilising available

Speaker: NA
Text: tools, both legislative and non-legislative.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is encouraged by an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creasing industry commitment to alternate

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute resolution and the ACCC's commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to review its management of arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: processes, utilising the new legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill does not preclude making further

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the telecommunications ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess arrangements after the release of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission's final report in

Speaker: NA
Text: September 2001.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provisions to streamline the telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications access regime will assist in cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating vigorous competition at all levels of the

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications industry with benefits to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian consumers and businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: through lower prices and better quality serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the bill to the House and pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen

Speaker: NA
Text: Smith) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Slipper, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: Fisher-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Finance and

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration) (10.09 a.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill contains amendments to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Electoral Act 1918 (the Electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: Act) to provide that, following elections,

Speaker: NA
Text: public funding for the Liberal Party is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to the agent of the Liberal Party of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia (Federal Secretariat), rather than to

Speaker: NA
Text: the state and territory divisions of the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party (that is, those state and territory divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions of the Liberal Party which are consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutionally linked to the federal secretariat-

Speaker: NA
Text: NSW, Vic, Qld, SA, WA, Tas and the ACT).

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the agent of the Federal Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tariat of the Liberal Party may lodge with the

Speaker: NA
Text: AEC, prior to polling day, a written notice

Speaker: NA
Text: that sets out the proportion of the public

Speaker: NA
Text: funding to be paid to the agents of the state

Speaker: NA
Text: and territory divisions and the proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the public funding to be paid to the agent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the federal secretariat. The public funding

Speaker: NA
Text: would then be paid to those agents in accor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dance with the proportions set out in the no-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Currently, the Electoral Act provides that

Speaker: NA
Text: public funding be paid to the agent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state or territory division of a party for the

Speaker: NA
Text: state or territory in which the candidate(s)

Speaker: NA
Text: stood. However, as the Federal Secretariat of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party is responsible for federal

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaigns, it is appropriate that all

Speaker: NA
Text: or part of the public funding be paid to the

Speaker: NA
Text: agent of the federal secretariat.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is desirable that these amendments be in

Speaker: NA
Text: place prior to the next federal election ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected to be held later in the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the bill to the House and pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent the explanatory memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Swan) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND

Speaker: NA
Text: SECONDARY EDUCATION

Speaker: NA
Text: ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 8 August, on mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by Dr Kemp:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which Mr Lee moved by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after “That” be omitted with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading, the House condemns the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: for:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) misusing the issue of literacy for political

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) manipulating statistics about literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) providing $145 million to wealthy category

Speaker: NA
Text: one schools which could have been better

Speaker: NA
Text: used improving literacy for students in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and needy non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools”.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Northern Territory)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10.12 a.m.)-The States Grants (Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: and Secondary Education Assistance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2001 legislates a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement described as ‘improving

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling outcomes' which, while costed at

Speaker: NA
Text: zero in the list of budget measures, claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that $36.9 million was being provided over

Speaker: NA
Text: the period 2001-02 and 2003-04 for literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that it is wise that we put to bed

Speaker: NA
Text: any perception that in this current financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year and the two out years financial years,

Speaker: NA
Text: until 2003-04, there are any additional mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: eys available for literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. The shadow minister for education,

Speaker: NA
Text: Michael Lee, said yesterday:

Speaker: NA
Text: Here we have a budget announcement claiming

Speaker: NA
Text: that $36 million extra is being provided to help

Speaker: NA
Text: improve literacy in schools across the country, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is only when you read the fine print that you

Speaker: NA
Text: find buried away at the back of Budget Paper No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2, under the heading ‘Improving Schooling Out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes', we have how much additional expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture in the year 2001-02? Zero dollars. How much

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2002-03? Zero dollars. How much in 2003-04?

Speaker: NA
Text: Zero dollars. How much in 2004-05? Zero dol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lars.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that illustrates markedly the kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: mean and tricky way in which this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is addressing issues to do with educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, not only in the matter of school educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion but also for higher education. All areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of education have suffered as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies of this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here we have a government wanting the

Speaker: NA
Text: community to believe that over the next four

Speaker: NA
Text: financial years, including the current one, an

Speaker: NA
Text: extra $36 million is going to be provided to

Speaker: NA
Text: help improve literacy and numeracy, when

Speaker: NA
Text: that is clearly false. We do not have the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister, the Prime Minister or anyone else asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated with the government up on their feet

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House explaining to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community why the government have sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to mislead, misguide and basically act dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: honestly in relation to this funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a parent and as a citizen of this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, I would expect that when the government

Speaker: NA
Text: announces that literacy and numeracy stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards are a high priority and that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: allocating additional funding for this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram-and when I am led to believe that that

Speaker: NA
Text: funding will be ongoing-I will see in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget papers a decent dollar figure over the

Speaker: NA
Text: current financial year and into the out years

Speaker: NA
Text: for this particular item. Yet, as has been il-

Speaker: NA
Text: lustrated by the shadow minister, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing but an attempted act of, I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: grave dishonesty in the way in which this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has been presented.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all acknowledge the importance of lit-

Speaker: NA
Text: eracy and numeracy, and it is a pity that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment, Workplace Rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and Small Business is not in the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. I do have to declare an interest. I was a

Speaker: NA
Text: schoolteacher, and my partner is a school

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher. I was Vice-President of the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory Teachers Federation, as it then was.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was an active teacher-unionist and I was

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to be involved in the education profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. But what we now have is dishonesty,

Speaker: NA
Text: with attacks on public education by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and a failure to address the areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest need and concern in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to numeracy and literacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said I wanted to declare an interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: did so for two reasons. Firstly, I am the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent, with my partner, of four children, all of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom attend schools; secondly, I am still a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the education union and have an

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing interest in what happens to educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in general and public education in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular. I am pleased to say that many of my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues share that interest, particularly as

Speaker: NA
Text: it relates to public education. We know how

Speaker: NA
Text: this government has disparaged public edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation by seeking to divert taxpayers' funds

Speaker: NA
Text: to the wealthiest of Australia's private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. The figures have been repeated of-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten in this chamber, and it is not my intention

Speaker: NA
Text: to repeat them again, other than to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: you do not have to be Einstein to work out

Speaker: NA
Text: that category 1 schools are currently getting

Speaker: NA
Text: an extra $60 million, and there are 57 of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. On average, that is a bit over $1 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion each. But schools in the public sector

Speaker: NA
Text: can expect to receive around $4,000 each

Speaker: NA
Text: from this process. Why is it that the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment sees the importance of literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy on the one hand but does not provide

Speaker: NA
Text: funding in the out years, or even in the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rent financial year, to address a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: need. On the other hand, it is quite capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: shoving an additional amount of money in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of $100 million into the pockets of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealthiest of Australia's private schools

Speaker: NA
Text: over the funding period. This does not add

Speaker: NA
Text: up.

Speaker: NA
Text: I live in the Northern Territory and I see

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance, on a daily basis, of ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are adequate school facilities, ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriate staffing arrangements, and that cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: riculum design and advice are ongoing. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, this all requires money. In the North-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Territory we have the highest proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of students in public education of any Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian state or territory: 77.5 per cent com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with the national average of 69.7 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. That means public education for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory is more important overall than it is

Speaker: NA
Text: for other states and territories. It is particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly important in the case of the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory because we have so many small,

Speaker: NA
Text: remote communities and because we have, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as the highest proportion of students in

Speaker: NA
Text: the public education system, the lowest year

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 retention rates. On 1997 figures, 48.4 per

Speaker: NA
Text: and I cent of students in the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: completed year 12 who are male, compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with the national average of 68.4 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 50 per cent addition in terms of that

Speaker: NA
Text: figure. Similarly, for females, the figure is

Speaker: NA
Text: 57.8 per cent in the Northern Territory and

Speaker: NA
Text: 79.5 per cent nationally. More alarmingly-

Speaker: NA
Text: and of greater concern-is the fact that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: area of indigenous education, the picture is

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely bleak, with year 12 retention rates

Speaker: NA
Text: at 9.4 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not sure how this minister seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the outcomes in indigenous educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion without ensuring that the public educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion system is properly and appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: funded. We hear often in this place about

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual obligation-that Australians must

Speaker: NA
Text: accept responsibility themselves in exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: for any commitment from government. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty hard to take that approach when the

Speaker: NA
Text: educational attainment levels of many stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents in the Northern Territory are not ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quate for them to gain entry into the labour

Speaker: NA
Text: market or into training programs that will get

Speaker: NA
Text: them into the labour market. That is a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility of government, yet we do not get

Speaker: NA
Text: even the slightest impression that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment takes seriously the concern of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community about the outrageous

Speaker: NA
Text: diversion of additional public moneys to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealthiest private schools. Despite that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern, this government has done nothing that

Speaker: NA
Text: has had any great impact on outcomes in

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of numeracy and literacy, or on overall

Speaker: NA
Text: education attainment levels, for students who

Speaker: NA
Text: live in the electorate of the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must say that it is not just the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government's responsibility. It is with some

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that I note the report entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: Learning lessons: an independent review of

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous education in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory, by our former Senate colleague Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: Collins, which has received some publicity

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place and in others. He makes it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: in this report that the Northern Territory gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment levies the Commonwealth funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Indigenous Education Strategic Ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiatives Program, which is used for salaries,

Speaker: NA
Text: at a rate of 46.1 per cent for on-costs. That

Speaker: NA
Text: an absolute scandal. In other states and juris-

Speaker: NA
Text: dictions the on-cost levy varies from four per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent to 18.6 per cent, so it is impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: justify the approach adopted by the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory government. This is a massive cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: shifting exercise. The Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: government is creaming Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: resources, which are for targeted programs,

Speaker: NA
Text: to supplement its own budgetary framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over recent days there has been a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of debate in the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: about education, primarily because there is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently a dispute between the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory Education Union and its employer.

Speaker: NA
Text: That dispute is derived from the union's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern about teachers' working conditions and

Speaker: NA
Text: the state of education in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory. There have been meetings of teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: already around the Northern Territory. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: told there will be a further meeting tomorrow

Speaker: NA
Text: to address concerns about professional de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment, resources such as special needs

Speaker: NA
Text: teaching and reasonable limits on class sizes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I declared an interest earlier. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: terest as a parent, but I also have an interest

Speaker: NA
Text: as a citizen of the Northern Territory that no

Speaker: NA
Text: child should be disadvantaged because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: short-sightedness and stupidity of the North-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Territory government about education. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has been in government since 1978, yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: educational attainment outcomes are appall-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the Northern Territory compared with

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest of Australia. The government has no

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable answers as to why that is the case

Speaker: NA
Text: and why it has not done a great deal more

Speaker: NA
Text: about improving the lot of Territory students

Speaker: NA
Text: by providing them with the opportunity that

Speaker: NA
Text: they deserve to compete favourably with

Speaker: NA
Text: other students around Australia. The longer

Speaker: NA
Text: we go on, the bigger the gap. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. Despite the fact that teachers, who

Speaker: NA
Text: are professional people, have expressed their

Speaker: NA
Text: concern, the Northern Territory Chief Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister-who, of course, is in the midst of an

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign-has accused the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party in today's Northern Territory News of

Speaker: NA
Text: conspiring with teachers to disrupt education

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory in the lead-up to an

Speaker: NA
Text: election. You have to ask what planet he is

Speaker: NA
Text: on. Mr Burke alleges in this article:

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the teachers and nurses unions were

Speaker: NA
Text: is pawns who were being used by the union leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship to heighten industrial action during an elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is an absolute insult. If the Chief Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister were at all serious about improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: educational outcomes for all Territorians, he

Speaker: NA
Text: would take seriously the concerns being ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed by the teaching profession. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: no more pawns of the Labor Party than he

Speaker: NA
Text: was of the Liberal Party when he was the

Speaker: NA
Text: officer commanding a cavalry regiment.

Speaker: NA
Text: How can he allege, as he has done, that

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers in the Northern Territory have con-

Speaker: NA
Text: spired with the Labor Party to disrupt educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion services in the Northern Territory in the

Speaker: NA
Text: lead-up to an election? There is absolutely no

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of that at all; yet he says it.

Speaker: NA
Text: He should be ashamed of himself and of

Speaker: NA
Text: his government. If he needs any reminding at

Speaker: NA
Text: all of why he should be ashamed of himself

Speaker: NA
Text: and his government-not because of what

Speaker: NA
Text: they have said about the teachers in this in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, but because of their appalling record

Speaker: NA
Text: in the provision of educational services to all

Speaker: NA
Text: an inTerritorians-all he need read is Learning

Speaker: NA
Text: lessons. Then he should read his own gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's internal review from 1999 of

Speaker: NA
Text: IESIP funding, which says that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a history of IESIP funding as substitute

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for the Northern Territory Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Education core business-game, set

Speaker: NA
Text: and match!

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the Chief Minister of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory needs to accept responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for the appalling state of educational

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes in the Northern Territory, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly as they affect indigenous Territorians.

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the Minister for Education, Training

Speaker: NA
Text: and Youth Affairs: instead of coming in here

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to con the Australian community, own

Speaker: NA
Text: up to your responsibility, just as the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of the Northern Territory needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: own up to his. Instead of blackguarding

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers and teacher unions, you should sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port them in their desire to achieve better

Speaker: NA
Text: educational outcomes for all Australians.

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Text: Dunkley) (10.32 a.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to rise today to support the States

Speaker: NA
Text: Grants (Primary and Secondary Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001. As other

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers have highlighted, the bill is basi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally about providing an additional $33.3

Speaker: NA
Text: million over the next three years towards

Speaker: NA
Text: improving literacy and numeracy out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes-which naturally feed into educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional and learning outcomes-for educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally disadvantaged students. The funding

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the form of strategic assistance to both

Speaker: NA
Text: government and non-government education

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities to support research programs and

Speaker: NA
Text: the implementation of projects to enhance

Speaker: NA
Text: what we understand about and how we ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress literacy and numeracy deficiencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: This funding gives effect to one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions from the meeting between Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, state and territory ministers for

Speaker: NA
Text: education, who agreed to establish as a na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional goal ‘that all students should have

Speaker: NA
Text: tained the skills of numeracy and English

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy such that every student should be

Speaker: NA
Text: numerate, able to read, write, spell and

Speaker: NA
Text: communicate at an appropriate level.' That

Speaker: NA
Text: has been agreed as a national goal. Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, state and territory ministers with

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for education have agreed that

Speaker: NA
Text: we as a nation should come together, work

Speaker: NA
Text: through the barriers that the federation often

Speaker: NA
Text: represents to sound public policy and move

Speaker: NA
Text: forward together. There is a reason for that,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I note that reason has not been discussed

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal by the Labor Party members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have spoken on this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: After 13 years of a Labor government,

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 30 per cent of kids in years 3 and 5

Speaker: NA
Text: could not read or write to an acceptable stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard. This is not some Third World country;

Speaker: NA
Text: this is Australia. This is a country with one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the highest standards of living in the

Speaker: NA
Text: I world and, as the OECD has confirmed, one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the most rapidly and robust growing

Speaker: NA
Text: economies in the world. So, surely, we could

Speaker: NA
Text: have our kids be able to read and write.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely that is not too much to ask. But ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: parently, after 13 years of a Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, almost one-third of our kids in years 3

Speaker: NA
Text: and 5 could not do that. That was a national

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace and a national tragedy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since this government was elected in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996, it has set about focusing on that clear

Speaker: NA
Text: area of deficiency, recognising that, without

Speaker: NA
Text: those core skills, without those basic capaci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, trying to achieve higher educational

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes is extraordinarily difficult. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: hard to get into an advanced discussion about

Speaker: NA
Text: physics or about career pathways that may

Speaker: NA
Text: involve budgeting or something like that, if

Speaker: NA
Text: someone is not particularly numerate. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult for someone with poor literacy skills

Speaker: NA
Text: to access the educational resources that are

Speaker: NA
Text: available, whether it be online, in books, in

Speaker: NA
Text: technical references or in material that is

Speaker: NA
Text: circulated in the classroom. So there is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: clear connection between strengthening the

Speaker: NA
Text: performance of all students in these base

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of competency and those students be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing able to move into more complicated ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas of education and skill development. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the link.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before the House is not all that

Speaker: NA
Text: at- complicated; it simply corrects an error in

Speaker: NA
Text: the maths-and I hope that is not a reflection

Speaker: NA
Text: of a numeracy problem. It is actually an issue

Speaker: NA
Text: about forecasting the funds that are needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: support these programs. This bill sets out to

Speaker: NA
Text: correct that error. That is really what the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is about. But I think the backdrop to the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is of even more interest to the community I

Speaker: NA
Text: represent at Dunkley by the bay down on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mornington Peninsula.

Speaker: NA
Text: This debate has been around for some

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and it often gets entangled in the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of school funding and whether government

Speaker: NA
Text: and non-government schools are better or

Speaker: NA
Text: worse. These are the areas that you see

Speaker: NA
Text: played out in the media as being the big

Speaker: NA
Text: points of discussion about education policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even the previous speaker, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory, spoke at length about

Speaker: NA
Text: his involvement in the education sector and

Speaker: NA
Text: about some argy-bargy that it is going on in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory. That may interest

Speaker: NA
Text: some in this House, but isn't this about the

Speaker: NA
Text: kids? Isn't it about developing their skills

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can achieve a situation in our coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try-because of the strength in our economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: our social fabric and our standard of living-

Speaker: NA
Text: where the opportunities and the pathways for

Speaker: NA
Text: our young people into adulthood are as good,

Speaker: NA
Text: as rewarding and as rich and delicious as

Speaker: NA
Text: they can be? Isn't that really what this is

Speaker: NA
Text: about? And today we are discussing another

Speaker: NA
Text: measure that the government has put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure our kids have the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: tools.

Speaker: NA
Text: The OECD is reported today as recognis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our country as the fastest growing in the

Speaker: NA
Text: developed world. That is a great credit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Don't we want our young people to be part

Speaker: NA
Text: of that? One of their passports to satisfying

Speaker: NA
Text: lifestyles and opportunities for fulfilment is

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the tools to contribute to that econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy and to participate in our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what numeracy and literacy are

Speaker: NA
Text: about. It gets a little tiresome when we hear

Speaker: NA
Text: people arguing about other issues-for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, I refer to the atmospherics in the

Speaker: NA
Text: theatre of politics in the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: when the government was elected. Thirteen

Speaker: NA
Text: years of Labor gave us 30 per cent of young

Speaker: NA
Text: kids in years 3 and 5 being unable to read

Speaker: NA
Text: and write at an acceptable level. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: rageous in a country like ours.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Kemp has done a remarkable job in

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing a sound set of policies. History

Speaker: NA
Text: will look on his time as education minister as

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the most progressive and forward-

Speaker: NA
Text: looking eras of education policy in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Labor looked after only those who

Speaker: NA
Text: went on to university. As a former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: minister said, Labor was not interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: people who did not go to university. That

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected an attitude on the part of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party that education is only about going to

Speaker: NA
Text: university. It is not. Seventy per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australians do not go on to university,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is 80 per cent in the community that I

Speaker: NA
Text: represent. Surely we have a responsibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop their capacity to be productive, en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged, satisfied citizens. I emphasise that

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy and literacy competency must be

Speaker: NA
Text: the building blocks of that. Shortly after Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kemp was appointed education minister, he

Speaker: NA
Text: came across the statistics that the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: education minister, Kim Beazley, now

Speaker: NA
Text: so Leader of the Opposition, had hidden. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search had been going on for some time into

Speaker: NA
Text: the literacy skills of many young Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Labor Party had that data but would

Speaker: NA
Text: not release it. It told nobody about the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: graceful circumstance that the Labor gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment presided over: that one-third of our

Speaker: NA
Text: kids in years 3 and 5 could not read and

Speaker: NA
Text: write properly. Dr Kemp flagged that literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy would be the number one pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ority of the Howard government.

Speaker: NA
Text: To develop those skills we opened new

Speaker: NA
Text: doors and new pathways for young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Numeracy and literacy have remained central

Speaker: NA
Text: to the coalition's education policies because

Speaker: NA
Text: they are important, for the reasons that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: explained. It is important to secure educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional opportunities and skill development

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects and to access programs that are

Speaker: NA
Text: available in that area. It is very much about

Speaker: NA
Text: people's ability to participate fully in our

Speaker: NA
Text: modern society, to be productive citizens and

Speaker: NA
Text: to be engaged in our community. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's goal is that every student

Speaker: NA
Text: will achieve adequate literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: skills by the end of primary school. Part of

Speaker: NA
Text: that commitment was the National Literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and Numeracy Plan, which has been agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: out- to by all states as an endorsement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: goals that the federal government has ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticulated and of the leadership that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided. A lot of state governments must

Speaker: NA
Text: have been asleep at the wheel at that time to

Speaker: NA
Text: have allowed 30 per cent of young people in

Speaker: NA
Text: years 3 and 5 to move through the school

Speaker: NA
Text: system without being properly skilled in nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy and literacy. In April 2000, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned, through Minister Kemp's advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cacy and the federal government's leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship, there is finally an agreement of ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved literacy and numeracy benchmarks

Speaker: NA
Text: for years 3, 5, and 7. We now have some

Speaker: NA
Text: goals and targets. The agreed national meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures are a way of evaluating whether the bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lions of dollars we invest in education are

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing about improvements in those skill

Speaker: NA
Text: areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 1999 year 3 benchmark results, which

Speaker: NA
Text: were the first results under the national

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmarks system, showed that on average

Speaker: NA
Text: 86.9 per cent of year 7 students achieved the

Speaker: NA
Text: reading benchmark. What is most important

Speaker: NA
Text: about that figure is not the percentage who

Speaker: NA
Text: passed but the percentage who did not pass.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are reducing the proportion of students

Speaker: NA
Text: who are not achieving that level of perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. That has been standardised across the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation and it shows education authorities,

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers and jurisdictions what needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done in targeting resources where there is

Speaker: NA
Text: underperformance in numeracy and literacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: A good example of that was the result among

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous kids. Whereas the general popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation average is 86.9 per cent, indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: kids scored significantly lower- 66.1 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. That reinforces the point that the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for the Northern Territory made. That

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence shows that there is a need for more

Speaker: NA
Text: work to be done. The whole point of the

Speaker: NA
Text: framework is to target assistance and to

Speaker: NA
Text: identify areas where skills are not being de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped to enable our citizens to be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in our community. As a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmarks, some action has followed. In-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous literacy is funded under the Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Education (Targeted Assistance) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000. More money is directed into early days

Speaker: NA
Text: and into early intervention, because from the

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmark we know that work needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: You would think that the advantage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmarking system would be pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: darned obvious. You would think that if you

Speaker: NA
Text: had that information you could identify

Speaker: NA
Text: where to put your education resources. All

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories have agreed that that

Speaker: NA
Text: helpful, and you would think that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: done that because it is patently obvious why

Speaker: NA
Text: it is helpful. However, Victoria is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: state where, rather than testing all students,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a sample. For reasons that no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: can quite understand, Minister Mary Dela-

Speaker: NA
Text: hunty does not want to test all Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: schoolkids' literacy and numeracy standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why not test all the kids? Why not give the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents information about how the kids and

Speaker: NA
Text: their schools are going? Why doesn't the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister want that information herself so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian education department can

Speaker: NA
Text: identify school communities where nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy and literacy are not the priority that

Speaker: NA
Text: they need to be and then take action to fix

Speaker: NA
Text: that? Surely that is helpful. What does Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister Mary Delahunty have to hide? Why will

Speaker: NA
Text: she not have all Victorian school children in

Speaker: NA
Text: years 3, 5 and 7 tested against the national

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy benchmarks? Why

Speaker: NA
Text: not? What is wrong with telling parents that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the performance in our schools? Why

Speaker: NA
Text: is Victoria the only jurisdiction where that is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening? She refuses to test all year 7 stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents and opts for a sampling test as an alter-

Speaker: NA
Text: native. Frankly, why do parents need to miss

Speaker: NA
Text: out on that information? Parents deserve and

Speaker: NA
Text: want to know whether their child can read

Speaker: NA
Text: and write at the national standards. A cult of

Speaker: NA
Text: secrecy seems to be important to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Education in Victoria. It bedevils state

Speaker: NA
Text: education policy. It is like saying, ‘Don't tell

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody.' It is like saying, ‘Don't speak

Speaker: NA
Text: about the war.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes you have to talk about things

Speaker: NA
Text: to move on. In this case, you should talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the performance tests against these

Speaker: NA
Text: national standards so that parents, school

Speaker: NA
Text: communities and the students can understand

Speaker: NA
Text: how they are going. Surely that is not too

Speaker: NA
Text: much to ask. However, apparently in Victo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ria, it is too much to ask. Perhaps she is fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing Kim Beazley's lead when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: education minister. He had those scandalous

Speaker: NA
Text: figures showing that almost one-third of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian schoolchildren were unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: read and write at an acceptable level. He had

Speaker: NA
Text: those figures when he was eduction minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and he kept them hidden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is Minister Mary Delahunty in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: is following Kim Beazley's lead? I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: quite sure about that, but it does open up an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other interesting story. We have heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party about their education policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the hallmarks of that policy is to rip

Speaker: NA
Text: money off some school communities and

Speaker: NA
Text: redirect it to others. One of the areas Kim

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley is talking about putting extra money

Speaker: NA
Text: into is school facilities. When he talks about

Speaker: NA
Text: it, he doubles the amount. What you do not

Speaker: NA
Text: hear, but what is in the fine print, is that

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley's pledge to increase funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: school facilities in government schools relies

Speaker: NA
Text: upon state and territory governments match-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing whatever federal money Kim Beazley

Speaker: NA
Text: finds on his bankcard.

Speaker: NA
Text: That matching requirement is an interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing point. There was a near revolt right

Speaker: NA
Text: across Victorian school communities be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause, at a time when the Bracks government

Speaker: NA
Text: had inherited a huge budget surplus, a treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure chest of resources to invest in public

Speaker: NA
Text: works and community services in Victoria,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bracks government came up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: most pitiful, pathetic effort for school fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It came up with a microscopic increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in funding. It was a funding increase which,

Speaker: NA
Text: when compared to what the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: had done, was an embarrassment to the Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: torian Labor government. So again a call was

Speaker: NA
Text: made to Minister Mary Delahunty by school

Speaker: NA
Text: communities across Australia: ‘Why are

Speaker: NA
Text: school communities missing out on extra

Speaker: NA
Text: resources when there is this huge budget sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus left behind by the Kennett government?'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mary Delahunty said, ‘Well, there's no more

Speaker: NA
Text: money for education in Victoria.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The interesting test now is that Kim

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley's education policy relies upon a

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian state government matching this

Speaker: NA
Text: extra capital funding that Kim Beazley will

Speaker: NA
Text: whip off his bankcard. The test will be in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. It will be interesting to see if

Speaker: NA
Text: ister Mary Delahunty, who has told parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: students and school communities right across

Speaker: NA
Text: our great state that there is no extra money

Speaker: NA
Text: for education, and that there is no extra

Speaker: NA
Text: money for our kids in Victoria, finds extra

Speaker: NA
Text: money for Kim-for the Labor Party. Won't

Speaker: NA
Text: that tell us something? It will tell us that

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley's education policy relies on the

Speaker: NA
Text: states matching additional funding for capital

Speaker: NA
Text: works in government schools. It relies on a

Speaker: NA
Text: state Labor government in Victoria matching

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever extra dollars Kim Beazley can

Speaker: NA
Text: whip off a bankcard.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no money for the kids, but will

Speaker: NA
Text: there be money for Kim? That is the question

Speaker: NA
Text: about education in Victoria and the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's policy. It will tell us something: was

Speaker: NA
Text: Mary Delahunty telling the truth that, for

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever reason despite there being sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: Kim pluses of biblical proportions that they in-

Speaker: NA
Text: herited off the Kennett government, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no extra money or crumbs for the edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation portfolio in Victoria, or will there be

Speaker: NA
Text: money for Kim? Won't that be an interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: test? Is she more interested in looking after

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party and playing party politics-

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australians are tired of party politics-

Speaker: NA
Text: cash for Kim, but no cash for the kids in our

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in Victoria? That will be an interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing test. Whatever the outcome is, either

Speaker: NA
Text: Mary Delahunty was telling the truth and

Speaker: NA
Text: Kim Beazley's education policy is already a

Speaker: NA
Text: fraud, or she was misleading the families and

Speaker: NA
Text: school communities in Victoria and she will

Speaker: NA
Text: find the money to match Kim's election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment-no cash for kids, cash for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kim. That will be an interesting test and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will get to see it shortly.

Speaker: NA
Text: This matters to me because I am a school

Speaker: NA
Text: council president at Monterey Secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: College in Frankston North. I work alongside

Speaker: NA
Text: the parents, the school community, the

Speaker: NA
Text: teaching professionals and the leadership

Speaker: NA
Text: group at the school. They are a fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: bunch of people who are working very hard

Speaker: NA
Text: to make the resources available to deliver the

Speaker: NA
Text: best educational opportunities for our kids in

Speaker: NA
Text: Dunkley by the bay in Frankston North. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will be an interesting test to see whether Kim

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley's education policy will stand up af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter Mary Delahunty stood up to the students,

Speaker: NA
Text: Min- parents and school communities in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: That highlights another great irony in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party's education policy. The Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party has moved an amendment to the States

Speaker: NA
Text: Grants (Primary and Secondary Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001, arguing

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government is somehow using liter-

Speaker: NA
Text: Kim acy data for political advantage. That is code

Speaker: NA
Text: for, ‘Gee, the Labor Party has been found

Speaker: NA
Text: out.' We have released the data which Kim

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley sought to hide about one-third of our

Speaker: NA
Text: kids at years 3 and 5 not being able to read

Speaker: NA
Text: and write properly. We are fessing up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community, and the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: can only describe that as political advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: So is highlighting their incompetence politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal advantage? It may be, but that is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of this. This is just to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we get the job fixed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other interesting point is that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about ripping money off non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools, on the gross assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: that only wealthy people go to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. Down my way, a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: families have two jobs. One job pays for the

Speaker: NA
Text: education of their kids. That is a choice. The

Speaker: NA
Text: families have decided that that is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment they want to make. They want

Speaker: NA
Text: to make that commitment to their kids and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are putting in a lot of work and earning

Speaker: NA
Text: an extra income just to be able to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: that. However, you would not know that if

Speaker: NA
Text: you listened to the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the money that a future La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor government-heaven forbid if one was

Speaker: NA
Text: ever elected- plan to rip off these non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools, they have already said

Speaker: NA
Text: on their web site that they are going to send

Speaker: NA
Text: that money off to capital investments in pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic schools-and I have already highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: how that is a bogus claim in Victoria-and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide some teaching scholarships and do

Speaker: NA
Text: some extra training for teachers. They do not

Speaker: NA
Text: mention anything at all on their web site

Speaker: NA
Text: about this funding rip-off from non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools going to literacy. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, in the amendment-guess what?-they

Speaker: NA
Text: have decided that they are going to spend the

Speaker: NA
Text: money on that as well. This is about phoney

Speaker: NA
Text: figures and dodgy maths. All of a sudden,

Speaker: NA
