Text: this money is going to have a literacy focus.

Speaker: NA
Text: They had better go back and update their

Speaker: NA
Text: web site.

Speaker: NA
Text: The great irony about this debate is that

Speaker: NA
Text: highlights the hypocrisy and internal incon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistencies in the Labor Party's education

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. They talk about resources being made

Speaker: NA
Text: available on the basis of need, yet when the

Speaker: NA
Text: government introduces a needs based policy

Speaker: NA
Text: for funding non-government schools, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party oppose it. The old state aid de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate is still resonating in the back corridors

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Party faction machine. We

Speaker: NA
Text: thought we had passed that years ago. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party talk out of the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: their mouth they are saying that education is

Speaker: NA
Text: a public good and we should get behind it,

Speaker: NA
Text: but somehow what comes through is this

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred of non-government schools when

Speaker: NA
Text: there are decent Australians just trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that their kids have the best possi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble start in life. I support this bill and I over-

Speaker: NA
Text: whelmingly endorse Minister Kemp's efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: in the education portfolio. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MOSSFIELD
Text: Greenway) (10.52

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m.)-I rise to speak on the States Grants

Speaker: NA
Text: (Primary and Secondary Education Assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance) Amendment Bill 2001 and to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment moved by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dobell. In considering this bill, I believe it is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to consider the broad education

Speaker: NA
Text: issues that we face today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill amends the States Grants (Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary and Secondary Education Assistance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 2000 to provide funding for literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy programs for the years 2001-02

Speaker: NA
Text: and 2002-03. If this were extra funding, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be clearly welcomed. However, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not extra funding; it is funding that is basi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally being rebadged. In addition, in deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ering literacy and numeracy programs, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to have a high standard of facilities in

Speaker: NA
Text: our schools, and that is an issue that I will

Speaker: NA
Text: address in my speech this morning. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: also like to refer to a part of the speech that

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Dobell made yesterday in

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular debate where he highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is not extra funding but actually re-

Speaker: NA
Text: badged money. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem is that it is minimal extra funding; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is simply rebadging the old Disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: Schools Program and rebadging the English as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Language Program- even wrapping up

Speaker: NA
Text: into it some of the special education program

Speaker: NA
Text: money-and claiming that that is going to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about literacy. If the government wants

Speaker: NA
Text: it to really do something about improving literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australian schools we need to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are targeting the extra funding into the schools

Speaker: NA
Text: that need the most help. That is why the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party is proposing to establish education priority

Speaker: NA
Text: zones to put extra Commonwealth funding into

Speaker: NA
Text: schools that need the most help.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members would be aware that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Principals Association recently

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioned a report entitled Our future, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which Max Angus and Harriet Olney of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Edith Cowan University surveyed 2,452

Speaker: NA
Text: primary school principals and deputy princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: pals across the country to canvass their views

Speaker: NA
Text: on school resources and the future of public

Speaker: NA
Text: education. In an introductory letter sent to all

Speaker: NA
Text: federal members, Tony Misich, the President

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Primary Principals Asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation, states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary school principals have long been worried

Speaker: NA
Text: about the increasing demands on schools, without

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving additional resources. Anecdotally and

Speaker: NA
Text: individually, we have been worried that the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary school dollar can stretch no further.

Speaker: NA
Text: He goes on to point out four main areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: concern. The first is resources. He states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Principals feared a number of negative conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences resulting from insufficient resources in

Speaker: NA
Text: government primary schools. They expressed a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear need for an increase in a) funding, b)

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, c) teaching and specialist staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that, when he talks about the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for teaching and specialist staff, he is clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to teachers who would be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver these literacy and numeracy pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams that are so vital in our schools. He

Speaker: NA
Text: also names administrative support and proper

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership structures as other areas of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: source concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second point he makes is that 80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of principals believe that their schools

Speaker: NA
Text: are underfunded in terms of what they are

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to achieve. The principals are often

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to take resources from one area of

Speaker: NA
Text: need in order to fund another area of need.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third point that Tony Misich makes is

Speaker: NA
Text: under the subheading ‘Policies and Ethos'.

Speaker: NA
Text: He states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The majority of principals attributed importance

Speaker: NA
Text: to academic performance, the development of a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong work ethic, conservation of the natural

Speaker: NA
Text: environment and respect for adults. Principals

Speaker: NA
Text: believe schools should reflect the values of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wider community, not just those found in local

Speaker: NA
Text: communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most telling point in that letter is the

Speaker: NA
Text: fourth point under the subheading of ‘The

Speaker: NA
Text: Future'. The report unfortunately shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘government primary school principals are

Speaker: NA
Text: generally pessimistic about the context in

Speaker: NA
Text: which schools will operate in the future',

Speaker: NA
Text: although he does point out that there is a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: gree of confidence in their capacity to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain standards regardless and a determination

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so, and that almost half believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools will continue to perform

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Our future report runs to some 46

Speaker: NA
Text: pages, which makes for some very interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing reading. I will quote it later, but first I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to say a few basic things about

Speaker: NA
Text: education in general. It is my belief that a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and vibrant education system forms

Speaker: NA
Text: the foundation stone of a free and democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: society, and any attack on public education is

Speaker: NA
Text: an attack on democracy itself. Historically,

Speaker: NA
Text: the call for, and the establishment of, public

Speaker: NA
Text: education went hand in hand with the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment of a modern democratic state. Mass

Speaker: NA
Text: public education helped to end feudalism as

Speaker: NA
Text: facilia system of government. Nations that have

Speaker: NA
Text: no publicly provided education system do

Speaker: NA
Text: not prosper. Children are the future of our

Speaker: NA
Text: country and their education is fundamental to

Speaker: NA
Text: that future. This is a cliche, of course, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a cliche simply because it is true and obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous and it should go without saying. Unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately, we have to say it because some

Speaker: NA
Text: people do not seem to believe it. Some peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple do not seem to believe in public educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion; some see education as a privilege, not a

Speaker: NA
Text: right. They are wrong; they are very wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are already too many barriers in our

Speaker: NA
Text: society for many children. Wealth, geogra-

Speaker: NA
Text: phy, the economic environment and technol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy are just a few. We should not and we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot allow the lack of access to education

Speaker: NA
Text: to be one of these barriers. Public education

Speaker: NA
Text: is fundamental to the future of our nation; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is fundamental. As representatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people, we have a very important role to

Speaker: NA
Text: play. We are the keepers of the purse strings,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is time to loosen these purse strings

Speaker: NA
Text: and provide an education system that will

Speaker: NA
Text: take us into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no point bickering over whose re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility it is-state or federal-to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide for the education of our children. That

Speaker: NA
Text: time has passed. That is an old way of

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking; that is last century's way of think-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. I would have thought that the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: millennium and a century of federation

Speaker: NA
Text: would have focused our minds and our ideas

Speaker: NA
Text: on the future. Unfortunately, this government

Speaker: NA
Text: have been so wrapped up in the never, ever

Speaker: NA
Text: of tax changes and in implementing a 1960s

Speaker: NA
Text: French socialist tax that they have taken their

Speaker: NA
Text: eyes off the future and the fundamentals. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have been mired in a bog of everyday petty

Speaker: NA
Text: politics as a result. The report, Our future,

Speaker: NA
Text: gives us a chance to refocus, to examine the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems that exist in the system today and

Speaker: NA
Text: to work towards the type of change that is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to bring public education into the

Speaker: NA
Text: 21st century. There are problems; they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been identified and we should not be stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing around simply passing the buck: ‘It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: our responsibility, it is the state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments' responsibility.' Wrong again. It is eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: rybody's responsibility. Parents, teachers,

Speaker: NA
Text: students, community leaders, state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and federal governments-we all have

Speaker: NA
Text: a part to play.

Speaker: NA
Text: The recent launch of the Knowledge Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion task force report shows that Labor have

Speaker: NA
Text: a plan for the future, a far-reaching and vi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionary plan, yet this government dismisses

Speaker: NA
Text: it out of hand. If they did not

Speaker: NA
Text: then it is not worthy of thought. Wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: again. The government's reaction to the

Speaker: NA
Text: launch of Knowledge Nation amply demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strates the lack of vision this government

Speaker: NA
Text: have when it comes to education and educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional issues. They may have wound back the

Speaker: NA
Text: despicable enrolment benchmark adjustment,

Speaker: NA
Text: but that cannot make up for all the money

Speaker: NA
Text: that has already been ripped out of the public

Speaker: NA
Text: education system of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we look at the history of our nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: we can point to a number of what have been

Speaker: NA
Text: called nation building projects, such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy Mountains scheme. I would like fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture generations to be able to look back, at

Speaker: NA
Text: the turn of this century, and point to educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion as a great nation building project. What

Speaker: NA
Text: better form of nation building can there be

Speaker: NA
Text: than to build up our education system to

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is the best in the world? One hun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dred per cent of our future citizens will at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tend primary schools, 70 per cent will attend

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. Nation building is not

Speaker: NA
Text: easy. It requires a huge commitment of both

Speaker: NA
Text: money and resources. It requires a vision

Speaker: NA
Text: from our leaders and it requires hard work

Speaker: NA
Text: from the rest of us. Governing is about pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: orities, and education needs to be placed at

Speaker: NA
Text: the top of the list. It is time to stop buck-

Speaker: NA
Text: passing. It is time to roll up our sleeves and

Speaker: NA
Text: get stuck into it. If we want to face the chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges that are before us today with any de-

Speaker: NA
Text: gree of confidence and skill, then we must

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in the education of our children. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is no short-term financial return, no quick

Speaker: NA
Text: stock market dollar, to be made from this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The payout will come many years down the

Speaker: NA
Text: track when our children have grown and

Speaker: NA
Text: taken their place in the new society that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be building. That is why governments

Speaker: NA
Text: must be involved. This is not something for

Speaker: NA
Text: the private sector preoccupied with a quick

Speaker: NA
Text: return on their investment. This is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: realm of the public domain; it is the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's responsibility. That is why govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments exist-to provide services to the peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, to provide for the education of our

Speaker: NA
Text: young.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said I would return in more detail to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Our future report. I will start with some

Speaker: NA
Text: comments from the executive summary of

Speaker: NA
Text: think of it first, that report:

Speaker: NA
Text: Literacy resources were a high priority for addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional funding. These included a wide range of

Speaker: NA
Text: needs such as guided reading materials, storage

Speaker: NA
Text: space, literacy expertise and increased staffing

Speaker: NA
Text: levels to allow for small and one to one instruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The need for larger, more functional class-

Speaker: NA
Text: rooms were also linked to concerns about literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an area we have to get right. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: area that requires constant revision and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stant adaptation. Without literacy there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: education. The States Grants (Primary and

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000

Speaker: NA
Text: would go part of the way to addressing that

Speaker: NA
Text: concern if, in fact, there were new money in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. We on this side of the House say that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no new money. The report went on

Speaker: NA
Text: to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The introduction of information communication

Speaker: NA
Text: technology into schools was identified as having

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly increased the recurrent cost of prime

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. The costs of establishing networks and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining and upgrading computer systems

Speaker: NA
Text: were cited as a common problem in schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology was also seen as requiring additional

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise and increased staff time. It is a resource

Speaker: NA
Text: that has great value as a learning tool, however.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budgets have simply not kept pace with the

Speaker: NA
Text: technological advances that have occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years. Inadequate resources in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area have led to a rapid increase in what is

Speaker: NA
Text: now known as the digital divide, and it rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resents one of those barriers I talked about

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier. The report also said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Pressure to provide curriculum breadth was

Speaker: NA
Text: linked to parental expectations and the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the eight key learning areas. Many princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: pals expressed concern that their schools were

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to provide music and physical education.

Speaker: NA
Text: They said that schools need suitable areas, staff

Speaker: NA
Text: with specialist skills and higher staffing levels

Speaker: NA
Text: order to provide such programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not enough to simply provide for read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, writing and arithmetic. Education is

Speaker: NA
Text: more than that, and we need to provide for

Speaker: NA
Text: more than just that. Limited resources re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire prioritisation and, when you prioritise,

Speaker: NA
Text: naturally some miss out. As the report

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, some principals believed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: most needy students were receiving the help

Speaker: NA
Text: they require. That is certainly a good, posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive point coming from the principals. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the problem occurs when trying to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: source programs for those students in the

Speaker: NA
Text: next level up of relative needs. This, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is most unsatisfactory. It basically

Speaker: NA
Text: means there are insufficient funds in total

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the funds have to be directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: where the principals feel there is most need;

Speaker: NA
Text: but the report has suggested that the needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most needy are being met. Three-quarters

Speaker: NA
Text: of the principals were against policies based

Speaker: NA
Text: on competition theories and did not accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that schools should be penalised when par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents withdraw children, which happened un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the enrolment benchmark adjustment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education cannot be based on competition,

Speaker: NA
Text: because competition, by its very nature, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duces winners and losers, and usually more

Speaker: NA
Text: losers than winners. Education must be uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versal.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the majority of principals indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that their facilities were adequate, some 26

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent- more than a quarter-indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that schools were badly in need of facility

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrades. This would again indicate a vast

Speaker: NA
Text: gap in the facilities of schools. Some obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously are fairly well equipped, and many are

Speaker: NA
Text: not. Some principals raised concerns about

Speaker: NA
Text: not being able to protect students from the

Speaker: NA
Text: sun, wind, rain and, in some locations, even

Speaker: NA
Text: snow during physical education classes and

Speaker: NA
Text: school assemblies and when moving between

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings. I know from personal experience

Speaker: NA
Text: of visiting schools in my own electorate that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a problem-not necessarily with snow

Speaker: NA
Text: but certainly with the other elements.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also aware that many school com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities themselves-parents and citizens-

Speaker: NA
Text: are raising the money for these facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: This issue was raised in an article in the Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney Morning Herald on 30 July when a sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: in vey conducted by the Sydney Morning Her-

Speaker: NA
Text: ald of P&C associations at 90 schools

Speaker: NA
Text: showed that parents are even paying for such

Speaker: NA
Text: basic items as gas and electricity, which in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact are not fully funded by the state gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment funding program. Funds raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: individual P&Cs, according to this article,

Speaker: NA
Text: ranged from $500 to more than $100,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: with one school in my own electorate, Kings

Speaker: NA
Text: Langley, raising some $60,000. In the Our

Speaker: NA
Text: Future report, reliance on outside sources for

Speaker: NA
Text: funding was seen as a problem by 91 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the respondents.

Speaker: NA
Text: While speaking about my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Greenway in an adjournment debate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Main Committee on 29 March, I tabled a list

Speaker: NA
Text: of urgent maintenance items that schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate required. I said in tabling the

Speaker: NA
Text: list that schools were not asking for the

Speaker: NA
Text: world; they were simply asking for basic

Speaker: NA
Text: items such as toilet and bubbler upgrades,

Speaker: NA
Text: first aid/sick bay facilities, decent security

Speaker: NA
Text: systems and airconditioning. I pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that, even if some of these schools received

Speaker: NA
Text: airconditioning, they would have trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: turning it on because, without an upgrade,

Speaker: NA
Text: the power system would blow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week I visited another very good

Speaker: NA
Text: school in my electorate, Blacktown South

Speaker: NA
Text: Public School, which has just under 700 stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents. The buildings are 40 years old and so

Speaker: NA
Text: is the wiring, and airconditioning, though

Speaker: NA
Text: desperately needed, would be virtually use-

Speaker: NA
Text: less because of the age of the power system.

Speaker: NA
Text: It needs at least $35,000 to upgrade the wir-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing before it can even think about something

Speaker: NA
Text: like airconditioning. In summer, the tem-

Speaker: NA
Text: peratures soar and the children and teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer, and they will continue to suffer until

Speaker: NA
Text: something is done to fix the problem. The

Speaker: NA
Text: school's classrooms have not been painted in

Speaker: NA
Text: 24 years and the students' artworks can only

Speaker: NA
Text: go so far to cover up the paintwork. Black-

Speaker: NA
Text: town South is a typical school with dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: staff achieving great results under severe

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions, and I think it is time that we as

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, both state and federal, helped

Speaker: NA
Text: these types of schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will give $33 million to literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy programs over the next two

Speaker: NA
Text: years. If this is real funding, it is still

Speaker: NA
Text: drop in the ocean. In its submission to the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales government for this year's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, the New South Wales Primary Prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipals Association identified the need for at

Speaker: NA
Text: least an extra $333 million to redress the ero-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of funding in real terms and enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: essential programs that I have been referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to in this speech to continue-$333 million

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales alone is what is needed

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring the system up to par. Add the other

Speaker: NA
Text: states into the mix and the figure is obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously much higher.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome of course whatever money is in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget for education. Any money put

Speaker: NA
Text: towards educational programs is welcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, let us be serious. Compared to

Speaker: NA
Text: what is needed in the primary sector alone-

Speaker: NA
Text: let alone the secondary sector-this is noth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and we need to be talking about bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: issues than just what is represented here in

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation. This bill represents no more

Speaker: NA
Text: than one step in a marathon race. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: still another 42 kilometres to go, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: pack is moving away in the distance and we

Speaker: NA
Text: are in danger of falling back amongst the

Speaker: NA
Text: stragglers, limping home after dark.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, just returning to the Our Future

Speaker: NA
Text: report for a moment, it is important to know

Speaker: NA
Text: that, while it was commissioned by and fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cused wholly on the government or public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, it was also supported by the private

Speaker: NA
Text: school principals as well. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Principals Association is made up of

Speaker: NA
Text: both public and private schools, and that as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociation strongly supports the report calling

Speaker: NA
Text: for more resources for public schools. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: time to stop the bickering and buck passing.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is time to put the federal-state divide be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hind us and look at education as a national

Speaker: NA
Text: priority; it is a chance for some truly monu-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental nation building. Only then will the

Speaker: NA
Text: money come, and then the resources. Only

Speaker: NA
Text: then will we start to make progress towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the knowledge nation that we all can be and

Speaker: NA
Text: that we need to be.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The chair

Speaker: NA
Text: might say that it is very pleased that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Greenway's scaffolding did not

Speaker: NA
Text: collapse during the course of his speech.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Text: Hinkler) (11.12 a.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the States Grants (Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: only a and Secondary Education Assistance) Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill 2001 is to provide additional

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for literacy and numeracy programs

Speaker: NA
Text: for the years 2001-02 and 2002-03. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to stand here today as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party, having been able to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: real difference in government to the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: children at schools in my electorate. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: that quite sincerely. We are making ground

Speaker: NA
Text: on numeracy and literacy, but the work is not

Speaker: NA
Text: finished, and unfortunately there are negative

Speaker: NA
Text: and cynical forces trying to keep children

Speaker: NA
Text: and schools from Bundaberg to Gladstone in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate in the dark ages and their par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents in the dark.

Speaker: NA
Text: I visit a lot of schools in my work, and

Speaker: NA
Text: lately I have made visits to South Kolan

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary School, Faith Baptist School, Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Morgan State High School, Mount Larcom

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary departments and St Stephen's

Speaker: NA
Text: College. At the secondary schools, I pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented the Centenary of Federation book on

Speaker: NA
Text: Edmund Barton. I just hope that the state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor education minister, the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Teachers Union and the federal ALP give

Speaker: NA
Text: those primary school students whom I visited

Speaker: NA
Text: a fighting chance to be able to read that book

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the secondary school children in the

Speaker: NA
Text: schools I visited will receive the remedial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance with their reading if they require

Speaker: NA
Text: it. The Labor state education minister, Anna

Speaker: NA
Text: Bligh, is, quite frankly, hiding the truth about

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy standards from the parents of

Speaker: NA
Text: schoolchildren in Bundaberg, Burnett, Isis,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Coral Coast, Miriam Vale, Discovery

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast and Central Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report on literacy and numeracy stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards issued by the Queensland School Cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: riculum Council last week reveals that al-

Speaker: NA
Text: most 22 per cent of year 5 students in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland did not meet the national

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmark standards last year. That means

Speaker: NA
Text: that one in five students or, if you like, six in

Speaker: NA
Text: every average class have fallen behind. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: aren't the QTU up in arms about that? I

Speaker: NA
Text: would have thought that that would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been a fundamental social issue in this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate on education. Minister Anna Bligh will

Speaker: NA
Text: not even tell the parents in the Hinkler elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate whether their children can read or

Speaker: NA
Text: write to the national standard levels for their

Speaker: NA
Text: age groups. Instead, she voted with the other

Speaker: NA
Text: state Labor education ministers to reject the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's proposal that the states

Speaker: NA
Text: should tell each parent how their child's

Speaker: NA
Text: reading, writing, spelling and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement compares with national literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy benchmark standards. She will

Speaker: NA
Text: not tell them because the figures are not

Speaker: NA
Text: good and people might start questioning the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that, despite $5 billion in a GST windfall

Speaker: NA
Text: going to the Beattie government in this

Speaker: NA
Text: year's budget, that government did not even

Speaker: NA
Text: match the federal government's education

Speaker: NA
Text: funding increase to state schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: A half-completed footbridge across the

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane River in Brisbane and a football

Speaker: NA
Text: stadium that few seem to want are amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: $700 million worth of unnecessary expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture being used to build monuments in Bris-

Speaker: NA
Text: bane. These works seems to be more impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant to the Labor Party in Queensland than

Speaker: NA
Text: the school children in Bundaberg and

Speaker: NA
Text: Gladstone being able to read or write. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: very quick to criticise the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment if we do not do something in the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate, but it is very slow to order its priorinised

Speaker: NA
Text: ties when it can build stadiums and foot-

Speaker: NA
Text: bridges at the expense of children receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: basic education. Anna Bligh, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: other state education ministers, then tried to

Speaker: NA
Text: put up a smokescreen by attacking the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Literacy and Numeracy Plan. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that is just a taste of what parents in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate could expect if Labor were to be

Speaker: NA
Text: successful in the coming federal election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Talk about roll-back, Labor wants to roll

Speaker: NA
Text: back the national benchmark tests because

Speaker: NA
Text: the teachers' unions oppose them-simply

Speaker: NA
Text: for that reason. The Queensland Teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: Union is running a purely political campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the ALP, knowing that the ALP

Speaker: NA
Text: will dismantle the literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives if elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government will never compromise

Speaker: NA
Text: on the education of Australian students by

Speaker: NA
Text: backing away from its literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy, and I fully support the efforts of

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Kemp, who has visited my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate on two occasions where this has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: seminal issue. By contrast, Minister Anna

Speaker: NA
Text: Bligh's refusal to tell parents whether their

Speaker: NA
Text: children can read or write at national stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards shows that she thinks very little of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents, the P&Cs and the schoolchildren

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. She obviously believes that lit-

Speaker: NA
Text: eracy and numeracy testing results are too

Speaker: NA
Text: politically dangerous in the hands of parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: who quite rightly demand that their children

Speaker: NA
Text: are properly schooled and skilled in the ba-

Speaker: NA
Text: sics. In refusing to be accountable to parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Anna Bligh is following the lead of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition who, as educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion minister, hid from parents the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: one-third of Australia's school children were

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to read or write to acceptable stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards.

Speaker: NA
Text: A knowledge nation will not work if 30

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the children of that nation cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: read or write. If you cannot get the funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentals right, you are going nowhere with

Speaker: NA
Text: the other programs. This hypocrisy seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: know no bounds. Yesterday morning, when I

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the Courier-Mail editorial that my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues have already alluded to in this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate, I had a feeling that for the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: justice is finally being done. At last, a sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Queensland media have recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: the paucity of Labor's claims and, to

Speaker: NA
Text: quote from the Courier-Mail itself, how

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘dishonest' was the campaign of the QTU. I

Speaker: NA
Text: just hope that the rest of the media, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the media in my electorate, are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: see through the QTU's patently dishonest

Speaker: NA
Text: marginal seats campaign. When it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocrisy on this issue, the media does not

Speaker: NA
Text: have too far to look.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Bundaberg, my Labor opponent's cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign manager is also, believe it or not, the

Speaker: NA
Text: local QTU spokesman, Greg Purches. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that this creates a situation where voters

Speaker: NA
Text: can clearly see that the union are nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a cheerleader for the local Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. Their arguments are transparent, mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: leading-dare I say, sleazy-and, if taken to

Speaker: NA
Text: their ultimate ends, dangerous for kids. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would welcome the chance to debate with

Speaker: NA
Text: them on this issue in front of parents, teach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and P&Cs, but I doubt that they will have

Speaker: NA
Text: the guts, because I believe their campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: would be far too easily exposed. It is an echo

Speaker: NA
Text: of the AMWU's campaign in Hinkler in

Speaker: NA
Text: which they claim that the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: done nothing for manufacturing in the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate. Anyone who knows the industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: towns of Australia will know that Gladstone

Speaker: NA
Text: is the powerhouse of good industry-yet

Speaker: NA
Text: they persist with this. It is part of this parallel

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign of the union running alongside the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party, trying to create this marginal

Speaker: NA
Text: seats imagery where they say, ‘Oh, these

Speaker: NA
Text: things are not being looked after in this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular marginal seat.' But, in talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: the AMWU-and I am not going to dwell on

Speaker: NA
Text: this-nothing could be further from the truth,

Speaker: NA
Text: and local people know it.

Speaker: NA
Text: As of yesterday, I can identify $219 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion that has been allocated by the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government to industry seed funding or fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: cilitation, or for trade promotion to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: local industries. I note that the minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table, the Minister for Trade, was in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate last week as part of that facilita-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. He had a lot to do with the $100 million

Speaker: NA
Text: announced last night for AMC; he was actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally at AMC with me as recently as last

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday. He has also been responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: $9 million worth of EMDG grants to export

Speaker: NA
Text: industries in my electorate. So the AMWU's

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign has no substance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me return to the QTU, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: been following a similar tactic with the ALP.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have been in my electorate with mobile

Speaker: NA
Text: billboards on the backs of trucks. Again, this

Speaker: NA
Text: is part of a blatantly misleading advertising

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. The QTU's so-called facts are a

Speaker: NA
Text: gross misrepresentation of the truth and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: veal only a small piece of the total picture of

Speaker: NA
Text: education in Australia. The real facts are

Speaker: NA
Text: these. Government schools in Australia enrol

Speaker: NA
Text: about 2.2 million students, about 69 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the total enrolments. Students in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment schools receive 78 per cent of the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic Commonwealth and state funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling-not 30 per cent, as the QTU

Speaker: NA
Text: claim. Government schools in Australia re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive around $13.5 billion each year from

Speaker: NA
Text: the taxpayer. Non-government schools get

Speaker: NA
Text: about $3.5 billion of public funding for the

Speaker: NA
Text: one million students that they look after.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are around 430,000 students in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools in Queensland and 307,000

Speaker: NA
Text: in non-government schools. Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: and state spending on government school

Speaker: NA
Text: students in Queensland is around $3.7 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: a year. Direct Commonwealth funding alone

Speaker: NA
Text: for Queensland government schools in 2002

Speaker: NA
Text: will be $440 million, an increase of 52 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent over Labor's last year in office. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary figure. That is way ahead of

Speaker: NA
Text: everything that inflation can account for.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland government has not

Speaker: NA
Text: matched the Commonwealth's rate of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in funding for government schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland increased its state expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: on government schools in its last budget by

Speaker: NA
Text: 4.1 per cent, compared with the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth's increase to Queensland government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools of 5 per cent. Most of this state's

Speaker: NA
Text: increase was taken up with a pay rise of 4½

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent to teachers, at a cost in 2001-02 of

Speaker: NA
Text: $215 million. I do not quibble for a minute

Speaker: NA
Text: with teachers receiving adequate and proper

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration. However, it is one thing to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the schools are not being properly

Speaker: NA
Text: funded but another thing not to tell the public

Speaker: NA
Text: that most of the increase that went to the

Speaker: NA
Text: state school system in the current year actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally went substantially to teachers' pay. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is fair enough, but parents are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: know where the money goes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Items in the latest Queensland budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the $3.7 million for the Quality

Speaker: NA
Text: Teacher Program, are paid in full by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. The QTU fails to mention

Speaker: NA
Text: that. By 2002 the Commonwealth govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will spend $669 million more in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools than in 1996, an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: 43 per cent. By contrast, the number of stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents in government schools has risen by

Speaker: NA
Text: only one per cent. A 43 per cent increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: funding; increase in students one per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The QTU's ‘facts' on non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools are equally misleading. Under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's new funding model, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 schools serving the most needy com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities will receive funding of $4,368 for

Speaker: NA
Text: each primary student and $5,721 for each

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary student. This compares with

Speaker: NA
Text: $8,172 in total funding for students in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools. Non-government schools

Speaker: NA
Text: serving the most needy communities are

Speaker: NA
Text: funded to a level of 70 per cent of what it

Speaker: NA
Text: costs to educate a student in a government

Speaker: NA
Text: school. By comparison, the schools serving

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealthiest communities will in 2004 re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive only $855 for each primary student and

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,120 for each secondary student. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: just 13.7 per cent of what it costs to educate

Speaker: NA
Text: a student in a government school. This 13.7

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent is hardly an indulgent amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money being spent in private schools. These

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements will inject $38 million extra

Speaker: NA
Text: into Queensland non-government schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 when the new funding model is fully

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented. This will go substantially to

Speaker: NA
Text: Catholic, Anglican, Adventist and Christian

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and also to community schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor and the QTU are acting as if the

Speaker: NA
Text: way government and non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools are funded is something new. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: this system where the state provides the ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jority of government school funding and the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government takes responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: providing a much lower funding level for

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government schools has been in vogue

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1973, and elements of it since even

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier than that. It is interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: the government that laid the foundations in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1973 for this type of break-up of government

Speaker: NA
Text: and non-government funding was in fact the

Speaker: NA
Text: Whitlam Labor government. It is funny to

Speaker: NA
Text: see the teachers union railing against it at

Speaker: NA
Text: present in its refined form. Despite this his-

Speaker: NA
Text: torical basis for the funding regime, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the teachers unions having a fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to remove all public funding

Speaker: NA
Text: from every non-government school, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Catholic parish and indigenous commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike the National Party, the QTU and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party are opposed to parents hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a choice in education. We in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party believe that parents have the right to

Speaker: NA
Text: choose the best schools for their child,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is in the government or non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government sector, and that the public good

Speaker: NA
Text: is served in providing public funding for the

Speaker: NA
Text: education of every Australian student. By

Speaker: NA
Text: choosing a non-government school, parents

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that their costs will not be fully cov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered, but they also do a public service by

Speaker: NA
Text: removing some of the burden from the public

Speaker: NA
Text: system, reducing pressure on the public

Speaker: NA
Text: purse and keeping class sizes down. So that I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not misquoted on this, let me make it

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly clear where I am coming from on

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue. I have no particular favour for

Speaker: NA
Text: government or non-government schools, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a passionate belief in choice. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: my children have gone to both systems, so I

Speaker: NA
Text: am in a position to judge: what suits one

Speaker: NA
Text: child in one system may not suit another

Speaker: NA
Text: child in another system. So I make no pejo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rative statements about either system, nor do

Speaker: NA
Text: I totally endorse both systems. What I am

Speaker: NA
Text: saying is that parents should have the fun-

Speaker: NA
Text: damental choice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at what the teachers union

Speaker: NA
Text: have to say about this. When appearing be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Senate inquiry into the states grants

Speaker: NA
Text: bill in July 2000 the AEU said it had long

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed any funding to private schools and

Speaker: NA
Text: would continue to do so. Nothing could be

Speaker: NA
Text: clearer than that. When asked on ABC Radio

Speaker: NA
Text: on 15 March 2001:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... do you want the government to stop funding

Speaker: NA
Text: private schools in all shapes and forms?

Speaker: NA
Text: Sue Simpson, of the NSW Teachers Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: to note that tion said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Well. that's certainly the ideal position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Teachers Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing could be clearer as to what their

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude is. We all know that sooner or later

Speaker: NA
Text: union policy becomes ALP policy, so what

Speaker: NA
Text: parents have to look forward to is certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: not the best.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another crime of education hy-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocrisy being carried out by the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate, and that concerns a small

Speaker: NA
Text: Gladstone non-government school. The edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of students at St Stephen's College has

Speaker: NA
Text: been put at risk because the Labor Party will

Speaker: NA
Text: not pass the bill to establish its grants in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate. This small Anglican school of 122

Speaker: NA
Text: students will be denied the October instal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of $15,250 from its establishment grant

Speaker: NA
Text: if the Labor Party does not do a backflip and

Speaker: NA
Text: vote in favour of establishment grants for

Speaker: NA
Text: new schools, including this one. St Stephen's

Speaker: NA
Text: is a fine example of a can-do school. It

Speaker: NA
Text: serves its community well and it has strong

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership from its principal, Peter Fowler.

Speaker: NA
Text: He tells me it is not a rich school, nor are the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents of the students who attend it rich. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Fowler told me that parents of students at the

Speaker: NA
Text: school work their hearts out on the factory

Speaker: NA
Text: floors of industries in Gladstone so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can have a choice of education for their chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren. They deserve something better.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition was in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gladstone recently but, surprisingly, he did

Speaker: NA
Text: not find time to go to one of these schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was more interested in running around

Speaker: NA
Text: with corflute signs, signing his signature

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside that of his Labor candidate, trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to convince the public that he had a new-

Speaker: NA
Text: found love of the public ownership of gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment facilities. Of course, he did not

Speaker: NA
Text: mention anything about the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank or Qantas.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: Werriwa) (11.32 a.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is a great shame that the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker, the member for Hinkler, was so

Speaker: NA
Text: negative in his remarks. In his 20-minute

Speaker: NA
Text: speech he spent more time talking about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party than the reading and writing

Speaker: NA
Text: skills of young people in his electorate. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was so short of ideas for improving literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy performance that he spent a

Speaker: NA
Text: good part of his speech talking about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Manufacturing Workers Union. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is regrettable indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, much of this debate has

Speaker: NA
Text: been about the literacy and numeracy pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams of the Keating government. Surely

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue is too important for an exercise in

Speaker: NA
Text: political point scoring; surely when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to something as vital as the literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy of young Australians the future

Speaker: NA
Text: counts for much more than the past. While

Speaker: NA
Text: ever this government bangs on about the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that happened or did not happen six

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago it will continue to overlook the

Speaker: NA
Text: education reforms that need to happen now.

Speaker: NA
Text: My focus in this debate is to be as positive

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible and to suggest to the minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: others the need for further reform in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's literacy and numeracy program. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to build on the fledgling success of the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic skills testing and national benchmark-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in our schools. We need to do more in six

Speaker: NA
Text: key areas of education reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first area is to improve our perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance in early childhood education. Early

Speaker: NA
Text: childhood education in Australia has been

Speaker: NA
Text: undervalued and underresourced for too

Speaker: NA
Text: long. Every report on knowledge highlights

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of early learning. We now

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the infant years are more impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant to literacy and numeracy than had been

Speaker: NA
Text: previously thought. An infant's grasp of lan-

Speaker: NA
Text: guage formed through speaking and listening

Speaker: NA
Text: in the early years is fundamental to the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment of good literacy skills at school.

Speaker: NA
Text: For every dollar of early education spending,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is possible to save seven dollars of public

Speaker: NA
Text: money in subsequent outlays on remedial

Speaker: NA
Text: services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, however, Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: been slow to act on this compelling research.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a nation, we have underestimated the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance of early childhood and underresour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ced its learning opportunities. Only 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of three-year-olds and 70 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: four-year-olds in this country attend pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: school. This has left Australia near the bot-

Speaker: NA
Text: tom of the OECD league table. Whereas on

Speaker: NA
Text: average infants in this country spend just

Speaker: NA
Text: eight months in pre-primary education, in

Speaker: NA
Text: France, Sweden, Germany and Japan they

Speaker: NA
Text: spend at least 30 months. You can see the

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison and the way in which we lag

Speaker: NA
Text: behind.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia needs to match this level of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipation. Provision needs to be made for all

Speaker: NA
Text: four-year-olds to access a preschool place,

Speaker: NA
Text: along with a significantly higher proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of three-year-olds. This requires improved

Speaker: NA
Text: federal-state cooperation and the implemen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation of a national preschool plan. Under the

Speaker: NA
Text: current system, participation rates and

Speaker: NA
Text: teaching standards vary widely across the

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories. In addition, the educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional component in Australia's child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: centres needs to be upgraded, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to the professional qualifications

Speaker: NA
Text: and training of staff. At the moment, only

Speaker: NA
Text: one in every two long day child centres in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country employs qualified preschool

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers. That is not good enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: A preschool education should also be

Speaker: NA
Text: made universal in terms of the assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: learning needs. All four-year-olds should be

Speaker: NA
Text: tested for learning disabilities, especially in

Speaker: NA
Text: speech and hearing. Up to 15 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian children have speech and lan-

Speaker: NA
Text: guage disorders, many at a severe level. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a very distressing statistic. The whole les-

Speaker: NA
Text: son in the research, and I think in common-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense, would say that you need to get those

Speaker: NA
Text: problems early and to invest early in reme-

Speaker: NA
Text: dial action to deal with those disabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Often the difficulties are not identified and

Speaker: NA
Text: not corrected until well into the school years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Remedial programs need to be brought for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward to preschool. Every child should arrive

Speaker: NA
Text: at school with a clear assessment of their

Speaker: NA
Text: learning capabilities and disabilities. Quality

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy programs at school

Speaker: NA
Text: need to build on the success of the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: primary years. Australia desperately needs a

Speaker: NA
Text: national preschool plan of action.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second reform that needs to be un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dertaken is to do more in our secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools with respect to literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy performance. We have a big problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in our high school system. A number of uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity studies have revealed huge difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in the level of reading, writing and

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking skills in grades 7, 8 and 9. For most

Speaker: NA
Text: students in the early secondary years, reading

Speaker: NA
Text: progress slows down and then levels out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even worse, one in four pupils actually goes

Speaker: NA
Text: backwards in their basic skills. This is a na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional crisis: one in four Australian students

Speaker: NA
Text: goes backwards in the early high school

Speaker: NA
Text: years in their basic reading, writing and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy skills. I take as my source the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search conducted at Melbourne University

Speaker: NA
Text: by Peter Hill and Jean Russell. One of their

Speaker: NA
Text: reports states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The mapping of pupil learning progress across

Speaker: NA
Text: the compulsory years of schooling revealed that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was virtually no growth during the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: years in reading, writing, speaking and listening.

Speaker: NA
Text: ... reading progress plateaus in grades 5 to 8 for

Speaker: NA
Text: most pupils, while for the lowest 25 per cent there

Speaker: NA
Text: was an actual decline in achievement, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in the first year of secondary school (grade 7). It school.

Speaker: NA
Text: was also evident that underachievement persists

Speaker: NA
Text: longer and is greater among boys than girls.

Speaker: NA
Text: The crisis is worse for boys than for girls.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very distressing statistic. At a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when most parents-and indeed, all the

Speaker: NA
Text: community-would be expecting their chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren to be learning more and getting ready

Speaker: NA
Text: for the challenges of adulthood, one in four

Speaker: NA
Text: students is worse off compared with when

Speaker: NA
Text: they left grade 5 in primary school. These

Speaker: NA
Text: middle school years can be a black hole for

Speaker: NA
Text: the reading, writing and numeracy skills of a

Speaker: NA
Text: large number of Australian students. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Education, Training and Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, Dr Kemp, is aware of these research

Speaker: NA
Text: findings but, unfortunately, he has done

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing about them. For 5ò years as educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion minister he has failed to introduce basic

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy testing in grades 7 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 9. He has not spent one extra dollar on the

Speaker: NA
Text: remedial programs and specialist teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to tackle this problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a big community concern. I say to

Speaker: NA
Text: every parent and to every citizen in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country who is worried about the behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: of young adolescents that the crisis that

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be addressed is in middle schooling.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problems with boys, the problems on

Speaker: NA
Text: our streets, the problems with law and order,

Speaker: NA
Text: with drug abuse-so many of these have

Speaker: NA
Text: their origins in the difficulties in the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: school years. We have a national crisis on

Speaker: NA
Text: our hands, but we do not have a national re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse from this government. If secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: students cannot read and write properly, they

Speaker: NA
Text: have next to no chance of finding jobs upon

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving school. Education failure is a one-

Speaker: NA
Text: way ticket to a lifetime of trouble. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search has identified the problem; we need a

Speaker: NA
Text: government willing to act and resolve this

Speaker: NA
Text: national crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need a vigorous program of middle

Speaker: NA
Text: school reform-and this is my third area of

Speaker: NA
Text: advocacy. We need to rethink the strategies

Speaker: NA
Text: for years 5 to 10, these vital middle years of

Speaker: NA
Text: school education. We need to introduce a

Speaker: NA
Text: system of home rooms and home teachers so

Speaker: NA
Text: that students can be familiar with their men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors and teachers. This is the best way of

Speaker: NA
Text: helping students through what can be a diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult transition from primary to secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: We also need to introduce a larger compo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nent of project based learning in our schools

Speaker: NA
Text: to make every classroom and every exercise

Speaker: NA
Text: a rich task in learning. Young people need

Speaker: NA
Text: the challenge that comes from project based

Speaker: NA
Text: learning, in environmental projects and civic

Speaker: NA
Text: projects and other community based initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives. This engages them and teaches them

Speaker: NA
Text: the habit of learning by doing, plus the prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical benefits and teamwork that come from

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also need to open up more diverse

Speaker: NA
Text: learning options in the middle school years. I

Speaker: NA
Text: envisage the middle school as a hub to which

Speaker: NA
Text: a range of learning settings can be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nected. Not every student will learn through

Speaker: NA
Text: the traditional academic curriculum; students

Speaker: NA
Text: learn in a variety of ways. The early adolesimportance

Speaker: NA
Text: cent years are a period of rapid change and

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge for many young people. So, too,

Speaker: NA
Text: their learning interests change and are chalsolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: lenged. We need to excite the diverse learn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing interests of Australia's young population

Speaker: NA
Text: by opening up diverse learning options and

Speaker: NA
Text: curricula in each of our schools. I envisage

Speaker: NA
Text: the middle school as a hub, connected to op-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in multimedia, the use of museums and

Speaker: NA
Text: libraries, the use of the performing arts and

Speaker: NA
Text: of manual practical skills in the education

Speaker: NA
Text: system. We need to build the learning envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment around the unique needs of every

Speaker: NA
Text: student, instead of making the assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: that one size might fit all in school educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is an excellent example of this

Speaker: NA
Text: proach in my electorate, at Macquarie Fields.

Speaker: NA
Text: A program called the MACThing has had out-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing success in reconnecting young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple to the benefits of literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: education. But, for all its success, it still

Speaker: NA
Text: lacks adequate funding from the federal and

Speaker: NA
Text: state government departments. It also lacks

Speaker: NA
Text: the flexibility and support to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not have red tape and bureaucracy

Speaker: NA
Text: standing in the way of further success. The

Speaker: NA
Text: MACThing is a more informal environment of

Speaker: NA
Text: learning where the students do not feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in a regimented classroom-the

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that they have rebelled against. It

Speaker: NA
Text: builds pastoral care and support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dents, trust between teacher and student,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby re-engaging these troubled young

Speaker: NA
Text: people with the benefits of education. The

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales Department of Education

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that the MACThing is not acceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: for 13and 14-year-olds to be part of its

Speaker: NA
Text: work; 13and 14-year olds in the eyes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: education department need to be in the for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal school environment. But these students

Speaker: NA
Text: have turned their backs on the formal class-

Speaker: NA
Text: room. Why can't the MACThing be regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as an annex, as part of the local government

Speaker: NA
Text: high school and be part of the funding sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and flexibility available from the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales Department of Education? We

Speaker: NA
Text: have much work to do in the vital area of

Speaker: NA
Text: middle school reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: A fourth area of reform is with regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged schooling. We all know the

Speaker: NA
Text: of literacy and numeracy right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country. Literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: are all-important for all schools but are ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: vital for disadvantaged areas. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people say that we need to go soft on stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards and testing, that rigorous testing can be

Speaker: NA
Text: too hard on students. I say that this attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: of softness is not doing anyone any favours,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it particularly hurts students in disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged schools. Australia's national pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram of basic skills testing is not being im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plemented rigorously enough. Evidence has

Speaker: NA
Text: come to light that these tests have been

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘dumbed down' to make it easier for schools

Speaker: NA
Text: to reach the minimum benchmark.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of even greater concern is the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: performance of disadvantaged schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: ap- literacy and numeracy remains poor. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that up to one-third of eight-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: olds in disadvantaged areas cannot read and

Speaker: NA
Text: write to an acceptable standard. Those who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to go soft betray the interests of those

Speaker: NA
Text: students. Unless those students have the rig-

Speaker: NA
Text: orous testing, benchmarking, teacher support

Speaker: NA
Text: and resourcing to get results, they will never

Speaker: NA
Text: get a fair start in life. Increased resources and

Speaker: NA
Text: more effective intervention strategies are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to overcome this problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also need greater flexibility in the run-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning of reading recovery programs in disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged schools. Recently I had the pleas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure of speaking to the principal of Claymore

Speaker: NA
Text: stuPublic School in my electorate, and he was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the New South Wales govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's reading recovery program. He said

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality for his school was that, if he took

Speaker: NA
Text: on the recommended number of reading re-

Speaker: NA
Text: covery teachers, they would have to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole class; they would basically have to

Speaker: NA
Text: take the whole school. In disadvantaged ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas the problem with literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: can be so acute that the targeted reading re-

Speaker: NA
Text: covery program is not adequate in the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which it is organised. The principal at Clay-

Speaker: NA
Text: more has recommended a return to phonics,

Speaker: NA
Text: whole class teaching, extra teachers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: classroom, and also an emphasis on rote

Speaker: NA
Text: learning. Sometimes this is discouraged, but

Speaker: NA
Text: let us not confuse reality with theory. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reality is that a lot of students get self-esteem

Speaker: NA
Text: and confidence out of rote learning- the

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence that comes from getting a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: answers right. They need that confidence and

Speaker: NA
Text: self-esteem to move onto harder and richer

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks. We need to be practical in this. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to identify the things that work in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular circumstances and back those pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams as vigorously as possible. One size

Speaker: NA
Text: does not fit all when it comes to disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: taged schooling.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also say that we have had too much tol-

Speaker: NA
Text: erance for failing schools. The greatest crime

Speaker: NA
Text: against a child, particularly a child from a

Speaker: NA
Text: poor background, is to give them a poor edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation; to deny them educational opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties through good schooling and a good

Speaker: NA
Text: learning environment at home. I want all

Speaker: NA
Text: state and territory governments to rigorously

Speaker: NA
Text: publish results and to make comparisons

Speaker: NA
Text: between good and failing schools. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: failing schools to be identified. Schools that

Speaker: NA
Text: are failing to add value to the education and

Speaker: NA
Text: future of their students need to be identified,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we need to do something about it. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should have zero tolerance of underper-

Speaker: NA
Text: forming schools in this country. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: close them down and bring in the experts, the

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and the innovations to get results.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only thing that matters in education is

Speaker: NA
Text: results. We should identify these failing

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and bring in the people who can get

Speaker: NA
Text: results for the students who are desperately

Speaker: NA
Text: in need.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fifth area of reform concerns class

Speaker: NA
Text: sizes. Australia needs a national program to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring down the size of our junior primary

Speaker: NA
Text: classes. This would allow teachers to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove the quality of classroom instruction,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the key to stronger literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy in the first three years of school. A

Speaker: NA
Text: number of studies have demonstrated that

Speaker: NA
Text: students in smaller classes achieve signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly higher scores. Follow-up research has

Speaker: NA
Text: shown the durability of these gains. Smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: class sizes in the junior primary years in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease the level of student progress for the

Speaker: NA
Text: remainder of the school years. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: gains that stick on for the remainder of

Speaker: NA
Text: school education.

Speaker: NA
Text: By international standards, Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: lagging behind. It is estimated that 80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of our early primary classes have more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 20 students; two in five have more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 students. Other nations are doing much

Speaker: NA
Text: better. Governments in Europe and North

Speaker: NA
Text: America are acknowledging what every

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher has long known: smaller class sizes

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the quality of learning. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt about it-in the early primary years

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller class sizes improve the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: learning. In the United States, for instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: the government is funding a national pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram to reduce primary class sizes to an av-

Speaker: NA
Text: erage of 18. Australia needs to match this

Speaker: NA
Text: effort and give our young people the same

Speaker: NA
Text: head start in life. Our children may be 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the population, but we are guaranteed

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are 100 per cent of our future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sixth and final area of reform I would

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate concerns the vital role of parents as

Speaker: NA
Text: educators. I regard school education as only

Speaker: NA
Text: one-half of the equation. It is only 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the learning experience. Learning

Speaker: NA
Text: does not begin and end at the school gate. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a whole of life process and it requires a

Speaker: NA
Text: quality learning environment at home. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently I had the pleasure of reading a book

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mem Fox. It is a best-selling book in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, and it is called Reading Magic. She

Speaker: NA
Text: presents research demonstrating that, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: read to our infant children at least three sto-

Speaker: NA
Text: rybooks a day, no Australian child will be

Speaker: NA
Text: illiterate. It is a vital investment for parents

Speaker: NA
Text: to spend at least 30 minutes a day reading at

Speaker: NA
Text: least three storybooks to their children. If all

Speaker: NA
Text: parents in this country do that, according to

Speaker: NA
Text: the research and according to commonsense,

Speaker: NA
Text: we would not have a literacy problem in this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. I can proudly report to the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that Oliver Dennis Latham enjoys having

Speaker: NA
Text: read to him at least three books a day. My

Speaker: NA
Text: favourite books have become his favourites;

Speaker: NA
Text: he has no say in it as yet, but when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to Dr Seuss's Fox in Sox, Green Eggs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ham, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, I

Speaker: NA
Text: love reading to him and I know the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: that apply to my little boy. I want those bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits to apply across the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: All parents must read to their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Never think you have not got enough time

Speaker: NA
Text: Never think you have not got the potential.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everyone can read to their children. For

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have not got the skills right now,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should be providing courses. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: have adult and community education courses

Speaker: NA
Text: through which parents can become more ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fective educators in the home. If they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that they have the literacy skills to be

Speaker: NA
Text: reading and assisting with homework, then

Speaker: NA
Text: the role of government is to identify those

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and provide the courses to bring their

Speaker: NA
Text: skills up to standard. If some parents are not

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to engage in such programs, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should apply mutual responsibility programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a basic responsibility of parent-

Speaker: NA
Text: hood-to assist the education of children. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that, in the vast majority of cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian parents want to be good educators

Speaker: NA
Text: in the home, and most are. But for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have not got the skills, we should provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: courses. For those who still say no, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should apply policies of mutual obligation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: note in the United States, for instance, that

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the state governments have a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby, if people live in public housing

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, they must agree to engage in adult

Speaker: NA
Text: education courses. It provides more effective

Speaker: NA
Text: skills for themselves and more effective edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation for their children at home. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: do the same in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: If parents still lack the capacity to act as

Speaker: NA
Text: educators in the home, we should bring in

Speaker: NA
Text: mentors. We should harness the vast skills of

Speaker: NA
Text: retired teachers and retired professional peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple-the vast and growing army of retired

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who can provide mentoring and

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in the home as educators. Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: I will quote an excellent letter to the Daily

Speaker: NA
Text: Telegraph yesterday from Bernadette

Speaker: NA
Text: Sweeney, a resident of Kiama. She wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps local schools or community centres need

Speaker: NA
Text: to advertise for “grandparent” figures to volunteer

Speaker: NA
Text: to assist in programs that could be implemented

Speaker: NA
Text: in mentoring children in need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm sure the self-funded retirees who John How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard is so keen to compensate would dearly love to

Speaker: NA
Text: give some time in this way, in return for what the

Speaker: NA
Text: community is prepared to give them. It would

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely be more fulfilling than worrying about

Speaker: NA
Text: which trip to take or which financial adviser to

Speaker: NA
Text: choose.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that in this parliament we often en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage financial interests to move to the

Speaker: NA
Text: front of the public policy agenda. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: vast community interest here, and that is to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide mentors and assistance for children

Speaker: NA
Text: in need, particularly when it comes to liter-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy and numeracy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend these six proposals to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and urgently suggest to the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that it take them on board to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems in literacy and numeracy per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance in this country.

Speaker: Mr BAIRD
Text: Cook) (11.52 a.m.)-It is my

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure to support the States Grants (Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary and Secondary Education Assistance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2001 today. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Werriwa on his speech and his

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas and thoughts on education. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Labor Party are not interested in his

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas on education because they moved him

Speaker: NA
Text: off the frontbench and rejected his ideas at

Speaker: NA
Text: the last election. A lot of interesting ideas

Speaker: NA
Text: were put forward, but innovative ideas are

Speaker: NA
Text: never encouraged amongst the ALP.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is of great encouragement to

Speaker: NA
Text: those who live in my electorate and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people, because the government

Speaker: NA
Text: has shown in clear terms its support for both

Speaker: NA
Text: government and non-government schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. Firstly, the bill provides legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive authority to the recent budgetary meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure of $33.3 million over the coming two

Speaker: NA
Text: financial years to continue strategic assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance in schools and to support literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy research. It is important that we

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the ongoing strategic assistance.

Speaker: NA
