Text: Secondly, the bill ensures that commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: to non-government schools are met. It

Speaker: NA
Text: amends the State Grants (Primary and Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ondary Education Assistance) Act 2000,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the principal vehicle authorising

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for the 2001-04 funding period to

Speaker: NA
Text: include this additional funding and to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government's commitment to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools continues. It is impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant to note that the bill makes no changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: policy; it simply appropriates the extra

Speaker: NA
Text: amount because the number of enrolments in

Speaker: NA
Text: new schools was higher than expected.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a press release earlier today, the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Education, Training and Youth Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that last year Labor said that it fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: voured extra funding for needy non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. On 5 October last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Dobell said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It's at the low-fee Christian schools where the real

Speaker: NA
Text: need is.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the following day, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's not against extra money for private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, especially needy private schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet in June the ALP voted against estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment funds for needy non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. It continues to endanger the funding

Speaker: NA
Text: of more than 50 new schools. All members

Speaker: NA
Text: would be aware of the hypocrisy of the ALP.

Speaker: NA
Text: An example is the stunt by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition this morning, who came in with

Speaker: NA
Text: his own charter of budget honesty when, for

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 years, Labor totally ignored all aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: it in its administration of the Treasury bench.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the same with the shadow minister

Speaker: NA
Text: education, the member for Dobell, who goes

Speaker: NA
Text: around the country saying, ‘Yes, you're ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: actly the type of school that should receive

Speaker: NA
Text: funding-small private schools should re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive it; the Christian schools out in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western suburbs should receive it.' If that is

Speaker: NA
Text: what Labor believe in, let them support it

Speaker: NA
Text: with votes on the floor of this House. But, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, they will not do that in here; it be-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes an entirely different situation because

Speaker: NA
Text: they get their ruling directions from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Teachers Federation. I have certainly had

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives from the Teachers Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: come to see me. They attack me because

Speaker: NA
Text: their view is that the government is not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding enough funding to government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. Record funding has been provided

Speaker: NA
Text: to schools around Australia by this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eighty-five per cent of funding to gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools must come from state edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation authorities, but the Teachers Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion never want to know about that. They

Speaker: NA
Text: want to take the 15 per cent that the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government is responsible for and beat us up

Speaker: NA
Text: without looking at the record of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments. In New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: funding has gone backwards. They do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to talk about the funding under this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, which has continued to escalate.

Speaker: NA
Text: They simply say, ‘Yes, but a lot of it is

Speaker: NA
Text: into private schools.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I have asked them, ‘Don't you believe in

Speaker: NA
Text: choice?' The people who live in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate, who pay their taxes, are very happy for

Speaker: NA
Text: there to be government schools and private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, but they should have the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the choice as to where their children

Speaker: NA
Text: should go. If they are paying their taxes, they

Speaker: NA
Text: would expect that that part of their taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: money would come back into educating their

Speaker: NA
Text: children-educating them according to the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests and the ideals that they as parents

Speaker: NA
Text: have for their children. The answer I got

Speaker: NA
Text: from one of the representatives of the Teach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers Federation was, ‘No, I do not believe in

Speaker: NA
Text: choice. There is a government system. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should do all we can to encourage the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment system, and that is the end of it.' So

Speaker: NA
Text: I said, ‘You are really talking about the Sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: linist view of no choice.' We all saw how

Speaker: NA
Text: for that ended up in the Soviet Union. They pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide government monopolies-government

Speaker: NA
Text: run factories, a government run distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: system and retail outlets. The result was that

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy of the Soviet Union has col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lapsed.

Speaker: NA
Text: People need choice. It provides a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive environment, with private schools

Speaker: NA
Text: competing against government schools, and

Speaker: NA
Text: vice versa. In New South Wales, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen some outstanding HSC results from

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. In my electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: Caringbah High, St George Girls High,

Speaker: NA
Text: James Ruse High, North Sydney High and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney High all have an outstanding record

Speaker: NA
Text: as government schools, but many of the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate schools in Sydney have also performed

Speaker: NA
Text: outstandingly in the HSC. Sydney Grammar

Speaker: NA
Text: and Knox are amongst those. Across the

Speaker: NA
Text: board, we have seen significant achievement.

Speaker: NA
Text: People having a choice is at the nub of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's philosophy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that more than 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite come from trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: backgrounds and they have a strong belief in

Speaker: NA
Text: the trade union system and the role that trade

Speaker: NA
Text: unions play in society. We do not object to

Speaker: NA
Text: the role that trade unions play, but we do

Speaker: NA
Text: object when they overstep that role and dic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tate to the Australian community, saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘You shall have no choice. We want only

Speaker: NA
Text: going government schools to be funded. We don't

Speaker: NA
Text: believe any funding should be provided to

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the non-government schools.' That

Speaker: NA
Text: is hypocritical for two reasons. I know that,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the opposition frontbench, the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for education, the member for Do-

Speaker: NA
Text: bell, did not go to a government school-and

Speaker: NA
Text: that is fine. He went to a very good private

Speaker: NA
Text: school in my electorate. I would like to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: him say, ‘Let's provide some equity in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the private sector. Let's provide assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: to independent schools and those schools

Speaker: NA
Text: that are funded by the churches, so that peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple can have a choice.' It was his parents'

Speaker: NA
Text: choice to send him to a private school, and

Speaker: NA
Text: other parents across Australia should have

Speaker: NA
Text: that same right. What I hear time and time

Speaker: NA
Text: again from people in my electorate is that

Speaker: NA
Text: they want to be able to exercise that right to

Speaker: NA
Text: choose. In fact, in my electorate I often hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the criticism that there are not enough private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools for them to go to.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill provides more assistance to not

Speaker: NA
Text: only government schools but also non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. I am proud to say that I

Speaker: NA
Text: went to a government school which provided

Speaker: NA
Text: a very significant level of education. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: members on the frontbench went to govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment schools. The Prime Minister, for exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, went to Canterbury Boys High. I went to

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Hacking High. These were excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. But this is about choice. If people

Speaker: NA
Text: were not allowed a choice, we would be run-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning a small dictatorship in terms of how

Speaker: NA
Text: people should live their lives. The bill also

Speaker: NA
Text: makes some minor technical changes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill includes a small change to correct an

Speaker: NA
Text: error resulting from the change of the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of funding from the previous quadrennial

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill highlights how much this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has been giving to education in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. This budget was the sixth budget in

Speaker: NA
Text: a row where schools funding has increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that schools funding has hit a

Speaker: NA
Text: new record high. We are constantly criticised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the opposition in terms of funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: schools across Australia; yet we have hit this

Speaker: NA
Text: all-time high. Eighty-seven per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for specific schools initiatives con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in this year's budget will go to gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools-$238 million will go di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly to government schools-and $34.1

Speaker: NA
Text: million will be spent over five years to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port online curriculum development to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that students are kept abreast of devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opments in information technology. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely appropriate in this new IT era.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget also provided $46.7 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue the successful Jobs Pathway pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram. This program enables the smooth tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition from school to the work force. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant program aimed at young

Speaker: NA
Text: people between 15 and 19. It is anticipated

Speaker: NA
Text: that this extra funding will assist some

Speaker: NA
Text: 70,000 young Australians, which is what we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see.

Speaker: NA
Text: The $33.3 million program specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with by this legislation has been put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place to fund projects that will improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: educational opportunities for those students

Speaker: NA
Text: who are recognised as being disadvantaged,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly those with disabilities. This

Speaker: NA
Text: shows the compassion with which this area

Speaker: NA
Text: of the budget is administered. It is intended

Speaker: NA
Text: that the funding will be directed especially to

Speaker: NA
Text: the areas of literacy and numeracy. The op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position has expressed some concern that the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding has been announced only for the first

Speaker: NA
Text: two years of the funding quadrennium. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the forward estimates have made room

Speaker: NA
Text: for further funding of almost $100 million

Speaker: NA
Text: over the 2003-04 and 2004-05 financial

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has an unsurpassed rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ord in the areas of the literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy-the building blocks of any person's

Speaker: NA
Text: education. In 1997, a National Literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: Numeracy Plan was agreed to by all state

Speaker: NA
Text: and territory ministers. Among other things,

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan provided for all students in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to be tested on their literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: needs in the earliest years of their education;

Speaker: NA
Text: for all students in years 3, 5 and 7 to be as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessed against national standards; and for

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent assessment of national levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement with respect to these standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the first ever nationally coordinated

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to literacy and numeracy in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian history. Reporting back to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity on student results against the national

Speaker: NA
Text: standards is already occurring. The plan has

Speaker: NA
Text: already seen a 13 per cent improvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the reading abilities of year 3 students

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia. Four years ago, the na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional school English survey showed that

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 30 per cent of year 3 students had

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to meet minimum standards of literacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Data from March last year shows that that

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion has been halved.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to make some comments

Speaker: NA
Text: about the emotive and misleading language

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been used in this debate. I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to the debate and, while the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Werriwa has been outlining his own

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative proposal in relation to education

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of the standard one we get from the

Speaker: NA
Text: ALP, there has been a lot of misleading in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation-and we hear it all the time. The

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading leaflets that were handed out to

Speaker: NA
Text: the students in my electorate have in large

Speaker: NA
Text: letters on the front: ‘The Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is a threat to the great work in our pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic schools'. The leaflet also claims that,

Speaker: NA
Text: since the early 1980s, there has been a run-

Speaker: NA
Text: down of spending on public education. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are lies-pure lies. The leaflet neglects the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that we have reached an all-time high in

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for government and non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. The government can be justly proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of its record on education. The 2000-01

Speaker: NA
Text: budget made $22.3 billion available for

Speaker: NA
Text: school funding for the next quadrennium.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a 32.6 per cent increase over the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1997-2000 quadrennium and $402 million

Speaker: NA
Text: per year more than the ALP ever gave. These

Speaker: NA
Text: increases come at a time when enrolments in

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools have increased by less

Speaker: NA
Text: than three per cent. That is the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: record.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be different if the Teachers Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration worked on a factual basis when it

Speaker: NA
Text: runs around my electorate, your electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, and most other

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates in this country. The reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: the government have increased funding by

Speaker: NA
Text: record amounts. There has been a 32.6 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent increase in funding. That is $402 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion more than the ALP gave in its best year.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not in terms of nominal dollars of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day; it is indexed dollars-real dollars of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day. There has been an extra $402 million

Speaker: NA
Text: per year from this government. Just in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past year, there has been a 32.6 per cent in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease, yet the Teachers Federation in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales and in other states goes around

Speaker: NA
Text: peddling lies to students. Concerned parents

Speaker: NA
Text: come to me and say, ‘I read that you are cut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting back significantly on funding to gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools.' They outline the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: of their schools and say that this and that are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed, and I say, ‘Look at this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: record compared with that of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: government, and look at the state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and what they are not doing in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of their responsibility for 85 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of government schools around Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The GST will provide a substantial in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in revenue to the states and it will

Speaker: NA
Text: fund the salary of every teacher in every

Speaker: NA
Text: school in every state in Australia. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: growth tax. If the Teachers Federation wants

Speaker: NA
Text: to complain about funding, let it talk to state

Speaker: NA
Text: education ministers and ask them to explain

Speaker: NA
Text: where the GST is going. This government is

Speaker: NA
Text: showing where the money is going: the 32.6

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent increase-the $402 million extra per

Speaker: NA
Text: year being put into school funding across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It was particularly interesting to

Speaker: NA
Text: see that in its editorial the Courier-Mail took

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland Teachers Union to task and

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out that state education is the respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of the state government. If education

Speaker: NA
Text: funding in Queensland has fallen short of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Queensland Teachers Union thinks

Speaker: NA
Text: is appropriate, the protest should be aimed at

Speaker: NA
Text: the bottom end of George Street, not at Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra. The same applies in New South Wales:

Speaker: NA
Text: the protest should be addressed to Macquarie

Speaker: NA
Text: Street in Sydney, not to Canberra. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that this government's record has been

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding the difference in respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility, federal government funding for gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment school students still remains thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands of dollars higher per student than

Speaker: NA
Text: that funding for students in any non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: school. Sixty-one per cent of federal funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for schools goes to government schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some is allocated, but most is given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: states to maintain their responsibilities. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government's priority is clearly to offer a

Speaker: NA
Text: choice. We make no secret of that. We be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that it is the right of every parent

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia to decide which schools

Speaker: NA
Text: their child will go to and to review the serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ices that are offered.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the debate has been full of

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric. The facts of the matter have been

Speaker: NA
Text: lacking on the opposition benches. The op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position have not highlighted the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: real commitment to education and education

Speaker: NA
Text: standards. The strong emphasis on literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy standards is the key to any

Speaker: NA
Text: significant education program. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a significant lift in literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy testing and standards across Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. There is assistance and planning for

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are in a transitional phase from

Speaker: NA
Text: school to work. Under this government, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen record funding being spent on de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloping literacy and numeracy standards,

Speaker: NA
Text: and outstanding assistance for smaller Chris-

Speaker: NA
Text: tian schools and independent schools across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Talk to the parents of children who

Speaker: NA
Text: attend the many small independent schools

Speaker: NA
Text: across Australia and you will see the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing choice. Some very exciting things

Speaker: NA
Text: are happening in small independent schools

Speaker: NA
Text: across Australia. If parents are not wealthy,

Speaker: NA
Text: the fees are often low. The government are

Speaker: NA
Text: putting education on the map and empower-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing students, who are developing to their

Speaker: NA
Text: fullest potential, and lifting numeracy and

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy standards. I for one am very proud of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's record in providing choice,

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing government funding and lifting

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy across this country. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Bevis) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA

Text: and (5)

Text: Repeal the subsections, substitute:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) If the Commission is satisfied:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) that a person (first party):

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) made an application under sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 170CE; or

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) began proceedings relating to an

Speaker: NA
Text: application; and

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph (b) the first party did so in circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances where it should have been

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably apparent to the first party

Speaker: NA
Text: that he or she had no reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of success in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: application or proceeding;

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph the Commission may, on application

Speaker: NA
Text: under this section by the other party

Speaker: NA
Text: to the application or proceeding,

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection make an order for costs against the

Speaker: NA
Text: first party.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If the Commission is satisfied that a

Speaker: NA
Text: party (first party) to a proceeding re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lating to an application under section

Speaker: NA
Text: 170CE has acted unreasonably in fail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) to discontinue the proceeding; or

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) to agree to terms of settlement that

Speaker: NA
Text: could lead to the discontinuance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the application;

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission may, on an applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion under this section by the other

Speaker: NA
Text: party to the proceeding, make an or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der for costs against the first party.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) If the Commission is satisfied:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) that a party (first party) to a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeding relating to an application

Speaker: NA
Text: made under section 170CE caused

Speaker: NA
Text: costs to be incurred by the other

Speaker: NA
Text: party to the proceeding; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) that the first party caused the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be incurred because of the first

Speaker: NA
Text: party's unreasonable act or omission

Speaker: NA
Text: in connection with the conduct of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proceeding;

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission may, on an applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by the other party under this

Speaker: NA
Text: section, make an order for costs

Speaker: NA
Text: against the first party.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) In making a decision under this section,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission may have regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: any certificate issued or advice given

Speaker: NA
Text: under section 170CF and whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: party pursued a course of action con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary to any such certificate or advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) An application for an order for costs

Speaker: NA
Text: under this section must be made within

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 days after the determination, dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: continuance, settlement or dismissal of

Speaker: NA
Text: the application under section 170CE or

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeding relating to an application

Speaker: NA
Text: under section 170CE (as the case may

Speaker: NA
Text: be).

Speaker: NA
Text: (5A) A schedule of costs may be prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to items of expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to be incurred in respect of:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) an application to the Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: under section 170CE; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) a proceeding in respect of an appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation under section 170CE.
