Text: page 16 (line 6), omit the item.

Speaker: NA
Text: (25) Schedule 1, item 36, page 16 (lines 14 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 35), omit the item, substitute:

Speaker: NA
Text: 36 At the end of subsection 170CP(6)

Speaker: NA
Text: Add “, or within such period as a court

Speaker: NA
Text: allows on an application made during

Speaker: NA
Text: or after those 14 days.”.

Speaker: NA
Text: Note: In Brodie-Hanns v MTV Pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishing Ltd (1995) 67 IR 298,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Industrial Relations Court of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia set down principles

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the exercise of its

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion under a similarly

Speaker: NA
Text: worded provision of the Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial Relations Act 1988.

Speaker: NA
Text: 36A Subsection 170CP(7)

Speaker: NA
Text: Repeal the subsection.

Speaker: NA
Text: (26) Schedule 1, items 37 and 38, page 17 (lines

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 to 10), omit the items.

Speaker: NA
Text: (27) Schedule 1, item 39, page 17 (line 18), at the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of section 170HBA, add “unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: second application corrects an error in the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous application, or the Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: considers that it would be fair to accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: second application.”.

Speaker: NA
Text: (28) Schedule 1, item 40, page 17 (line 26), after

Speaker: NA
Text: “applicant”, insert “or a respondent”.

Speaker: NA
Text: (29) Schedule 1, item 40, page 18 (line 2), after

Speaker: NA
Text: “applicant”, insert “or a respondent”.

Speaker: NA
Text: (30) Schedule 1, item 40, page 18 (after line 18),

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of section 170HE, add:

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) An adviser must not encourage an em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployer to continue to oppose an unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: termination application if, on the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been disclosed or that ought

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably to have been apparent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: adviser, the adviser should have been,

Speaker: NA
Text: or should have become, aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was no reasonable prospect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: respondent defending the action.

Speaker: NA
Text: (31) Schedule 1, item 40, page 18 (line 26), at the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of subsection (2), add:

Speaker: NA
Text: ; or (d) the Registrar; or

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) an organisation of employees or

Speaker: NA
Text: employers that represented a party

Speaker: NA
Text: in proceedings at first instance in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of the unfair termination ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plication.

Speaker: NA
Text: (32) Schedule 1, item 40, page 19 (lines 1 to 7),

Speaker: NA
Text: omit section 170HG.

Speaker: NA
Text: (33) Schedule 1, item 40, page 19 (line 12), after

Speaker: NA
Text: “application”, insert “or no reasonable pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect of the respondent defending the action”.

Speaker: NA
Text: (34) Schedule 1, page 20 (after line 10), after

Speaker: NA
Text: item 42, insert:

Speaker: NA
Text: 42A Application of items 9A and 10A

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments of the Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Act 1996 made by items 9A

Speaker: NA
Text: and 10A apply only in relation to appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations under section 170CE of that

Speaker: NA
Text: Act where the employment to which

Speaker: NA
Text: the application relates commenced on

Speaker: NA
Text: or after the date on which those items

Speaker: NA
Text: commence.

Speaker: NA
Text: (35) Schedule 1, item 46, page 20 (line 31) to

Speaker: NA
Text: page 21 (line 4), omit the item.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Workplace Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business) (12.13 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendments be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very happy to support the Senate's

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the Workplace Relations

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Termination of Employment)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2000, because the bill now significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: improves the regime governing unfair dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missals. The problem with the old unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal regime is that it has cost jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: depressed employment in this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal regime, as it stood first un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the former government's legislation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: even under the legislation that this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment put in place in 1996, put at its most

Speaker: NA
Text: simple, is this: if it is expensive to let

Speaker: NA
Text: go, it is hard to take people on. This govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is about maximising opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in this country. The Senate's

Speaker: NA
Text: changes are reasonable and fair. They should

Speaker: NA
Text: give confidence to employers, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: small business employers, who are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: business of giving people jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want briefly to run through the major

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that the Senate has put in place. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the bill as amended by the Senate, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial Relations Commission will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to impose penalties on lawyers and other

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers who encourage people to bring for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward speculative and unmeritorious claims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the changes in the bill as amended,

Speaker: NA
Text: lawyers and advisers will be required to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clare up front that they are operating on a no

Speaker: NA
Text: win, no fee basis. The commission will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to exclude unmeritorious applications

Speaker: NA
Text: after an initial conciliation hearing. In con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidering these matters, the commission will

Speaker: NA
Text: be required to take into account the special

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances that affect many small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses that are required to appear in unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal matters. The commission will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to order costs in cases of unreasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: and completely unmeritorious unfair dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missal applications. In addition, the bill as

Speaker: NA
Text: amended streamlines and simplifies the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures governing the conduct of these sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of matters in the commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most especially, the bill establishes a gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral three-month probationary period for new

Speaker: NA
Text: employees during which the provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the unfair dismissal legislation will not ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ply. This three-month probationary period

Speaker: NA
Text: will apply generally to all businesses. I

Speaker: NA
Text: should point out to the House that this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular government amendment was based on

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation in Queensland, and I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that this part of the legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland was introduced by the Beattie

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In commending the bill as amended to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, I want to acknowledge the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: small business representatives in presenting

Speaker: NA
Text: the case for change. I particularly acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge the indefatigable work of Rob Bastian

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Council of Small Business Organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of Australia. I also acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: work of the Australian Chamber of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: people merce and Industry which represents very

Speaker: NA
Text: large numbers of small businesses in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. Obviously, my distinguished friend and

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague the Minister for Small Business

Speaker: NA
Text: has repeatedly lobbied on behalf of his port-

Speaker: NA
Text: folio constituency with me and with cabinet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I would like to congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate on the work it has done with this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: All senators adopted a constructive and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: telligent approach. I particularly commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the work of Senator Andrew Murray and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats. Obviously, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: always agree with Senator Murray and I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not always agree with the Democrats, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that Senator Murray is a man of great

Speaker: NA
Text: goodwill and sincerity. He has the best inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests of Australian business at heart and he

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to do the right thing by workers. He

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to try to ensure that the rights of work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and the rights of employers are balanced

Speaker: NA
Text: so that both workers and employers can go

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in the sort of partnership that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: best for our economy and our society.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe that this bill, even as

Speaker: NA
Text: amended, represents the last word in im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving the unfair dismissal regime. Cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly, the government would prefer to see

Speaker: NA
Text: the sort of legislation that we have brought

Speaker: NA
Text: forward previously in this place and in an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other place to be passed, but I accept that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament as currently constituted, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is most unlikely. It is important that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should celebrate the progress that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made rather than dwell on the things that

Speaker: NA
Text: might yet remain to be done. This Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Amendment (Termination of Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment) Bill 2000 is a sign of this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's determination to do everything it

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably can to boost employment. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: sign of our determination to help small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness to create jobs. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Text: Brisbane) (12.18 p.m.)-We

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be supporting the amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations Amendment (Termina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Employment) Bill 2000 which have

Speaker: NA
Text: been agreed to in the Senate and to which the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister has just referred. I want to comment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the background to all of this, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: done on other occasions when this bill, and

Speaker: NA
Text: bills of its kind, have been before parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with unfair dismissal laws.

Speaker: NA
Text: The laws the parliament is proposing to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend are the laws that this government put

Speaker: NA
Text: in place. They are the third generation of

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal laws in the federal jurisdic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Unfair dismissal law is a longstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: and common practice in state jurisdictions

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australian industrial relations. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: a much shorter history in the federal juris-

Speaker: NA
Text: diction. The laws in the federal jurisdiction

Speaker: NA
Text: were first introduced by the former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government and, prior to the 1996 election,

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor recognised that the laws we put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place were not functioning as we had in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended. We made a number of quite signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant changes to those laws that addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the concerns that had been raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with us, particularly by some in business

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, some in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government was elected in 1996 and

Speaker: NA
Text: made sweeping changes to those laws. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was the first wave of legislation introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: by the then minister, Peter Reith. Amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: those sweeping changes were significant

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the way in which unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: laws operate under federal jurisdiction. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to remind parliament of what the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister of the day, Peter Reith, said when refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ring to exactly these unfair dismissal laws we

Speaker: NA
Text: are now talking about. In 1996, he told par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: We have delivered a workable system for dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with unfair dismissal on the basis of a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: round.

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘A fair go all round' is how he described this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's laws that they now want to

Speaker: NA
Text: change. At the time, we took the view that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's laws went too far, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: government argued that they were a fair go

Speaker: NA
Text: all round. They now propose to change the

Speaker: NA
Text: system that they said was a fair go all round,

Speaker: NA
Text: to tilt the playing field more heavily in fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: vour of employers, and to provide fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: protections to employees. Remember that the

Speaker: NA
Text: starting point for the adjustment is a system

Speaker: NA
Text: this government introduced which they said

Speaker: NA
Text: was ‘a fair go all round'.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should understand that these amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are about changing that ‘fair go all

Speaker: NA
Text: round'-and those are not my words; they

Speaker: NA
Text: are Minister Reith's words-so that workers

Speaker: NA
Text: have less of a fair go all round. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: support that. In saying that, I want to place

Speaker: NA
Text: on the record our view that there are changes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are warranted in the operation of unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal laws. There is a problem, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly about time delays in the processing of

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal laws, which is a burden both

Speaker: NA
Text: for the company and for the worker seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a case heard. On many occasions it

Speaker: NA
Text: can be a problem for a worker engaged to

Speaker: NA
Text: replace the one who has been dismissed. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: in everybody's interest that these matters are

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with quickly. Unfortunately, the current

Speaker: NA
Text: system does not facilitate that. We have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal cases run for more than two

Speaker: NA
Text: years and that is a very unsatisfactory situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Justice delayed is justice denied and

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been the case too often in unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal applications. So we need to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We recognise also that there is a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: with the ambulance chasers that are so often

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to. We need to understand that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a problem peculiar to unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: law, nor is it peculiar to industrial relations

Speaker: NA
Text: law. Anyone who is involved in commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: or legal negotiations will tell you that. If one

Speaker: NA
Text: side think they have the leverage to extract

Speaker: NA
Text: something from the other, they will give it a

Speaker: NA
Text: go. It is not just in industrial law; it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: just in unfair dismissal law. People will be

Speaker: NA
Text: presented with the dilemma: ‘Do I defend

Speaker: NA
Text: this case, which I do not think is meritori-

Speaker: NA
Text: go all ous? If I defend it, it is going to cost me

Speaker: NA
Text: more money than if I simply settled out of

Speaker: NA
Text: court.' That is the problem of the ambulance

Speaker: NA
Text: chasers in unfair dismissal law. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that and I do not like it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us not kid ourselves. It is not created

Speaker: NA
Text: by unions or workers; it is not created by

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal laws; it is created by an at-

Speaker: NA
Text: titude amongst the legal profession. I happily

Speaker: NA
Text: stand here and say that I am not a lawyer-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I have upset lawyers on both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House with that comment! (Extension of time

Speaker: NA
Text: granted) But it happens to be the case that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole range of areas of the operations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the law, that sort of behaviour is common-

Speaker: NA
Text: place. If you can press the advantage and get

Speaker: NA
Text: a claim settled out of court, you do it. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course that happens, and that is a concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: us. We have been looking at remedies to that

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, discussing them with various

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders. I made the comment to them

Speaker: NA
Text: that I make in this parliament now: the

Speaker: NA
Text: remedies that are proposed to deal with that

Speaker: NA
Text: create problems that are just as bad as the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem they seek to overcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: On that point, I think it is worth having a

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the comments that the Democrats

Speaker: NA
Text: made on this in their report on the second

Speaker: NA
Text: wave legislation. This bill, of course, has its

Speaker: NA
Text: genesis in the second wave legislation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: an extract from that second wave bill. In re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to these specific provisions that were

Speaker: NA
Text: in the second wave bill that have now been

Speaker: NA
Text: separated out, the Democrats said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... It is in the interests of all parties concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with unfair dismissals, if the Commission's proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: esses are made as quick and inexpensive as is

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with the needs of justice, and if the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of law does not become manipulative.

Speaker: NA
Text: I agree with that. My concern is that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have the balance wrong with these amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. They have not ensured that both effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency and effectiveness, as well as justice,

Speaker: NA
Text: are being applied here.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before us is markedly different

Speaker: NA
Text: from that which the government proposed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Senate, thankfully, had the wisdom to

Speaker: NA
Text: extract a range of matters out of this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: which did not have the support of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: parties in the Senate. They include provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that would have excluded contractors

Speaker: NA
Text: from the legislation, that would have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: stricted access to extend time to lodge appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations as they currently exist and that would

Speaker: NA
Text: have prohibited compensation for shock,

Speaker: NA
Text: distress or humiliation. The workers in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia are entitled to ask, ‘Why does the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment actually want to reduce the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: that we presently have? Why does the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment want to prevent us being paid even

Speaker: NA
Text: when the court feels we should?' Remember,

Speaker: NA
Text: this is where a court hears the facts and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cides that the worker has suffered shock,

Speaker: NA
Text: distress or humiliation and as a result of that

Speaker: NA
Text: is entitled to some payment, but the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment actually wants to write that out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thankfully, the Senate took those provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions and a number of others that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment was seeking out of the bill. But we

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard here today from the minister his

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to see further changes in the law. I

Speaker: NA
Text: assume by that he means to see those things

Speaker: NA
Text: that were in the government's bill pursued in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future. So we now know the agenda for

Speaker: NA
Text: the next election from this government. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: to strip those things from workers in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the entitlements they currently have under

Speaker: NA
Text: the law relating to unfair dismissal. I assure

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister that we will make certain that

Speaker: NA
Text: the workers of Australia are aware of those

Speaker: NA
Text: additional changes the government wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: make to further strip entitlements from em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to talk specifically now about the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments made in the Senate with the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the Democrats. We did in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for a number of these amendments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate with the Democrats. We took the

Speaker: NA
Text: view that, if there was going to be a bill

Speaker: NA
Text: passed through this parliament, it was better

Speaker: NA
Text: that it be a bill improved on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's version, even if we did not like the

Speaker: NA
Text: final product. We supported a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: these amendments and subsequently sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to defeat the bill as a whole. As it turns out,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is just as well we did, otherwise the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers of Australia would not even have had

Speaker: NA
Text: these small mercies to be thankful for.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Democrats in the Senate proposed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and had accepted, the following changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, where at the conciliation stage it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been indicated by the commission that the

Speaker: NA
Text: applicant has no reasonable prospect of suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess at arbitration, the application must be

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissed. I can understand why the Demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: crats proposed that. It goes to some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions of meritorious claims and the am-

Speaker: NA
Text: bulance chasers and the like. That will pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce a requirement that the full case will be

Speaker: NA
Text: run up front. There will no longer be a two-

Speaker: NA
Text: stage process under this arrangement. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will now have the full case dealt with up

Speaker: NA
Text: front, and that is not going to expedite mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. Those cases that could easily have been

Speaker: NA
Text: sorted out in the first tier of this process,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite simply, are now going to be prolonged

Speaker: NA
Text: because no-one will be able to take the gam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble that you might have an adverse finding at

Speaker: NA
Text: that stage. You will have to run the full case

Speaker: NA
Text: up front. This will slow the process down. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will have the opposite effect to that which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Democrats and the government seek.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Extension of time granted)

Speaker: NA
Text: The second Democrats amendment I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to refer to is that, in considering whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: termination was unfair, the commission con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siders the degree to which the size of the

Speaker: NA
Text: employer's business would be likely to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pact on the procedures followed. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental problem with this. What we are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying as a parliament, what the government

Speaker: NA
Text: is saying and what the Democrats have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: is that you have two sets of rights as a

Speaker: NA
Text: worker. You can be in one company and the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts of the case are absolutely identical,

Speaker: NA
Text: cept that company A employs five or 10

Speaker: NA
Text: people and company B employs 50 or 60-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the only distinguishing feature-but

Speaker: NA
Text: your rights are different in those two places

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the operation of this new provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. That is a fundamental undermining of

Speaker: NA
Text: basic judicial principles. It is wrong. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be saying that workers will be

Speaker: NA
Text: treated differently, solely because of how

Speaker: NA
Text: many people happen to work at their work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place, when their cases are heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also alert the government to the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that I think is going to occur as companies

Speaker: NA
Text: reconstruct themselves. We already have

Speaker: NA
Text: many examples of companies that operate in

Speaker: NA
Text: the one location but actually use an umbrella

Speaker: NA
Text: of organisations that may all be owned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: same people. It happens. In fact, Joy Manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing, where there was a major industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute, had a number of companies operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on the one site. The workers all wore the

Speaker: NA
Text: same uniform, they all thought they were

Speaker: NA
Text: working for the same company, but in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: they were working for a range of different

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. There is nothing to stop an or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation establishing that structure and

Speaker: NA
Text: employing five people in every one of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of having one company with 50 peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, there are 10 different companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: they all employ just five, who all wear the

Speaker: NA
Text: same uniform. They all trade under the same

Speaker: NA
Text: name, the customers all come to the same

Speaker: NA
Text: place; but, technically, the workers are em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed by different organisations. The mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment you introduce that distinction into these

Speaker: NA
Text: laws you invite that activity-and you do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have to invite it too much because it already

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs for tax purposes and for other rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons. The government is going to confront

Speaker: NA
Text: that situation. But, sadly, the people who will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay the cost will be the workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third amendment I will refer to is the

Speaker: NA
Text: change that lawyers and other representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: must disclose whether or not they have a

Speaker: NA
Text: costs arrangement or contingency fee agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-that is, no win, no pay. Why are we

Speaker: NA
Text: doing this? If the law is supposed to deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mine matters before it on the facts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: case, why should the financial arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: between the client and the lawyer be a

Speaker: NA
Text: ground for determining whether or not the

Speaker: NA
Text: excase should succeed? This is an absurd prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple that we do not apply anywhere else in

Speaker: NA
Text: the legal system. But when it comes to work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers' rights for reinstatement, we introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: it-only here do we introduce it-to strip

Speaker: NA
Text: away one of the arguments that workers have

Speaker: NA
Text: available to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inference, of course, is that if a

Speaker: NA
Text: worker-who, by the way, has just lost their

Speaker: NA
Text: job, so the chances are they do not have a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of money and certainly have no income

Speaker: NA
Text: stream for the future-gets offered the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to have their case taken by a law-

Speaker: NA
Text: yer on a no win, no pay situation, that is less

Speaker: NA
Text: meritorious than if they had a big bank ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count and could afford to pay the lawyer up

Speaker: NA
Text: front in a trust fund. What an absurd, class

Speaker: NA
Text: based, elitist attitude that is. But that is what

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament is being asked to support by

Speaker: NA
Text: this government. A factor determining the

Speaker: NA
Text: merits is now whether you are rich enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay the lawyer and put the money into their

Speaker: NA
Text: trust fund up front. This really is chequebook

Speaker: NA
Text: judicial behaviour. This is disgraceful. Of all

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendments the government proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: make and that the Democrats have sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported, this one is the most offensive. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: actually surprised that the Democrats have

Speaker: NA
Text: given it their support.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to mention two other amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly-I hope not to prolong the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: much further. One is the prohibition on ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: visers encouraging applicants to make or

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue a claim where they were, or should

Speaker: NA
Text: have been, aware that it had no reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of success, for which the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment now intend to impose a fine of $10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: on the body corporate or $2,000 on the indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual. Again, this is a mechanism that, as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I am aware, is unknown in the rest of

Speaker: NA
Text: the legal system. (Extension of time granted)

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not actually fine advisers in any other

Speaker: NA
Text: jurisdiction I am aware of because they hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pen to have lost the case. They may have to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay costs in some jurisdictions, but that is

Speaker: NA
Text: not what we are talking about here. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: actually talking about fining them because

Speaker: NA
Text: they lost the case. Someone is going to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cide: you should have known you were going

Speaker: NA
Text: to lose the case, so you should not have

Speaker: NA
Text: fronted up in the first place. This is a stacked

Speaker: NA
Text: deck. This government have loaded the dice

Speaker: NA
Text: so that when a worker takes a case for unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal the odds are well and truly stacked

Speaker: NA
Text: against them. And not only are the odds

Speaker: NA
Text: stacked against them because we have

Speaker: NA
Text: changed the rules on how it is going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: decided; if you happen to lose, not only are

Speaker: NA
Text: you not going to get your job back, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: are you not going to get any money, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: may you face costs, but your advisers may be

Speaker: NA
Text: fined as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Follow through the implications of this.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are going to be required to give up

Speaker: NA
Text: their assets to pay costs. For a lot of workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in this situation, their assets are the house

Speaker: NA
Text: and car and a bit of furniture-that is it. So

Speaker: NA
Text: what are we going to take from them? Are

Speaker: NA
Text: we going to take the car from them? Well,

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be helpful for them in finding an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other job-they will not have transport. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is good. Or are we going to take the furniture

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the house or sell up the house? Or are

Speaker: NA
Text: we going to put them in jail? We will put

Speaker: NA
Text: them in jail because they had the audacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: go before the courts and argue they had been

Speaker: NA
Text: unfairly sacked. That is the application of the

Speaker: NA
Text: combination of these things.

Speaker: NA
Text: We acknowledge, as I said at the outset,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a problem with ambulance chas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and there is a problem with time delays.

Speaker: NA
Text: The time delay issue is not addressed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill at all. But to the extent that the Demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: crats have sought to fix the problem associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated with ambulance chasers, they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed it; what they have done is create an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other set of problems that is greater than the

Speaker: NA
Text: one they set out to solve. We will not be a

Speaker: NA
Text: party to doing that. We opposed this in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate and we will oppose the bill here in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives. I look forward,

Speaker: NA
Text: early next year in government, to bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to the parliament a bill to put some

Speaker: NA
Text: decency back into these arrangements and to

Speaker: NA
Text: address the issue the government have failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at-the problem of time delays-and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in consultation with the stakeholders, to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: more fairly with the issue of ambulance

Speaker: NA
Text: chasers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I again remind the House: let us not kid

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves about the practice of ambulance

Speaker: NA
Text: chasers. It is not unique to unfair dismissals;

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not unique to industrial law. And I sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect that, when the legal profession find a

Speaker: NA
Text: nice set of rules or practices to overcome that

Speaker: NA
Text: problem generically, at that point, and not

Speaker: NA
Text: before, we will overcome the problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations. But we should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to address that in an isolated fashion,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly when to do it in the way this

Speaker: NA
Text: government proposes to do it denies ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: workers the limited rights they currently

Speaker: NA
Text: have. Those limited rights, made available

Speaker: NA
Text: by Peter Reith's first wave of IR laws, were

Speaker: NA
Text: in themselves not overly generous. Today,

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament proposes to take away some

Speaker: NA
Text: of those limited rights. We will divide on the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill when the debate reaches that point and

Speaker: NA
Text: we will oppose it.

Speaker: Mrs CROSIO
Text: Prospect) (12.38 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: too would like to rise and consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments in the House today. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: when I relooked at when the Workplace Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations Amendment (Termination of Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment) Bill 2000 first came into the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, I found that it was something I spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: about in September last year, so here we are

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 12 months later discovering that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are still trying to rectify some of the anoma-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies existing in this bill. Having this minister

Speaker: NA
Text: now in control of industrial relations is like

Speaker: NA
Text: having Dracula in charge of the blood bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot expect any sympathy, we cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: expect any thoroughness and, more impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tantly, we cannot expect any sympathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of what workers are on about

Speaker: NA
Text: out there in the real world. This is really a

Speaker: NA
Text: no-frills version of the ‘more jobs, better

Speaker: NA
Text: pay' bill that was put up by the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. When you look at that bill, and then

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the debate that took place in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate on the amendments that we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: debating, you understand and appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: where we are really coming from. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment are really about driving a stake into

Speaker: NA
Text: the heart of industrial relations. They seem

Speaker: NA
Text: have an absolute obsession with dismantling

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Industrial Relations Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, which is really the only fair and inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent umpire. If this government had their

Speaker: NA
Text: way, believe me, we would still have eight-

Speaker: NA
Text: and nine-year-olds down in the coalmines or

Speaker: NA
Text: working in the cotton mills.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the Minister for Employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations and Small Business,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is at the table: Minister, you have got to

Speaker: NA
Text: wake up. We are now in the 21st century.

Speaker: NA
Text: This minister seems to be an absolute clone

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992, when he was Liberal spokesman for

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations, said-and I say it again;

Speaker: NA
Text: he has never denied it: it is there in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ord-‘We in the Liberal coalition would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to stab the commission in the stomach.' And

Speaker: NA
Text: that is what we seem to be doing eight or

Speaker: NA
Text: nine years later. The government are trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to have another crack at it; they are making

Speaker: NA
Text: another attempt to walk over the workers to

Speaker: NA
Text: stab the commission in the stomach. If they

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that unfair dismissal is really going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be an issue out there with workers and

Speaker: NA
Text: employers, I say again what I said last Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember: they have got to do their homework,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they have to do it well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yesterday I criticised the minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table in the matter of public importance be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore this House over his claim that protecting

Speaker: NA
Text: the entitlements of workers by a 0.1 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: charge will cost 50,000 jobs. This seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a mythical figure that the coalition gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment repeatedly brings up. I did some

Speaker: NA
Text: more research and found that when Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Reith was in charge of industrial relations he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that if we did not get rid of unfair dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missals we would lose 50,000 jobs, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: if we did not do something about unfair dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missals we would not allow small business to

Speaker: NA
Text: create 50,000 jobs. This mythical 50,000

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to pop up every time this government

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to colour the figures or colour the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate-I call it hypocrisy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tried to find at least an honest survey to

Speaker: NA
Text: see where anyone could get these figures as

Speaker: NA
Text: to how many people will be disadvantaged. I

Speaker: NA
Text: could not find any. The only paper I could

Speaker: NA
Text: find that had surveyed small businesses em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploying workers out there in some of the ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: to eas I was concerned about was a University

Speaker: NA
Text: of Newcastle paper in 1999 which says that

Speaker: NA
Text: less than half of their respondents found un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fair dismissal laws influenced them in any

Speaker: NA
Text: way whatsoever when hiring their people. I

Speaker: NA
Text: then found another survey done in May

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000-the Telstra Yellow Pages Small Busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness Index-where it asked the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 1,200 small business owners, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: from the replies, 44 per cent of small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses believed there were no barriers what-

Speaker: NA
Text: soever and, of the 56 per cent who believed

Speaker: NA
Text: there were barriers to taking on new employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ees, 39 per cent believed the major barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: was that there was not enough work, 19 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent mentioned the cost of employing them,

Speaker: NA
Text: rec12 per cent said that finding skilled labour

Speaker: NA
Text: and staff was a barrier, eight per cent said the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of cash flow, and eight per cent said the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of the GST. There was no men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, in the only two surveys I have been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to find in that respect, that if we can get rid

Speaker: NA
Text: of unfair dismissals it will create lots of jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry at large. I am saying to the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment through the minister: if we are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to have figures floated around to be used as a

Speaker: NA
Text: basis for amendments or for this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to become law, then let us have some

Speaker: NA
Text: factual figures and let us not be so hypocriti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal in presenting this mythical figure of

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 every time someone wants to prove a

Speaker: NA
Text: point.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to agree with the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Brisbane, our shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister on industrial relations, on the points

Speaker: NA
Text: he made regarding the amendments that were

Speaker: NA
Text: moved in the Senate. When I first saw that

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Murray was trying to move the word

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘reasonable', I thought that I would like any-

Speaker: NA
Text: one to define ‘reasonable' when we are talk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about what is going on in the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the particular bill we are now de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bating here in the House. (Extension of time

Speaker: NA
Text: granted) As has been stated before by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Brisbane and to my

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge-and I am no lawyer, either; I

Speaker: NA
Text: can only do research-there is no instance in

Speaker: NA
Text: the courts of Australia where a person who

Speaker: NA
Text: has lost a case will not only then be asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay costs but will also be fined. Yet we are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying to individuals, ‘If we believe that you

Speaker: NA
Text: have no right of winning that case, you will

Speaker: NA
Text: be fined $2,000 before you even have the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to present it'- with a fine of $10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for a company. This is quite unfair. I really

Speaker: NA
Text: believe there has to be a lot more fairness in

Speaker: NA
Text: action in some sections of the bill, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly in the amendments. I reiterate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrat amendments, looking at the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciliation stage, ask the commission to indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate when an applicant has no reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of success. I say to you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, and to the minister: who decides

Speaker: NA
Text: that? The case is before the commission. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrat amendment says that at the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciliation stage it has to be indicated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission if the applicant has no reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able prospect of success. It is almost Caesar

Speaker: NA
Text: judging Caesar. The applicant is going before

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission to plead a case, and now the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission has to say, ‘At the conciliation

Speaker: NA
Text: stage, if I feel you are not going to win the

Speaker: NA
Text: case I am not going to allow you to proceed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the case.' I think we have to examine

Speaker: NA
Text: that a little bit further.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned before, with fines of

Speaker: NA
Text: $2,000 for an individual in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: breaching, how can you tell them they

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been aware they had no reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able prospect of success? When people you

Speaker: NA
Text: represent-especially people in an electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: like mine- have been unfairly dismissed,

Speaker: NA
Text: how can you say to them, ‘You have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: sure in your own mind that you are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue this claim, because you are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be fined if you have no reasonable prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: of success.' In other words, we would be

Speaker: NA
Text: saying to them, ‘Whatever you do, just take

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Don't try. Don't appeal.' We may have a

Speaker: NA
Text: lawful process but, because of this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's industrial relations bills and because

Speaker: NA
Text: of what they are trying to do in the industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations field, we will have to say to those

Speaker: NA
Text: people who feel they have a right to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: claim, ‘Don't do it. It'll be too hard for you.

Speaker: NA
Text: We're not going to give you the encourage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that you should have.' More impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tantly, we are denying workers their rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Who are we to say whether or not they have

Speaker: NA
Text: that right? Only the Industrial Relations

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission has that right.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned that if this bill goes

Speaker: NA
Text: through with these amendments in their pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent form we will have taken a backward

Speaker: NA
Text: step. We thought we were going into the 21st

Speaker: NA
Text: century with social changes, that is, consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration of the rights of workers. This gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, no matter what we see or hear from

Speaker: NA
Text: them, and no matter that they have changed

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers, will not change the level at which

Speaker: NA
Text: they contemplate where they are going with

Speaker: NA
Text: these bills. It is an enormous degree of hy-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocrisy on the part of the government. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us, for once, have some consideration of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the amendments signify and, more im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portantly, some consideration of what this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation signifies for the workers of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia into the future. If we as legislators fail

Speaker: NA
Text: them in this House, we fail as Australians.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Text: Calare) (12.47 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: the last five years I have been pretty consis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent about the workplace relations legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: of this government. I rejected the workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation in its original form when it came

Speaker: NA
Text: into this House back in 1996, but in that de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate I said that the unfair dismissal law was a

Speaker: NA
Text: disincentive to employment. As far as small

Speaker: NA
Text: employers throughout my electorate are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned I have found that to be a continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: situation. In this debate-and in it there have

Speaker: NA
Text: been extremes from both ends of the spec-

Speaker: NA
Text: trum-we have to start talking about mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: trust in the employment market, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to small business. We know the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the GST on small business and we

Speaker: NA
Text: know the impact of other regulatory changes

Speaker: NA
Text: on small business. I certainly know of the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on small business of the GST and I

Speaker: NA
Text: know, too, of the negative impact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal regime has on employers

Speaker: NA
Text: and indeed employees in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are to overcome the partisan and ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: versarial approach to industrial relations we

Speaker: NA
Text: must get away from this Left-Right nexus-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ideological positions that both sides

Speaker: NA
Text: take-and look at the actual job situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: For instance, I had a case in my electorate a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of years ago of a recently hired per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son who was looking after the phones in a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular company. The circumstance was

Speaker: NA
Text: that that person ran into a huge personality

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict with the manager. That person then

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeded to, if you like, undermine the

Speaker: NA
Text: credibility of the employer and, indeed, her

Speaker: NA
Text: work colleagues. That situation was unten-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. I believe that within an organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: with 15 or fewer employees we should not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a situation where the employee is able

Speaker: NA
Text: to march into that workplace in almost an

Speaker: NA
Text: adversarial role; nor should the employer be

Speaker: NA
Text: armed with the means of taking that person

Speaker: NA
Text: through a legal process or dismissing them

Speaker: NA
Text: on the spot. Where 15 or fewer employees

Speaker: NA
Text: are working in a small manufacturing plant

Speaker: NA
Text: or in commercial premises, unless there is

Speaker: NA
Text: that mutual trust it is not going to be a very

Speaker: NA
Text: productive workplace anyway. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: message I am getting from employers in my

Speaker: NA
Text: seat of Calare.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said back in March this year that in 1996

Speaker: NA
Text: I had no problems with a bill that exempts

Speaker: NA
Text: from the unfair dismissal provisions busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses employing no more than 15 workers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: feel the same way now. Such workers are

Speaker: NA
Text: always to be protected by the unlawful dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missal provisions which include dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: for discriminatory reasons such as sexual

Speaker: NA
Text: preference, age, union membership and fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily responsibilities. I said then, and I see

Speaker: NA
Text: reason to change my view after talking to

Speaker: NA
Text: small business operators, that unfair dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missal legislation is a disincentive

Speaker: NA
Text: pansion of employment opportunities. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: also aware that this government-and no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt future ones-will use employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment figures to their political ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage. It is a nonsense to speak only of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment figures as a sign of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: health. One needs to work only an hour a

Speaker: NA
Text: week to not appear on those stats.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many employees in rural and regional ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas, and no doubt in city areas, are cobbling

Speaker: NA
Text: together a portfolio of part-time and casual

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs to make ends meet. We must protect

Speaker: NA
Text: their work conditions; we must protect them

Speaker: NA
Text: in all ways-through representative union

Speaker: NA
Text: membership, if that is their choice. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: recent days we have seen the effectiveness of

Speaker: NA
Text: arguing that position on behalf of employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I honestly believe that, unless we have

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual trust in those small, micro businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: and employment situations, with employers

Speaker: NA
Text: armed with lawyers and employees with no

Speaker: NA
Text: resources to access lawyers, this three

Speaker: NA
Text: months is reasonable. I accept the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the Workplace Relations Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Termination of Employment) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 that have been passed by the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HORNE
Text: Paterson) (12.52 p.m.)-Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore I came into the House today, I noticed

Speaker: NA
Text: on my computer that the job figures have just

Speaker: NA
Text: been released. They indicate that there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in unemployment in Australia. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment stays constant at 6.9 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, what they show is that the agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: of this government is well and truly on track,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the number of full-time permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs has decreased and the casualisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian workers has increased. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda of this government: this government

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that the problem we are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: today does not relate to casual workers and

Speaker: NA
Text: that is why this government encourages the

Speaker: NA
Text: casualisation of Australia's work force. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the tragedy that is befalling many Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian workers. That is the uncertainty that is

Speaker: NA
Text: being built into the life pattern of many

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australian families in particular: they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot make a commitment to the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: no this country, they cannot make a commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the future of their families, because

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not guaranteed a job next week, next

Speaker: NA
Text: to the exmonth, next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other point I would like to make is

Speaker: NA
Text: about Job Network. The Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment, Workplace Relations and Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business, who is at the table, often gets up

Speaker: NA
Text: and reminds us that as far as this government

Speaker: NA
Text: is concerned 15 hours of paid work is a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fifteen hours of paid work is what this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will fund a Job Network provider

Speaker: NA
Text: for, as long as they can get a person 15

Speaker: NA
Text: hours. It is not a question of whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: can find them a job on which they can earn

Speaker: NA
Text: their living, on which they can survive, and

Speaker: NA
Text: nor are the statistics that give us the 6.9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent unemployment based on such criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: in Surely anyone in the work force that has a

Speaker: NA
Text: job has a right to expect that they can survive

Speaker: NA
Text: on that job, that they can be independent and

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will upkeep them and give them a

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living. Of course, that is not what

Speaker: NA
Text: the government claims at all. This govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment says, ‘Fifteen hours of work is a job,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will pay a Job Network provider as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as they can get that amount of work for

Speaker: NA
Text: someone that has been unemployed.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The Steel Tank and Pipe Company in

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle is one of those companies that

Speaker: NA
Text: went belly-up last year. The 200 workers had

Speaker: NA
Text: to fight for their entitlements. Of course they

Speaker: NA
Text: missed out on them. I always find it inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: esting that it is the workers that have to

Speaker: NA
Text: for their entitlements and it is this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that forces the workers to fight for their

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements. It should be the reverse, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause in my opinion what happened to those

Speaker: NA
Text: workers was quite criminal. They were trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred in employment from their original

Speaker: NA
Text: employing company to a number of shelf

Speaker: NA
Text: companies that were only shells-they had

Speaker: NA
Text: no cash and no material. When the day came

Speaker: NA
Text: when the workers were told, ‘Sorry, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no more work,' there was absolutely no sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance to the company that was employing

Speaker: NA
Text: them. The plant, the equipment, the land-all

Speaker: NA
Text: the property-was held by another company,

Speaker: NA
Text: not the employing company. Do we hear

Speaker: NA
Text: anything from this government in defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the workers in that situation? No, not one jot.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet what happened to those workers Steel

Speaker: NA
Text: Tank and Pipe Company in my opinion, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, is quite criminal, quite abhorrent to

Speaker: NA
Text: every Australian except this minister, who

Speaker: NA
Text: had absolutely nothing to say on it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace relations is the most important

Speaker: NA
Text: foundation on which to build any nation. We

Speaker: NA
Text: want families out there to have confidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of this country, to have the confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence to go out and build a house whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they get $14,000 or not. They can only do so

Speaker: NA
Text: if they know with some security that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have a job, that they have a place in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's work force. It is the responsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: government to ensure that that security is

Speaker: NA
Text: there. All we see from this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: that security being reduced at every occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. That is why we should oppose it. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Text: Barton) (12.57

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-The first point of real concern is what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Workplace Relations Amendment (Ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mination of Employment) Bill 2000 means

Speaker: NA
Text: to the employment security of average work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, in particular workers in a number of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries that are facing significant structural,

Speaker: NA
Text: economic change-in particular, the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing industry. We note, for instance, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Democrat amendments took out an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to section 170CG, by removing

Speaker: NA
Text: the words which had prevented unfair dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missal actions in circumstances which in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved the operational requirements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: employer's undertaking, establishment or

Speaker: NA
Text: fight service. But in the amendments that have

Speaker: NA
Text: come in, it is proposed to add an additional

Speaker: NA
Text: term in section 170CG(d) to prevent unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal actions relating to the operational

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of the employer's undertaking,

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment or service, unless the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances are exceptional.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are going to be the exceptional cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances? That is so vague as to be all but

Speaker: NA
Text: useless. Already, as a result of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's inclusion in section 89A of the Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations Act that issues relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: redundancy cannot be included in awards-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, there can be no requirement placed in

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial awards compelling employers to

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate with workers or their unions prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to dismissal in circumstances of redun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dancy-workers are left with the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is only in an enterprise agreement or

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps an Australian workplace agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: that they could prescribe a procedure in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of dismissal as a result of technological

Speaker: NA
Text: change or economic decline. However, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are authorities that the Federal Court cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: grant injunctive relief-or, in other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: specific performance-of those sorts of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Effectively, when this bill goes through,

Speaker: NA
Text: workers who are sacked because of the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: erational requirements of the business-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, because of restructuring, technological

Speaker: NA
Text: change or economic decline- are without

Speaker: NA
Text: remedy. This government is dramatically

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocritical, and that stands out starkly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian workers have had a bomb explode

Speaker: NA
Text: at their feet today courtesy of this minister. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think, with respect to the minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: his department, that he has thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: through. This is a matter of real concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: the job security of ordinary Australian work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the time available to me I will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to traverse the matters raised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the shadow minister. I think he did very

Speaker: NA
Text: well, with respect to him. There is no need

Speaker: NA
Text: for these double standards that apply to the

Speaker: NA
Text: representation of workers who have lost their

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. We have heard in debate during parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment this week that if you are in or above

Speaker: NA
Text: your mid-40s and without tertiary education

Speaker: NA
Text: you are in real trouble in terms of getting

Speaker: NA
Text: other employment. To require the disclosure

Speaker: NA
Text: of contingency fee arrangements in circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances where lawyers in Australia are not

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to claim a percentage of any verdict

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained- they can only charge their scale

Speaker: NA
Text: fee according to court rules-is totally un-

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary. To cast a reverse onus on lawyers

Speaker: NA
Text: to prove that their ongoing conduct of the

Speaker: NA
Text: litigation was justified turns completely on

Speaker: NA
Text: its head any concept of professional privilege

Speaker: NA
Text: that has developed, because a lawyer needing

Speaker: NA
Text: to discharge that reverse onus would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: breach solicitor-client privilege. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that the legal profession generally

Speaker: NA
Text: should be concerned about. There is no other

Speaker: NA
Text: area of the law where that could even possi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly be contemplated. But to do it with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect to workers, to scapegoat workers who

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost their jobs, is quite simply an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: rage. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Workplace Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business) (1.02 p.m.)-I do not wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to prolong debate on the Workplace Rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Amendment (Termination of Employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment) Bill 2000 but I do wish to respond

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly to some of the comments that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made by speakers in the debate. While I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not agree with most of what was put by

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition members, I do respect their pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion and their commitment and I thank them

Speaker: NA
Text: for their contributions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Brisbane made a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of points. The first point he made was that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate's amendments are amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's 1996 legislation, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was declared at the time to institute a fair go

Speaker: NA
Text: all round in the unfair dismissals regime. I

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly take the member's point. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to our legislation. We thought at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time that our legislation was, indeed, a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair go all round. The sad truth is that,

Speaker: NA
Text: eration, our legislation did not work as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as we thought it should. That is why it

Speaker: NA
Text: needed some change and that is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: think the bill as amended by the Senate is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the member for Brisbane said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the changes would mean that people

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to run a full case up front be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the ability of the commission to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude proceedings after a conciliation hear-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. I think that is a reasonable point for the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Brisbane to make, but the reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the regime as it stands has meant that,

Speaker: NA
Text: after a conciliation hearing, the vast majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of employers have been in the situation of

Speaker: NA
Text: having to pay as they contemplate the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing. Hence the inelegant expression

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘piss-off money', which so many businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply complain about having to pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third point that the member for Bris-

Speaker: NA
Text: bane made was that, as a result of changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill, workers would be employed by dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent entities. The provisions of this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring the commission to take into ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count the different circumstances of small

Speaker: NA
Text: business do not go to the substantive law. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are not talking here about a different law

Speaker: NA
Text: applying to small business when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissals; we are simply talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the consideration that the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: should give to small business in the conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: of these hearings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fourth point that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane made was that the no win, no fee

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosure was oppressive. I should point out

Speaker: NA
Text: in response that there is no requirement un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the bill for the commission to take any

Speaker: NA
Text: judicial notice of this. It is simply the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's view that it is relevant and it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be on the public record.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final point that the member for Bris-

Speaker: NA
Text: bane made was that the commission's ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to impose fines for unmeritorious cases is an

Speaker: NA
Text: unjust imposition on people in trouble. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me just reassure the member for Brisbane on

Speaker: NA
Text: that point by stressing that these fines can be

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed on lawyers and their advisers, not

Speaker: NA
Text: on applicants in this case.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, I do not wish to prolong the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate. I certainly do not wish to impugn the

Speaker: NA
Text: in opmotives or the commitment of members op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite who made the points they did in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. I think, if I may say so, that their

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns are misplaced, because I have con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable confidence in the ability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission to handle this new regime fairly.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the commission comprises decent

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who are determined to do the

Speaker: NA
Text: right thing by all Australians, but particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: by working Australians. I do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: this regime will be interpreted in ways which

Speaker: NA
Text: are harmful to the workers of Australia. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the bill, as amended, to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Senate's amendments be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House divided. [1.11 p.m.]

Speaker: NA
Text: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND

Speaker: NA
Text: SECONDARY EDUCATION

Speaker: NA
Text: ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms O'BYRNE (Bass) (1.18 p.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: States Grants (Primary and Secondary Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to implement the changes to funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for literacy and numeracy programs outlined

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 2001 budget. The funding for these

Speaker: NA
Text: programs is for 2001-02 and 2002-03. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Education, Training and Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs has claimed that nearly $40 million is

Speaker: NA
Text: planned to be spent on literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. This announcement was made

Speaker: NA
Text: with much fanfare and beating of chests, but

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately with very little actual basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Paper No. 2 makes a mockery of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister's claims. Under the heading ‘Im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving schooling outcomes', the years are

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004-05-but what seems to be missing is

Speaker: NA
Text: the millions of dollars for each year; the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount appears to be zero. But what else can

Speaker: NA
Text: we expect from this government-the mas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters of mean and tricky?

Speaker: NA
Text: Literacy is important. It is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: component of our ability to function within

Speaker: NA
Text: our society. We certainly need to aim for not

Speaker: NA
Text: only high levels of literacy across the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity but high literacy levels for all indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals within our community. This need

Speaker: NA
Text: was recognised by the previous Labor gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. In an effort to gain a benchmark

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of literacy in our schools, in 1994

Speaker: NA
Text: the federal Labor government provided $2.6

Speaker: NA
Text: million for the national schools English liter-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy survey, which took place in 1996, to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide nationally comparable data on liter-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy achievement. Unfortunately, the minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Kemp, could not agree with the state

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers on what the results showed, so he

Speaker: NA
Text: went out and commissioned his own report

Speaker: NA
Text: on the survey. His report differed signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly from the initial report. The two reports

Speaker: NA
Text: ranged from four per cent of year 3 students

Speaker: NA
Text: not achieving the benchmark for reading to,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to Dr Kemp's report, some 27 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. It would not be too much of a stretch

Speaker: NA
Text: for someone to suggest that it was the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister's intention to artificially engineer a

Speaker: NA
Text: port which allowed him to claim that literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: standards were well below their actual mark.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to measuring any portion

Speaker: NA
Text: of our community we can always rely on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ABS. Given that this week the census was

Speaker: NA
Text: collected, I would like to note that the ABS

Speaker: NA
Text: has looked into literacy levels and found that

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been no major change in those lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: els over the last 20 years. There is no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that literacy is critically important, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt there would be any disagreement with

Speaker: NA
Text: this from any member of the House. But

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a catch: the only way we can expect

Speaker: NA
Text: our schools and our teachers to deliver is if

Speaker: NA
Text: we deliver to them the level of resources and

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of support they require. The reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for needing to deliver support is that the task

Speaker: NA
Text: of removing barriers to learning cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: left to teachers alone. No matter how hard

Speaker: NA
Text: our dedicated teaching professionals work,

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be barriers to attaining greater

Speaker: NA
Text: learning outcomes that they will not be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to overcome on their own. But the trick to

Speaker: NA
Text: providing not only the resources required but

Speaker: NA
Text: also the support required is realising that

Speaker: NA
Text: funds are required. With the transfer of funds

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia's richest schools and areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers in our outstanding public schools

Speaker: NA
Text: are not receiving the funds that they know

Speaker: NA
Text: they need. They know it because they dedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate all of their concerns to students and to

Speaker: NA
Text: education. I wish the minister were half as

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to education policies as our

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers are. That is the primary reason that

Speaker: NA
Text: most of them become teachers, and they are

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly doing their bit.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the federal government is not coming

Speaker: NA
Text: to the party. This focus has gone hand in

Speaker: NA
Text: hand with Dr Kemp's focus on providing

Speaker: NA
Text: additional funding to private schools, seen in

Speaker: NA
Text: his unfair enrolment benchmark adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the introduction of the SES funding

Speaker: NA
Text: model for non-government schools. The na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional literacy and numeracy plan endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1997 was seen by many as a response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the media driven perception that literacy lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: els were at a desperate point. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Union has accused the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of manufacturing a literacy crisis for

Speaker: NA
Text: political expediency. Although it is clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: the literacy debate is often used for political

Speaker: NA
Text: regain, one point that is not debated is the link

Speaker: NA
Text: between literacy skills, socioeconomic dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage and opportunity. A stark example

Speaker: NA
Text: of this is shown in a recent Australian Bu-

Speaker: NA
Text: reau of Statistics study which shows that the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate for people with poor lit-

Speaker: NA
Text: eracy skills is 16 per cent, compared with

Speaker: NA
Text: only four per cent for those with high skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot allow socioeconomic disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tages of children to dictate their lives, op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunities and outcomes. People must be

Speaker: NA
Text: given a fair go to achieve their full potential.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why the Labor Party will introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: education priority zones.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education priority zones will focus on the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of education as a tool for overcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: economic disadvantage. DETYA's analysis

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 1996 national schools English literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: survey found that children of upper profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional or managerial parents had signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly higher literacy achievement than chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren of parents working in unskilled manual

Speaker: NA
Text: occupations. A 1993 DEET ACER report

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at children who had completed year

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 and found that those who had professional

Speaker: NA
Text: parents were twice as likely to go to univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity than those who had unskilled parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: and those from the wealthiest 25 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: families were 33 per cent more likely to go

Speaker: NA
Text: to university than those from the poorest 25

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. The Tasmanian Primary Principals

Speaker: NA
Text: Association talks about the influence of pov-

Speaker: NA
Text: erty on educational outcomes in its recent

Speaker: NA
Text: report entitled Learning Together. The report

Speaker: NA
Text: says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Poverty is an additional and critical factor in the

Speaker: NA
Text: quest for all students to be literate and educated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The relationship between children living in pov-

Speaker: NA
Text: erty and illiteracy is well established. 40% of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanians are now judged to be living in pov-

Speaker: NA
Text: erty (The Mercury, April 15 2000), exacerbating

Speaker: NA
Text: our educational problems ... the highest rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: illiteracy is still found in our schools with the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest number of children coming from families

Speaker: NA
Text: existing below the poverty line.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report goes on to talk about Dr Ken

Speaker: NA
Text: Rowe's observation of a particular outcome

Speaker: NA
Text: of the poverty for boys' disruptive behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: study. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is strong evidence indicating that poor

Speaker: NA
Text: eracy leads to disruptive behaviour, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: disruptive behaviour leading to poor literacy. This

Speaker: NA
Text: chain of poverty-poor learning, disruptive be-

Speaker: NA
Text: haviour is well known to educators and many

Speaker: NA
Text: others but has yet to be broken in a major way. It

Speaker: NA
Text: now needs to be done, not only to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: life chances of children from impoverished

Speaker: NA
Text: homes, but for the good of society in general.

Speaker: NA
Text: These statistics prove that if we are to over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come intergenerational economic disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage in our society, we must improve educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional opportunity for those disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: children. While the Prime Minister targets

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's wealthiest schools for assistance,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will identify schools in low socioeco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic areas and work with the community to

Speaker: NA
Text: identify what is needed in those particular

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. We know that a one size fits all

Speaker: NA
Text: policy will never work in this complex area,

Speaker: NA
Text: so the initiatives used in education priority

Speaker: NA
Text: zones will be multifaceted. In each zone the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth will work with communities

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop a plan for their particular commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity that will include a focus on core educa-

Speaker: NA
