Text: tional outcomes such as literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy and year 12 completion rates, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: will actually be accountable for improving

Speaker: NA
Text: those things. Some of the initiatives could

Speaker: NA
Text: include employing specialist remedial liter-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy and numeracy teachers; extra profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional development for teachers; introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: a community mentor program; encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: local businesses and local government to

Speaker: NA
Text: work with schools to motivate students and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide new opportunities for them, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: the excellent no dole program, which is run

Speaker: NA
Text: at Brooks high school within my electorate;

Speaker: NA
Text: and strengthening the link between schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFEs and universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: This policy demonstrates definitively the

Speaker: NA
Text: stark contrast between the position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government and the position of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Beazley government in regard to their

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to public education. Public

Speaker: NA
Text: schools educate over 70 per cent of our chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren. A high quality public education system

Speaker: NA
Text: is the backbone of a fair and equitable soci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ety. It is the only way we can ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: children from all backgrounds, geographical

Speaker: NA
Text: locations and areas of society get a fair go. In

Speaker: NA
Text: a recent article in Dissent titled ‘The freebie

Speaker: NA
Text: down the road', Lindsay Connors explains

Speaker: NA
Text: lit- the effect of government indifference to

Speaker: NA
Text: public education:

Speaker: NA
Text: Educational inequality strikes at the heart of de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mocracy, leaving those poor in terms of knowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge and information to be used and manipulated

Speaker: NA
Text: by those with greater power.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the Prime Minister is busy looking

Speaker: NA
Text: after the wealthiest and most advantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in our community, Labor is saying

Speaker: NA
Text: loud and clear, ‘We are committed to high

Speaker: NA
Text: quality public education for all Australians.'

Speaker: NA
Text: In its recent report Learning Together, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian Primary Principals Association

Speaker: NA
Text: talks about the importance of public educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments, communities and schools are right

Speaker: NA
Text: to relentlessly pursue the ideal that all will be

Speaker: NA
Text: well educated. Education is the best chance for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people to become positive, active partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pants in our democratic society and economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Howard government's emphasis on pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate schools endeavours to change the way

Speaker: NA
Text: we think about our education system. Profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sor Alan Reid of the Australian Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Union says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The shift of students from the public to the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate system has a number of effects, the most

Speaker: NA
Text: significant of which is the way it threatens

Speaker: NA
Text: our accepted understanding about the nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: public education. Since it is this change which

Speaker: NA
Text: endangers our democratic system, it is the one

Speaker: NA
Text: which most demands community attention and

Speaker: NA
Text: debate ... Broadly speaking, individual private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools represent a certain section of the popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ... By contrast, public schools comprise a

Speaker: NA
Text: diverse cross-section of the population of their

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities. It is this key difference which

Speaker: NA
Text: is about to change. As the government facilitates

Speaker: NA
Text: this shift to private schooling and creates a single

Speaker: NA
Text: education market, so the diversity of public

Speaker: NA
Text: schools will diminish.

Speaker: NA
Text: This change introduced by the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, with the misleading rhetoric of

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘choice', is incredibly damaging to our soci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ety. It undermines the very basis of a fair and

Speaker: NA
Text: equitable Australia. Marginson in 1997 says

Speaker: NA
Text: that this emphasis:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... encourages parental choice to be expressed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of a myriad of different monocultural

Speaker: NA
Text: world views, premised explicitly on the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid contamination by other groups. This is to

Speaker: NA
Text: put a value on social difference rather than toler-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance ... and in laying the basis for serious social

Speaker: NA
Text: and educational problems in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Howard government's commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: private education is demonstrated in three

Speaker: NA
Text: policy changes that have been made since

Speaker: NA
Text: they came to office in 1996: the abolition of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's new schools policy, the introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of the enrolment benchmark adjustment and

Speaker: NA
Text: the SES funding for non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. Associate Professor of Education at

Speaker: NA
Text: the University of South Australia, Alan Reid,

Speaker: NA
Text: commented for the AEU that:

Speaker: NA
Text: The point ... is to shift people across to private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most recent evidence of this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's favouring of the wealthiest private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools-of which, I hasten to add once

Speaker: NA
Text: again, there is not a single one in Tasma-

Speaker: NA
Text: nia-is in the form of the SES funding

Speaker: NA
Text: model. The minister has abolished the previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous education resources index. This index

Speaker: NA
Text: was a measure of the school's ability to gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erate its own funds compared to a standard

Speaker: NA
Text: level of school resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new SES system supposedly assesses

Speaker: NA
Text: need according to the socioeconomic status

Speaker: NA
Text: to alter of the school community but directs high

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of funding to the nation's wealthiest

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. This new system is a clear indica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of where the Howard government's pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: orities lie, and that is to look after the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealthiest people in our community. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: mode that is simply not fair. It completely

Speaker: NA
Text: undermines the needs based principle un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derlying Commonwealth funding of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. It takes no account of

Speaker: NA
Text: the school's resources and earning capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: and ignores assets, donations and trust funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know of any state primary school in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate that actually has a trust fund,

Speaker: NA
Text: but what I do know is the number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who struggle to take their children on a

Speaker: NA
Text: school trip or to keep books in their school

Speaker: NA
Text: library.

Speaker: NA
Text: The incredible inequity of the system is

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out by Lindsay Connors when she

Speaker: NA
Text: asks the question, ‘Fairness for Whom?' She

Speaker: NA
Text: asks:

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it fair that significant increases will go to some

Speaker: NA
Text: schools with more than twice the funds to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: on their students as most others? The answer de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pends on what the policy is trying to achieve.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to Dr Kemp, it was the previous edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation resources index which was unfair. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: like calling a common tape measure unfair ... it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have human virtues like fairness. That

Speaker: NA
Text: depends on how it is used. Dr Kemp's repeated

Speaker: NA
Text: assertion that the ERI was unfair masks the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Howard government is changing far more

Speaker: NA
Text: than the index. It is making radical changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: game itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: The concept of socio-economic status comes in as

Speaker: NA
Text: a device only for ranking schools for public

Speaker: NA
Text: funding purposes. The resources the school actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally has are irrelevant under the scheme ... This is

Speaker: NA
Text: in no way a scheme designed to narrow the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisting gap between educational outcomes that

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect socio-economic differences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The assertion that this system will make

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government schools available to all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians is completely ridiculous. The

Speaker: NA
Text: money will be paid directly to the school,

Speaker: NA
Text: with no compulsion for them to reduce fees;

Speaker: NA
Text: thus they will still remain inaccessible to low

Speaker: NA
Text: income Australians. This system is not even

Speaker: NA
Text: to be fairly applied to all non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. In fact, it will apply only to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fifth that stand to benefit from its applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Those schools will benefit greatly, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest will be funded at the level of the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any initiatives that improve literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently life outcomes for our children

Speaker: NA
Text: must be supported. However, we must never

Speaker: NA
Text: forget where this government's priorities lie

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to the education of our na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's children. They do not lie with the

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling public schools that are battling

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming odds to give their students a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair go; they do not lie with the 70 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian children who are educated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: public system; they do not lie with the dedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated and hardworking teachers struggling

Speaker: NA
Text: with inadequate funds to still provide a qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity education for the children that they teach;

Speaker: NA
Text: and they do not lie with the socially and eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomically disadvantaged members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. Their priorities, as we all know

Speaker: NA
Text: too well, lie with the most socially, economi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally and educationally advantaged members

Speaker: NA
Text: of our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Literacy is undoubtedly important and so

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill will be supported. But a true com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment from the government to the educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Australian children would be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: freshing and, frankly, most welcome.

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Text: ANNE KELLY (Dawson) (1.30

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I rise to speak in support of the States

Speaker: NA
Text: Grants (Primary and Secondary Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very important piece of legislation. It is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant to the independent schools in my

Speaker: NA
Text: state of Queensland and in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson. I take this opportunity to commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the independent schools in my electorate, be

Speaker: NA
Text: they Catholic, Anglican or other independent

Speaker: NA
Text: church based schools. They make a wonder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful contribution to the education of our chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren in Dawson.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill has already been unnecessarily

Speaker: NA
Text: delayed by the opposition and should be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: layed no longer. It contains no policy change

Speaker: NA
Text: to funding arrangements of non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. It is simply an additional appropria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to ensure that the government can meet

Speaker: NA
Text: its obligations to 54 new non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools over the next four years and the al-

Speaker: NA
Text: most 4,000 students who will attend them.

Speaker: NA
Text: oneHaving delayed the passage of this bill once,

Speaker: NA
Text: I sincerely hope that the opposition gives it a

Speaker: NA
Text: speedy passage both here and in the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to turn to some of the misin-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation that is being peddled about school

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. One of the things that I note when I

Speaker: NA
Text: travel around Dawson and visit both gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and non-government schools is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the signs on government schools still say

Speaker: NA
Text: what they said when I was a child, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a while ago: Queensland state school.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason they are called state schools is

Speaker: NA
Text: because predominantly they are the respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: of sibility of the state to fund, assisted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. The reality is that some 88

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent-it varies-of funding for govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment schools, or state schools as they are

Speaker: NA
Text: known in Queensland, comes from the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government; the remainder comes from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. However, non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools-private schools, church schools;

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a number of terms used to describe

Speaker: NA
Text: them-receive virtually no funding from

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments. They are dependent on

Speaker: NA
Text: their parish, their parents and the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth government of the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: The claim is made that these private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools or non-government schools receive

Speaker: NA
Text: more per student in public funding than gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment schools. This assertion is simply not

Speaker: NA
Text: true. By 2004, government secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools will receive approximately $8,172

Speaker: NA
Text: per student per year in public funding. By the

Speaker: NA
Text: same year, for those students in

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government schools, the amount will be

Speaker: NA
Text: $5,721 per student per year-considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: less. That is for non-government schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the needier schools. For those so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called wealthy schools-and I do not quite

Speaker: NA
Text: know how one determines a wealthy

Speaker: NA
Text: school-the amount of government funding

Speaker: NA
Text: per student per year is $1,120. It is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: plain to see that government schools receive

Speaker: NA
Text: some $8,000 per student; non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools receive some $5½ thousand; and the

Speaker: NA
Text: so-called wealthier schools receive $1,100.

Speaker: NA
Text: The facts speak for themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to turn particularly to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of school funding in my home state

Speaker: NA
Text: of Queensland. Much has been said by the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition and elements of the education

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement in recent days and weeks,

Speaker: NA
Text: attempting to prove that Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for state schools was being cut in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of private schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the record, Commonwealth funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for state schools in Queensland is increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: to a record $440 million in 2002-an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of $23.6 million, or 5.7 per cent, over

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous year. Compared to 1996, the last

Speaker: NA
Text: year of a Labor federal government, this rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resents a massive 52 per cent increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for state schools. That is a pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: good record when you consider that the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of students since 1996 has increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by only 2.3 per cent. It is quite plain that,

Speaker: NA
Text: while Commonwealth funding-and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: National and Liberal government funding-

Speaker: NA
Text: for state schools in Queensland has increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by 52 per cent, the student numbers have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by only 2.3 per cent. So we are

Speaker: NA
Text: accelerating funding faster than the students

Speaker: NA
Text: are enrolling.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Queensland we have heard much from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland Teachers Union but little

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Beattie state Labor government, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in a moment we will find out why. In 2000-

Speaker: NA
Text: 01 the Beattie Labor government increased

Speaker: NA
Text: school funding by less than one per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: which the same Queensland Teachers Union

Speaker: NA
Text: described as ‘standstill at best'. How much

Speaker: NA
Text: did they increase funding by this year? By

Speaker: NA
Text: 4.1 per cent. But surprise, surprise, where did

Speaker: NA
Text: this money go? Most of it has been chewed

Speaker: NA
Text: up by a 4.5 per cent salary increase to teach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers. So the QTU was very happy to run inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference for the Labor Party and to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: point at the Commonwealth, but when the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding finally went up from the Beattie

Speaker: NA
Text: state Labor government by 4.1 per cent, who

Speaker: NA
Text: had their hand out? Queensland teachers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not begrudge them the salary increase, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do begrudge them running a campaign to

Speaker: NA
Text: try to point the finger elsewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately, others have been awake to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The APC Review, the newsletter of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Parents Council, paints a somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: different picture to the story we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the Queensland Teachers Union. In

Speaker: NA
Text: this newsletter's May 2001 edition, they ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: press their support for increased public in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment for all school education, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: in view of the alarming decline in commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to public education by the states over

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years. The respected journalist Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Kelly, writing in the Australian newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: on 28 March 2001, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is that public schools are mainly a

Speaker: NA
Text: State responsibility. The fate of our education

Speaker: NA
Text: system lies with our Premiers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hear, hear to that! However, the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier is doing precious little. Even the

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane Courier-Mail stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland Teachers' Union should be made

Speaker: NA
Text: to write out 100 times: State education is the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility of the State Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Absolutely. The Courier-Mail of 8 August

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be congratulated. It has got it in one.

Speaker: NA
Text: It went on to state:

Speaker: NA
Text: So, if education funding in Queensland has fallen

Speaker: NA
Text: short of what the QTU thinks appropriate, the

Speaker: NA
Text: protests should be aimed at the bottom end of

Speaker: NA
Text: George Street, not Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the responsibility lies with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Beattie Labor government in Brisbane,

Speaker: NA
Text: not with the Commonwealth, which has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased its funding by 52 per cent since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996. Remember that the bulk of the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in state funding this year has been

Speaker: NA
Text: chewed up by the same QTU in salary in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases, so clearly they cannot vent their

Speaker: NA
Text: spleen at Mr Beattie or the state minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: education, Ms Bligh.

Speaker: NA
Text: So in the face of this underwhelming per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance by the Queensland state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, what is the reaction from the Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland Teachers Union? On Monday, 25 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001, they launched what they called ‘the

Speaker: NA
Text: most intense public campaign in its history'

Speaker: NA
Text: and ‘vowed to call federal politicians to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count over state school funding'. The QTU

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it will focus on what they describe

Speaker: NA
Text: as nine marginal coalition seats in Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland-namely, Petrie, Moreton, Longman,

Speaker: NA
Text: Blair, Wide Bay, Hinkler, Herbert, Leich-

Speaker: NA
Text: hardt and my own electorate of Dawson. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us see what the Courier-Mail thinks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: QTU. The same Courier-Mail article stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The QTU would be better advised to throw its

Speaker: NA
Text: weight behind reform, rather than running politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal interference for the Australian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign is not only dishonest, but also based on

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair degree of self-interest. Increased federal

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for Queensland schools would leave the

Speaker: NA
Text: way open for the QTU to seek higher salaries for

Speaker: NA
Text: its members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Precisely. We have already seen what they

Speaker: NA
Text: do when they get an increase in funding from

Speaker: NA
Text: the state. Apparently they are going to chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge us-and I refer again to federal par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liamentarians-to defend our local schools. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will very happily do that. Can I just remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the QTU that for them the three Rs, which

Speaker: NA
Text: used to stand for reading, (w)riting and

Speaker: NA
Text: (a)rithmetic, now stand for raiding, running

Speaker: NA
Text: interference and ranting. So the three Rs are

Speaker: NA
Text: alive and well but, unfortunately, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a political change of face. The QTU are

Speaker: NA
Text: raiding the increase in funding that the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government gave to schools, they are run-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning interference for the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party and they are ranting, trying to point

Speaker: NA
Text: their finger at the federal government. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly hard, though, to run such a campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: when we have increased funding to state

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in Queensland by 52 per cent since

Speaker: NA
Text: Why do the QTU support the blatant dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: crimination of the Beattie Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: against the state schools in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson? I have a question to ask them when

Speaker: NA
Text: they come to Dawson. The Beattie govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment announced a major revamp of state

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary schools-its so-called Secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: Schools Renewal Program, as far as it goes a

Speaker: NA
Text: worthy program. This was directed at

Speaker: NA
Text: schools which were built prior to 1975 and

Speaker: NA
Text: were in need of refurbishment-as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said already, a worthy idea. But there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: catch-a very big catch. When the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: announced the program and sent out the cri-

Speaker: NA
Text: teria and details to state secondary schools

Speaker: NA
Text: around Queensland, he also indicated the

Speaker: NA
Text: location of the schools which would qualify

Speaker: NA
Text: and those which would not. Those which

Speaker: NA
Text: would qualify were those that were under

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive threat from non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us just think about that for one mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. What that means is that, if you have

Speaker: NA
Text: another secondary school within bus distance

Speaker: NA
Text: or driving distance of that particular secon-

Speaker: NA
Text: Its dary state school in Queensland, then you

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify. If you do not, then you do not qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ify. In other words, if a state secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: school did not have competition, that is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: children attending the school had no choice

Speaker: NA
Text: in education and nowhere else to go, then

Speaker: NA
Text: their needs were totally ignored by the Beat-

Speaker: NA
Text: tie Labor government. The schools in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate that are on this list that will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive no renewal funding at all include the

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary school in Ayr, the secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: school in Home Hill and the state secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in Bowen, Proserpine, Mirani and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sarina. They are excluded because children

Speaker: NA
Text: there have nowhere else to go. Only in Mac-

Speaker: NA
Text: kay, where there are several private schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: were the two state schools included-and

Speaker: NA
Text: received a total of $6 million. Naturally I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see those schools receive that

Speaker: NA
Text: funding; but it is a pity that their country

Speaker: NA
Text: cousins were excluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Did we hear howls of outrage from the

Speaker: NA
Text: QTU? No, we did not. This appalling neglect

Speaker: NA
Text: of country based schools was let go through

Speaker: NA
Text: to the keeper by the QTU, without a murmur

Speaker: NA
Text: or a whimper. They are happy to see country

Speaker: NA
Text: schoolchildren in Ayr, Home Hill, Bowen,

Speaker: NA
Text: Prosperpine, Mirani and Sarina totally ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded-absolutely excluded from a program

Speaker: NA
Text: that would give them enhanced facilities:

Speaker: NA
Text: better assembly halls, new classrooms and

Speaker: NA
Text: refurbishment of old and decaying buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: built before 1975. One of my P&C presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents said to me that their school hall, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was opened in 1978 as a P&C project, is now

Speaker: NA
Text: too small to accommodate all of their stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents, so they are unable to have a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: school assembly. It is an absolute disgrace,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I reflected on when, on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, I recently opened three refurbished

Speaker: NA
Text: science buildings at the Proserpine State

Speaker: NA
Text: High School, almost entirely funded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government-the same one the QTU

Speaker: NA
Text: are continually pointing their finger at. This

Speaker: NA
Text: citycentric Secondary Schools Renewal Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram-only for schools where the children

Speaker: NA
Text: have a choice-and the citycentric QTU are

Speaker: NA
Text: a reflection of the Beattie government's atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude to country Queensland. How far do the

Speaker: NA
Text: education unions propose to go?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me share with the House some recent

Speaker: NA
Text: quotes. We should remember that the so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called wealthiest non-government school

Speaker: NA
Text: receives only some $1,100 a year per stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent; by comparison, a government school

Speaker: NA
Text: receives $8,000 a year per student. But what

Speaker: NA
Text: does the Australian Education Union want to

Speaker: NA
Text: do about funding for non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools-for small church parish schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: schools like St Joseph's, in my electorate, or

Speaker: NA
Text: like St Colman's, in Home Hill, which I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently visited, small schools that service

Speaker: NA
Text: communities where the parents struggle to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise fund for the most basic items but where

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a great deal of community pride and

Speaker: NA
Text: of dedication by the teachers? Let us hear

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Australian Education Union says

Speaker: NA
Text: about these church based schools. Its sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to the Senate inquiry into the states

Speaker: NA
Text: grants bill, in July 2000, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The AEU has long opposed any funding to pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate schools and will continue to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us hear from the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Teachers Federation. Sue Simpson was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked, during an interview on ABC Radio on

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 15 March 2001:

Speaker: NA
Text: Do you want the government to stop funding pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate schools in all shapes and forms?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Simpson replied:

Speaker: NA
Text: That is certainly the ideal position of the Teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us hear from the Australian Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Union Tasmanian President, Mike Poate. In

Speaker: NA
Text: a radio interview on 26 July 2001 he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The federal government must redistribute the

Speaker: NA
Text: money that it is currently giving to private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools into the public sector. That way we can

Speaker: NA
Text: assure the future of Australian children.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that the education unions are emi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nently unsuccessful with their deceptive

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. I ask the parents of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly those in Queensland, not to be

Speaker: NA
Text: misled. The federal National and Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: government will continue to ensure that:

Speaker: NA
Text: … government secondary schools will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: $8,172 per student in public funding. Non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools will receive $5,721 per stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent; for those students in the so-called wealthi-

Speaker: NA
Text: est schools, they will receive a mere $1,120.

Speaker: NA
Text: That does not sound to me like a terribly un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fair outcome. What it does say is that every

Speaker: NA
Text: child in Australia matters. Every child should

Speaker: NA
Text: have the best opportunity of a quality educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, whether they attend a government or

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government school. Their parents should

Speaker: NA
Text: have confidence in not only the federal and

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments but also the teachers to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that their child has the best education

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable them to both make a worthwhile

Speaker: NA
Text: career and have a satisfying adulthood. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are committed to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1996, the federal National and Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral government have increased funding to

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state schools by 52 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is an enormous amount when you con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider that student numbers have increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: only 2.3 per cent. We are also looking to

Speaker: NA
Text: those small schools, particularly in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate. I have no so-called wealthy schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do have a great number of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools where the community

Speaker: NA
Text: battles extremely hard to pay fees and to as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sist their children-as do the parents of stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents at the state schools. The divisive cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign by the education unions to draw atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from the fact that they have raided state

Speaker: NA
Text: budgets with teacher salary increases should

Speaker: NA
Text: cease. We should all be committed, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal National and Liberal government is,

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensuring a quality outcome for our stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents right across Australia.

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: Griffith) (1.49 p.m.)-Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is the heart of the knowledge nation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: States Grants (Primary and Secondary Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House is of direct relevance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge nation because it deals directly

Speaker: NA
Text: with literacy and numeracy and, without high

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of literacy and numeracy, we have no

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge nation. Regrettably, however, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is dramatically deficient in a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: ways. It is deficient in its quantum and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: deficient in its equity, but most importantly it

Speaker: NA
Text: is deficient because it exists in a policy vac-

Speaker: NA
Text: uum. It exists in a vacuum of national vision.

Speaker: NA
Text: At best, the government's approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: education policy could be described as frag-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary. There is no attempt to relate the

Speaker: NA
Text: part to the whole, as we do in the Knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation report. There is no attempt to formu-

Speaker: NA
Text: late a clear vision for the future educational

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes of the nation, as we do in Knowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge Nation. There is no attempt to link

Speaker: NA
Text: cational outcomes with future economic out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes for the nation, as we do in Knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation. Worst of all, there is no attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: defend the role of government in the overall

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery of education services. If there

Speaker: NA
Text: overriding ideological dictum on the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite when it comes to the role of

Speaker: NA
Text: government in education, that dictum is this:

Speaker: NA
Text: good government is absent government;

Speaker: NA
Text: good government is dead government. In

Speaker: NA
Text: toto, what we see in the fragments which

Speaker: NA
Text: constitute the government's overall approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to education policy is a zero response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive strategy for education for the

Speaker: NA
Text: next decade which we presented in Knowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge Nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before going to this absence of a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: framework, let us deal with the specifics of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of money in this legislation. In

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to literacy there is $36.9 million over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years from the Commonwealth of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and $10 million per annum from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth of Australia to six states and

Speaker: NA
Text: two territory education systems. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bined education budgets of the states and the

Speaker: NA
Text: territories is in excess of $15 billion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: education budget in the state of Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: alone is in excess of $3 billion. Literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy programs in my state of Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland under the Beattie government are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: order of tens of millions of dollars. Yet what

Speaker: NA
Text: we have in this enormous act of public pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy munificence on the part of the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government is a bill which provides-I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peat-$10 million per annum across all six

Speaker: NA
Text: states and two territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we look at where that fits across the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of the states, not only is it lacking in

Speaker: NA
Text: quantum; it fails to address what is already

Speaker: NA
Text: under way on the part of the states. For ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, has Dr Kemp, the education minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: heard of the year 2 and year 6 diagnostic

Speaker: NA
Text: tests in my own state of Queensland, which

Speaker: NA
Text: go to the very heart of literacy performance

Speaker: NA
Text: on the part of children in the classroom? No.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am here to inform Dr Kemp, the education

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, that that was an initiative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Goss Labor government in 1995-96 before, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think, Dr Kemp ever darkened the corridors

Speaker: NA
Text: outside his office as education minister. Has

Speaker: NA
Text: he heard of a program called Support a

Speaker: NA
Text: edu- Reader? Support a Reader is a program

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at literacy intervention in the class-

Speaker: NA
Text: room, which was again introduced into

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland education in 1995-96 under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Goss government-before the election of the

Speaker: NA
Text: is an Howard government and before Dr Kemp

Speaker: NA
Text: had anything to do with school education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Has Dr Kemp heard of a program called

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reading Recovery Program? The Read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Recovery program was again introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Queensland education system to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with children with literacy problems in pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary school, picked up through the year 2

Speaker: NA
Text: and year 6 diagnostic tests. Again, that pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram was introduced in 1995-96, well before

Speaker: NA
Text: the election of the Howard government. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you look at all these things, as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of dedicated literacy and nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy teacher aides in education in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of Queensland, you will find that they all

Speaker: NA
Text: predated by a considerable period any inno-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation of any description on the part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government or its representative in

Speaker: NA
Text: the education portfolio, Dr Kemp.

Speaker: NA
Text: The federal education minister, Dr Kemp,

Speaker: NA
Text: claims to have invented the wheel as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy programs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: schools are concerned because some years

Speaker: NA
Text: and ago he commissioned a methodologically

Speaker: NA
Text: dodgy report on literacy performance in the

Speaker: NA
Text: classroom. I would suggest that, before he

Speaker: NA
Text: takes on that report and adheres to the rheto-

Speaker: NA
Text: ric contained within it, he should practise

Speaker: NA
Text: first and foremost the elementary discipline

Speaker: NA
Text: of a historian, which is to look at what eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ryone else has been doing for a long, long

Speaker: NA
Text: time. Look at what has been happening in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland before and during the period of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government. Look at what is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in the classrooms in the other

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories in terms of literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy programs. Look at the history of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government reporting on the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of literacy. Dr Kemp's 1997 report

Speaker: NA
Text: was, he would say, the first breakthrough

Speaker: NA
Text: report on the literacy of our nation's chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren. In fact, if you look at a report prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Parliamentary Library, you will find

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is not the first report, but the 30th re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port to be prepared on literacy outcomes for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, going back to 1975.

Speaker: NA
Text: If Dr Kemp and this government have not

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly invented a concern for literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy, then perhaps the education min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isters of the states and territories would

Speaker: NA
Text: him seriously if there were significant dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: on the table, but we do not have that. I repeat

Speaker: NA
Text: the figures from before: a princely $10 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion for the states and territories combined.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is $2 million for my own state of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland alone, which runs a $3 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: education portfolio. But here is the ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: rub: this $10 million per annum, $2 million

Speaker: NA
Text: for the state of Queensland, is not even new

Speaker: NA
Text: money; it is old money, as the shadow min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for education, Michael Lee, articulated

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly in his contribution to this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: terday, and as is clearly demonstrated from

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Paper No. 2.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, that is just literacy. If we look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the other elements of education policy

Speaker: NA
Text: performance, there is the ongoing scandal of

Speaker: NA
Text: the education grants for the country at large.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have that $145 million grant to 58 cate-

Speaker: NA
Text: gory 1 schools across the country- some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing like $2 million a knock if you happen

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to the Kings School, to Wesley or to

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the first-class schools around this

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. But what happens if you happen to go

Speaker: NA
Text: to one of the Catholic systemic schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are there in large numbers in each of

Speaker: NA
Text: our electorates right across Australia? How

Speaker: NA
Text: much do they get? About $60,000 each extra.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about government schools as a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence of this grants program? They get an

Speaker: NA
Text: extra $4,000 each per government school.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is an absence of equity in what the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is doing through that program,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it does not stop there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the school establishment grants.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was an announcement by this minister

Speaker: NA
Text: of $14 million for non-government schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: which of course we do not oppose. But how

Speaker: NA
Text: many dollars have been announced for

Speaker: NA
Text: school establishment grants for government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools? Zero dollars. Yet government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools across Australia educate 70 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the nation's schoolkids. They should, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of equity alone, be delivered an

Speaker: NA
Text: extra $30 million. How much extra money

Speaker: NA
Text: have they been delivered? Zero dollars.

Speaker: NA
Text: The school education portfolio is far too

Speaker: NA
Text: important a portfolio to have loosed upon it a

Speaker: NA
Text: rampant ideologue whose ultimate view of

Speaker: NA
Text: government education is that it should disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pear. From an education perspective, what

Speaker: NA
Text: take we have in Dr Kemp, I believe, is the Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Strangelove of education. What we have in

Speaker: NA
Text: this person is someone on a mission from

Speaker: NA
Text: God, someone who believes that his ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: mission in this country is something the

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent in education of eliminating the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet communist menace. But for him what

Speaker: NA
Text: that means in the school system is something

Speaker: NA
Text: like this: the elimination ultimately of public

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and the elimination ultimately of

Speaker: NA
Text: public school teachers, and the ultimate An-

Speaker: NA
Text: tichrist of all in Dr Kemp's eschatology is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: yescourse, the Australian Education Union and

Speaker: NA
Text: every other public education union in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: But ideology does not stop with schools. It

Speaker: NA
Text: also is applied to this government's continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing cold war against the universities. Let us

Speaker: NA
Text: look for example at research training places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow minister, Michael Lee, revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier this week that this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively brought about a 13 per cent cut in

Speaker: NA
Text: research training places for this nation's uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: na- versities. As Michael Lee has said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Figures from Dr Kemp's own department show

Speaker: NA
Text: that there were 24,980 research training places in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 and Dr Kemp's press release today-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, 6 August-

Speaker: NA
Text: confirms there will only be “more than 21,600”...

Speaker: NA
Text: What does that mean?

Speaker: NA
Text: ... a decline of 3,336 places or 13%.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means there will be fewer training places for

Speaker: NA
Text: students doing PhDs in vital areas like IT, bio-

Speaker: NA
Text: technology and environmental science.

Speaker: NA
Text: These areas are the core of the Knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Kemp's attack will reduce the number of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search PhD students at Australia's seven

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘UniTech' universities-

Speaker: NA
Text: By how many places?

Speaker: NA
Text: by 1,113 places or 29%.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will also reduce the number of research training

Speaker: NA
Text: places at regional universities by 800 places or

Speaker: NA
Text: And as the shadow minister concluded:

Speaker: NA
Text: How can Australia possibly move towards being

Speaker: NA
Text: a Knowledge Nation when the Howard Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is making such savage cuts to our research

Speaker: NA
Text: capabilities?

Speaker: NA
Text: If we go through it campus by campus, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: an even more disturbing picture. If we look

Speaker: NA
Text: at, for example, the unitech universities,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are 458 fewer places at RMIT, a drop

Speaker: NA
Text: of 46.4 per cent; a removal of 1,113 places

Speaker: NA
Text: from the other unitech universities. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: own electorate, at Griffith University, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a loss of 214 places. This is a disgrace,

Speaker: NA
Text: which only this party will redress.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 2 p.m.,

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate is interrupted in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 101A. The debate may be

Speaker: NA
Text: resumed at a later hour and the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith will have leave to continue speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: when the debate is resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 2.00 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, now that the Tristar dispute is over, are

Speaker: NA
Text: you going to apologise to the Tristar workers

Speaker: NA
Text: for calling them traitors?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I notice that the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition never condemned a strike

Speaker: NA
Text: which put 12,000 people out of work. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition never said boo to

Speaker: NA
Text: the union that caused 12,000 workers to be

Speaker: NA
Text: out of work. The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: never condemned the Manusafe scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: which amounts to a 19 per cent levy on pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll-

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Mr Speaker, I raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order on relevance. It was a simple, well

Speaker: NA
Text: focused question. Is he going to apologise

Speaker: NA
Text: for calling those workers-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position will resume his seat. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked a question relative to the Tristar

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute and his answer was relative to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tristar dispute.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: At every step of this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess, the Leader of the Opposition has stood

Speaker: NA
Text: shoulder to shoulder with the ultra-militants

Speaker: NA
Text: who have threatened the future of the motor

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. It is the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: who should be apologising to all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 12,000 workers stood down as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial action that he completely sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy: OECD Report

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Text: 2.02 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is addressed to the Treasurer. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer advise the House of the key find-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings of the latest OECD report on the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy, released overnight?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Macquarie for his question.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can report to the House that overnight the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD released its economic survey on

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, forecasting growth picking up in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2002 to 3.8 per cent and noting that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: would be one of the fastest growing econo-

Speaker: NA
Text: mies in the developed world next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the United States economy

Speaker: NA
Text: has slowed very considerably, the Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: economy is now in recession, Singapore is in

Speaker: NA
Text: recession, Taiwan and most of South-East

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia have had negative quarters and Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: is slowing. This is making world growth

Speaker: NA
Text: very uncertain and weaker than it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: probably for over a decade. But the good

Speaker: NA
Text: news is that, notwithstanding the weakness

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world economy, the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy has held up very strongly and the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy is now considered to be one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the strongest growing economies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: developed world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The OECD report also made a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: findings as to what contributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening of the Australian economy. It

Speaker: NA
Text: found, for example, that the recent tax re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form would contribute a further improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in economic performance, a broader

Speaker: NA
Text: and more efficient tax base reinforcing the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits of fiscal consolidation. A narrower

Speaker: NA
Text: and less efficient tax base, the kind of tax

Speaker: NA
Text: base that roll-back is designed to give us,

Speaker: NA
Text: would of course undermine fiscal consolida-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The Labor Party would take us right

Speaker: NA
Text: back to where they had us: $10 billion worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of debt, an $80 billion build-up of debt over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last five years and $23 billion worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: build-up of debt under the worst finance

Speaker: NA
Text: minister in Australian history. The OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: also said that major economic benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: should accrue from the comprehensive tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reform, the first major step of which came

Speaker: NA
Text: into effect on 1 July 2000.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Australian economy strengthens

Speaker: NA
Text: over the course of 2002, we would expect

Speaker: NA
Text: growing job opportunities for Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment is a lagging indicator: as your

Speaker: NA
Text: economy strengthens, you would expect,

Speaker: NA
Text: after some months, jobs growth to

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen. We expect jobs growth to

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen in 2002.

Speaker: NA
Text: The OECD report is a report on the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which good economic policy can bring re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sults. I make this point: it would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: happened just by accident. It would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: happened that Australia's exports would

Speaker: NA
Text: boom without taking taxes off exports; it

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have happened that we would

Speaker: NA
Text: have had low interest rates if we had not put

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget back into surplus; it would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have happened that we would have low

Speaker: NA
Text: home mortgage variable interest rates if we

Speaker: NA
Text: had not repaid $60 billion of Labor's $80

Speaker: NA
Text: billion worth of debt. This report shows

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the benefits from economic policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the message is that good economic man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement must continue. It is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: we keep good budget and good tax policy

Speaker: NA
Text: and, most importantly, that we do not roll

Speaker: NA
Text: backwards on all of the good work that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done in the Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment and Unemployment:

Speaker: NA
Text: Statistics

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: 2.06 p.m.)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer and it follows his earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: answer. Treasurer, how can you claim it is

Speaker: NA
Text: good news when you have just presided over

Speaker: NA
Text: the biggest recorded monthly fall in full-time

Speaker: NA
Text: employment ever: a fall of 79,200 jobs last

Speaker: NA
Text: month? What do you say to the 160,000

Speaker: NA
Text: workers who have lost their full-time jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: since your GST came in last July? What do

Speaker: NA
Text: you say to the hundreds of small business

Speaker: NA
Text: people being forced to the wall because of

Speaker: NA
Text: your job destroying GST? Treasurer, if eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ryone has never had it so good, why are so

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australians and their families missing

Speaker: NA
Text: out?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: If the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: really believed the GST was the author of

Speaker: NA
Text: such havoc on the Australian economy, they

Speaker: NA
Text: would have pledged to repeal it. I have never

Speaker: NA
Text: really understood this point that, on the one

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, the Labor Party would have you be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that the GST has caused havoc in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fastest growing economy in the world, most

Speaker: NA
Text: probably caused an outbreak of foot-and-

Speaker: NA
Text: mouth disease in the United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: most probably is responsible for Mount Etna

Speaker: NA
Text: erupting, but, if they ever get elected to of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice, what do they want to do? They want to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep it. Every time you ask them about the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of roll-backwards and say, ‘GST

Speaker: NA
Text: raises $24 billion. Will you commit yourself

Speaker: NA
Text: to rolling backwards 50 per cent, or $12 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion?' they say, ‘No, it's not $12 billion.' If

Speaker: NA
Text: we say, ‘Will you commit to rolling back-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards one-third of the way?' they say, ‘No,

Speaker: NA
Text: we wouldn't commit to that.' Roll-

Speaker: NA
Text: backwards-the policy which dare not speak

Speaker: NA
Text: its name-disappears by the minute. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: half-world of shadow and fantasy that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition exists in,

Speaker: NA
Text: roll-backwards is the policy that is required

Speaker: NA
Text: but can never actually be revealed.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the labour force, let us put

Speaker: NA
Text: some facts on the table. The Australian un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment rate is currently at 6.9 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: down from its peak of 10.9 per cent in De-

Speaker: NA
Text: cember 1992, when the employment minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was the now Leader of the Opposition. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of the five years since this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment was elected in March 1996, there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been a net new 805,000 jobs created in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy. Youth unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has come down from the all-time high

Speaker: NA
Text: of 34.5 per cent in July 1992, when Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley was the employment minister, to a

Speaker: NA
Text: rate now of 24 per cent. As I said, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: made some substantial progress in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. We have undone a lot of La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor's damage. But have we finished? No, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course there is more work to be done in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: What do we have to do? We need a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, and the Australian economy is

Speaker: NA
Text: holding up well compared with all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economies of the developed world. More

Speaker: NA
Text: than that, we need labour market reform,

Speaker: NA
Text: because nothing would be better to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: down structural unemployment than labour

Speaker: NA
Text: market reform. I pay tribute to the work that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done, but more labour market re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form needs to be done. The third thing I say

Speaker: NA
Text: is this: if you were really interested in people

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining their jobs in Australia, would

Speaker: NA
Text: you support the irresponsible union action

Speaker: NA
Text: that put 10,000 people out of work last

Speaker: NA
Text: week? The one thing we never heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party was a condemnation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: strike that threw 10,000 fellow Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: out of work. The Manufacturing Workers

Speaker: NA
Text: Union, affiliated to the ACTU, threw 10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians out of work last week, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: old ACTU president could not bring himself

Speaker: NA
Text: to condemn it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor Party, if they get elected at the

Speaker: NA
Text: next election, will have three living former

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTU presidents on their front bench and a

Speaker: NA
Text: few dead ex-ACTU presidents sitting on

Speaker: NA
Text: their front bench, too. Who would ever be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that they could take a strong stand on

Speaker: NA
Text: labour market reform? Who would ever be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that they could support the kind of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form that is necessary to create real jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: real people in this country?

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade: Export Performance

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Text: ANNE KELLY (2.11 p.m.)-My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is addressed to the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Minister for Transport and Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional Services. Would the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister outline the contribution made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians in rural and regional areas to the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's economic growth as reflected in the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD annual review of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dawson for her question

Speaker: NA
Text: and acknowledge that that electorate, like so

Speaker: NA
Text: many others in rural and regional Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: contributes massively to our export perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. Indeed, rural and regional exports re-

Speaker: NA
Text: main-increasingly, it can be said-huge

Speaker: NA
Text: engines for economic growth in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the partnership be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the government and rural industries

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last 5½ years is starting to bear very

Speaker: NA
Text: real fruit. We are now, for the first time that

Speaker: NA
Text: can remember in my adult life, all of which

Speaker: NA
Text: time I have been involved with rural Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, seeing an improvement in the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: trade for the nation's farmers virtually right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the board. That is to say, prices and

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes are rising faster than costs. That

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot happen without sound economic

Speaker: NA
Text: management.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the great export industries of rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional Australia-farming, mining,

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism and the manufacturing industries that

Speaker: NA
Text: spin off them, because the biggest employer

Speaker: NA
Text: of the lot in the manufacturing industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is the food and fibre processing

Speaker: NA
Text: sector-are all enjoying much improved

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects. Farm exports alone this year will

Speaker: NA
Text: be worth almost $30 billion, up 21 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: on last year, constituting around 20 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of all of our exports. Higher prices-and this

Speaker: NA
Text: is an interesting point to those with an inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est in trade, including the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade-mean that more will be produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what the nation's farmers will do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher beef prices, higher grain prices and

Speaker: NA
Text: higher wool prices will result in more beef,

Speaker: NA
Text: more grain and more wool. Not only will that

Speaker: NA
Text: produce more exports; it will produce a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: more manufacturing jobs, as that product is

Speaker: NA
Text: value added, and exports. Minerals and oil

Speaker: NA
Text: exports add another $40 billion to our na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's export earnings. Even international

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors to rural and regional Australia earn

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation around $2.5 billion a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people responsible for all of this have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown great resilience and great courage.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have battled all of the seasonal irregu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larities that we know are a feature of living

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country, but it is not so very long ago

Speaker: NA
Text: that they were also suffering under the yoke

Speaker: NA
Text: of the most monstrously damaging economic

Speaker: NA
Text: parameters of any of the farmers in the West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern world, with interest rates through the

Speaker: NA
Text: roof-two and three times what their com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitors in other countries were paying.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every year a farmer had to add 12 or 13 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent farm inflation to his budgets for the

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It is a wonder, really, that the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: sector survived at all, but it did. It took the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 5½ years of partnership, when we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been prepared to put the economic house in

Speaker: NA
Text: order and to fight the issues that had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: tackled, for that to happen. We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: I prepared to tackle tax reform: $3 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: indirect taxes are no longer shackling our

Speaker: NA
Text: export industries. We have world-class tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: communications, so that you can export your

Speaker: NA
Text: organic beef out of Birdsville directly to Ja-

Speaker: NA
Text: pan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government have the vision to take on

Speaker: NA
Text: such projects as the Alice to Darwin railway

Speaker: NA
Text: and to ensure that AMC gets off the ground

Speaker: NA
Text: in Central Queensland as we become a world

Speaker: NA
Text: leader in light metals. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: worked with industries such as the pork in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry through great difficulties to see it

Speaker: NA
Text: ceed in export markets, when every cheap-

Speaker: NA
Text: jack political opportunist in the nation-par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly those opposite- was running

Speaker: NA
Text: around saying that we ought to resort to

Speaker: NA
Text: protectionism. We did the hard yards. We

Speaker: NA
Text: held a course on reform. The pork industry

Speaker: NA
Text: today is in the best shape it has been in for

Speaker: NA
Text: decades, with a very strong future based on

Speaker: NA
Text: exports, particularly into Asia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These investments we have made are

Speaker: NA
Text: showing dividends in the very strong growth

Speaker: NA
Text: figures put forward by the OECD. Rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional Australia is right up there making its

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution. What do we find from the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position-those who ought to be responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for putting forward a policy position to this

Speaker: NA
Text: vitally important part of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community? Do we find criticism or objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive remarks about the government's poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies? No. Worse than that, do we find any

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas at all from the opposition? No. When

Speaker: NA
Text: given an opportunity-a free kick-my op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position spokesman was not even prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to an invitation to speak to a jour-

Speaker: NA
Text: nalist about an article on reform in rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional Australia. I think that says it all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employee Entitlements Support Scheme

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 2.16 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, do you recall releasing a paper in January

Speaker: NA
Text: this year entitled The protection of employee

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements on employer insolvency, which

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that your employee entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme is a mere safety net? It concluded:

Speaker: NA
Text: This does not preclude the adoption of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: measures by particularly employers and employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ees. Such an approach would place the obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: directly on the employer concerned and could

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver 100 per cent of what is owed to the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, isn't this exactly what the workers

Speaker: NA
Text: at Tristar did? I ask you again: will you

Speaker: NA
Text: apologise to the Tristar workers for calling

Speaker: NA
Text: them traitors, when all they did was to follow

Speaker: NA
Text: your prescription by legally bargaining at the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace to secure their legal entitlements?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position is now entering into argument.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I will never apologise for

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to end strikes, because strikes cost

Speaker: NA
Text: suc- jobs. This government is in the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: ending strikes and opposing strikes, not sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting them or fanning them like the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition do. Workers at Tristar have now had

Speaker: NA
Text: their entitlements protected. They have had

Speaker: NA
Text: their entitlements protected because the

Speaker: NA
Text: company offered them an insurance policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: What the company did not do, would not do

Speaker: NA
Text: and will not do is support the Manusafe

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme-the scheme that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition supports, the scheme the opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion supports and the scheme which will ul-

Speaker: NA
Text: timately add 19 per cent to payroll costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: cost hundreds of thousands of jobs across the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation: Government Policy

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-My question is to the Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Would the Treasurer advise the House if he

Speaker: NA
Text: is aware of any policy proposals to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax burden on Australians?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for his question. Some infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation has come to my attention that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are people in Australia advocating higher

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: You've been reading the

Speaker: NA
Text: papers again.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: No, I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: watching TV. Everybody would know, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the ABC would know, that I am an

Speaker: NA
Text: avid watcher of the 7.30 Report. Last night

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a story regarding school funding

Speaker: NA
Text: which reported that, while the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment maintains that some states, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are primarily responsible for public school

Speaker: NA
Text: funding, are failing, five Labor ministers are

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing to convince voters otherwise. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have set up a task force to demonstrate that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth should pitch in more and

Speaker: NA
Text: are considering mounting an advertising

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. One proposal for raising extra

Speaker: NA
Text: money for public schools is an education

Speaker: NA
Text: levy similar to the Medicare levy. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: from five Labor ministers. The 7.30 Report

Speaker: NA
Text: went to Professor Simon Marginson. Profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sor Simon Marginson is the author of that

Speaker: NA
Text: much vaunted document that was released at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney Institute, formerly known as

Speaker: NA
Text: Knowledge Nation but now known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: noodle nation. Simon Marginson said this on

Speaker: NA
Text: the 7.30 Report:

Speaker: NA
Text: I suspect there's probably sufficient community

Speaker: NA
Text: support for that-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, the education levy

Speaker: NA
Text: because people do want to pay more taxes if they

Speaker: NA
Text: know it's going to go to education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Marginson costed Knowledge Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at $12 billion per annum. He was the

Speaker: NA
Text: author of the report that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition relied on when he was still talk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about knowledge nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean interjecting-

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: The Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition interjects. He says, ‘Where

Speaker: NA
Text: does he sit on that side?' Let me ask him:

Speaker: NA
Text: where does the member for Lyons sit on that

Speaker: NA
Text: side? According to the AAP report this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning, on his way into the parliament-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: You can always tell

Speaker: NA
Text: when they interject the loudest, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are showing great excitement at the

Speaker: NA
Text: quote which is about to come. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the AAP report, the member for Lyons told

Speaker: NA
Text: reporters on his way into parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: Levies for one thing or another (are) being touted

Speaker: NA
Text: around ... I think it's because in Australia we've

Speaker: NA
Text: got into low-taxing regime.

Speaker: NA
Text: People on this side would probably agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have got into a low taxing regime-

Speaker: NA
Text: and we remember that the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: fought us every single step of the way as we

Speaker: NA
Text: went into it. The member for Lyons went on

Speaker: NA
Text: to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: I think people are looking for higher revenues.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are starting to realise that services can

Speaker: NA
Text: only be provided by having a tax regime that can

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for those services ... and whether that's an

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental levy, or whether it's a levy for

Speaker: NA
Text: education, or whether it's a levy to send troops

Speaker: NA
Text: East Timor, it's one way of us funding our future

Speaker: NA
Text: services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us make it clear: a levy on incomes is

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing income taxes. The Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business has just been up to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a little chat with him. He probably went up

Speaker: NA
Text: to pull a lever, so that his chair would open

Speaker: NA
Text: up and he would disappear into the floor.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Treasurer will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turn to the question.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Don't you sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: wish that the ground would just open up and

Speaker: NA
Text: you could fall through-the member for Ly-

Speaker: NA
Text: ons does. So the member for Lyons is into

Speaker: NA
Text: higher income taxes; Professor Simon Mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginson is into higher income taxes; five La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor ministers are into higher income taxes;

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Fremantle is into education

Speaker: NA
Text: bonds; and the Leader of the Opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: into mezzanine finance-noodle finance for

Speaker: NA
Text: the noodle nation. So we are going to have

Speaker: NA
Text: some noodle finance now. All of this is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of an opposition which says it is go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to roll backwards on GST, it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend more money and it is going to have

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger surpluses. It is going to spend more, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to tax less and it is going to have

Speaker: NA
Text: more left over at the end of the day. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: didn't we think of that? You tax less, you

Speaker: NA
Text: spend more and you have more at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the day-in 5½ years they have come up

Speaker: NA
Text: with a genius of an idea!

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 2.25 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, will you apologise to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community for your provocative behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: this week in seeking to prolong the Tristar

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute with your inflammatory comments

Speaker: NA
Text: and actions?

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position has the call and will be heard in si-

Speaker: NA
Text: lence.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Minister, is it not the

Speaker: NA
Text: case that, if the employer had followed your

Speaker: NA
Text: advice to not compromise, the dispute at

Speaker: NA
Text: to Tristar would still be running, throwing

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands more people out of work? Instead

Speaker: NA
Text: of being an industrial arsonist, why won't

Speaker: NA
Text: you act as a responsible minister and seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: settle industrial disputes, not inflame them,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to achieve fair outcomes for all parties,

Speaker: NA
Text: not just one side?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ross Cameron- Mr Speaker, I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: on a point of order. On page 511 of House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Practice it says that the

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of standing order 144 is to attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: restrain the questioner from giving unneces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary information or introducing or inviting

Speaker: NA
Text: argument and thereby initiating a debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Besides the hypothetical dimension to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question, there was not even the pretence of

Speaker: NA
Text: avoiding argument. The question is an invi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation to debate and should be ruled out of

Speaker: NA
Text: order.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I could be tempted to

Speaker: NA
Text: rule the question out of order if I were

Speaker: NA
Text: dictive Speaker concerned about the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: I could not be heard above those who chose

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue interjecting. The question con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains more argument than is desirable. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition is aware of that. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow the question to stand.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Tristar did not compro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mise. They opposed Manusafe at the begin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning and they opposed Manusafe at the end.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tristar offered an insurance bond to their

Speaker: NA
Text: workers a week before this strike finished

Speaker: NA
Text: and it was completely rejected by the Metal

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Union, with the full support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, because they were

Speaker: NA
Text: pursuing political objectives, not industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives. Let me also remind members op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite that this government sought to inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: vene before the commission in support of a

Speaker: NA
Text: return to work application. We supported a

Speaker: NA
Text: return to work application. I did not see any

Speaker: NA
Text: support for a return to work application from

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade: OECD Report

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Text: 2.29 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Would

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister inform the House of the impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for Australia's trade performance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the OECD forecasts? What part did exports

Speaker: NA
Text: play in the good OECD predictions? Are

Speaker: NA
Text: there any threats to achieving this positive

Speaker: NA
Text: trading future?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker for his question and his interest. The

Speaker: NA
Text: economic survey on Australia's performance

Speaker: NA
Text: and projection for the future that has been

Speaker: NA
