Text: released by the OECD is quite outstanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, there has been a significant con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution from Australia's exporting indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries in that performance. This document is a

Speaker: NA
Text: pur- glowing endorsement of Australia's eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic performance. I believe it is a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation why Australians should not

Speaker: NA
Text: elect a Labor government at the end of this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. All the indicators in this document rein-

Speaker: NA
Text: force the importance of the policy settings

Speaker: NA
Text: that our government has put in place since

Speaker: NA
Text: we came to office in 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to the government coming to office

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1996, we earned about $99 billion from

Speaker: NA
Text: our exports. This year, we are on track to

Speaker: NA
Text: a vinearn $153 billion from exports-a 54 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent increase. That is the significant contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution that exports have made to that growth

Speaker: NA
Text: in our economy during that period. Also, the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD report indicates that the economy is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to grow between 3.5 and four per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2002, which is described by the OECD as

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable in the face of slowing world

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. All that is built on a number of indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cators that were highlighted in the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the key findings in the report were

Speaker: NA
Text: that company profitability is strong and cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porate balance sheets are in good shape.

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP growth is projected to pick up to 3.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent to four per cent. There have been no

Speaker: NA
Text: major second-round inflation effects from

Speaker: NA
Text: GST. The 2001-02 Commonwealth budget

Speaker: NA
Text: remains focused on preserving the significant

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidation gains achieved in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The underlying budget position is sound, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth net debt has fallen sharply,

Speaker: NA
Text: surpassing the government's target to halve

Speaker: NA
Text: the ratio from its 1995-96 level, and major

Speaker: NA
Text: economic benefits should accrue from the

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive tax reforms that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the more interesting statistics in

Speaker: NA
Text: the document is a graph of the differential

Speaker: NA
Text: between interest rates in Australia and one of

Speaker: NA
Text: our major trading partners, the US. It indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cates that the difference between Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: and US interest rates is now less than half of

Speaker: NA
Text: one per cent. Under Labor, Australians were

Speaker: NA
Text: paying more than three per cent more than

Speaker: NA
Text: Americans. That was the result of Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: lazy policies of that time. The graph indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cates how the competitive nature of our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy has significantly improved under

Speaker: NA
Text: the reform regimes that we have introduced,

Speaker: NA
Text: with tax reform, industrial relations reform,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the removal of $3½ billion of taxes off

Speaker: NA
Text: the back of our exports to achieve that $153

Speaker: NA
Text: billion figure. What are the risks? The

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD says that Australia should continue

Speaker: NA
Text: with this positive outlook for the economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: provided there are no major economic im-

Speaker: NA
Text: balances. We should ask ourselves: what

Speaker: NA
Text: could those imbalances be?

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen a number of comments re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently, as has been outlined in the media and

Speaker: NA
Text: here in the House. Labor believes, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition believes, that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians do not pay too much tax. Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to raise taxes to pay for all the

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley-Crean promises. Now we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: the Democrats saying that taxes are not too

Speaker: NA
Text: high and that they would block any proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate for tax cuts. The Democrats

Speaker: NA
Text: have given a green light to the Labor Party to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase taxes. If the Labor Party is elected at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of this year, there will be no opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the Senate regarding increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes that we have worked so hard to remove

Speaker: NA
Text: from the backs of Australian exporters. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will put back on again the $3½ million worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of tax cuts off exporters if a Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are elected at the end of this year. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, the OECD has said that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: should continue with its positive outlook for

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy, provided there are no major

Speaker: NA
Text: economic imbalances. The only economic

Speaker: NA
Text: imbalance on the horizon in Australia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley-Crean imbalance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 2.33 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, will you confirm that at a press confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence yesterday you were asked whether you

Speaker: NA
Text: were pleased the Tristar dispute was over,

Speaker: NA
Text: and you responded, ‘Can I go off the rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ord?' Was that because you were simply ig-

Speaker: NA
Text: norant and ill prepared, or did you really

Speaker: NA
Text: want to tell the media off the record that you

Speaker: NA
Text: were an industrial arsonist and you wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: the dispute to continue, whatever it took?

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: If I were to rule a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion out of order, it would not have been the

Speaker: NA
Text: preceding question but the question just

Speaker: NA
Text: asked, on the basis of imputation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Text: 2.34 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice is to the Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment, Workplace Relations and Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business. Minister, could you report on the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome of the Tristar dispute and the motor

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, and is further disputation likely?

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the government's attitude to this and

Speaker: NA
Text: are there any alternative policies that you are

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of in this area?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean-So they can impute the alter-

Speaker: NA
Text: natives.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: If the Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition wishes to take a point of or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der, I will hear him, otherwise he will exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise some restraint.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean-I will take a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker. You have just ruled out a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion asked by the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: because you said it imputed things. Doesn't

Speaker: NA
Text: the tail end of that question, which is at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tached every time they ask a dorothy dixer in

Speaker: NA
Text: this house, impute intention to us, and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: variably it is deceitful and a lie?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition will resume his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I remind the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Batman that I have not in fact given any

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: When the House has

Speaker: NA
Text: come to order. Member for Reid!

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I believe that was the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Sturt. His interjection has been

Speaker: NA
Text: noted. I call the member for La Trobe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Charles-Thank you Mr Speaker. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would have thought that it was more than

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant for the member for La Trobe to

Speaker: NA
Text: question whether there are other policies-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe will resume his seat. I presumed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for La Trobe had a point of or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has asked why it is that I have ruled one

Speaker: NA
Text: question out of order on the basis of imputa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and not another. The question asked by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition made an unjus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tifiable imputation of the motives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment, Workplace Rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and Small Business. The question

Speaker: NA
Text: asked by the member for La Trobe did not in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact impute any unjustifiable motives to any

Speaker: NA
Text: individual. The question is in order.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Just so that I can satisfy

Speaker: the Leader of the Opposition, Mr SPEAKER
Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position's question has been ruled out of or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der. The question which stands is the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from the member for La Trobe.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: And I am answering it,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker. Let me make it very clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tristar strike, from the beginning, was

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by the opposition. From the be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning it was opposed by this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan- Mr Speaker, on a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order: the standing orders and House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Practice give you responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for maintaining order in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: How can you expect this House to be in or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der when you rule out the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position's question and allow the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment, Workplace Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business to continue to tell lies about

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition? It will not suffice!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Manager of Opposition Business is well

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that the occupier of the chair is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: strained by the standing orders. As an occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pier of the chair, in common, I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought, with all the other occupiers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair and members of the Speaker's Panel, I

Speaker: NA
Text: bristle every time I hear the words, ‘It's a

Speaker: NA
Text: lie.' I hear it as frequently from my left

Speaker: NA
Text: do from my right. Under the standing orders,

Speaker: NA
Text: the accusation of lies levelled at any individa

Speaker: NA
Text: ual is out of order. The generalised accusa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is highly undesirable and calls for my

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention, but the standing orders do not

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for it. However, there is a provision

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain a particular dignity in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: which I believe is eroded by that sort of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tervention. I do not believe that it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that should be made by those on my

Speaker: NA
Text: left or by the minister in response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question on my right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kernot-Couldn't he just tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dickson is not in any sense facilitating the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate or, I would have thought, assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of the Manager of Opposition Business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan-May I make a represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation to you, Mr Speaker, on the point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order that I raised before? I was not asking

Speaker: NA
Text: you to go outside the point of order or prece-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents. You have a standard responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: under the standing orders and House of Rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives Practice, in general beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: specific standing orders, to maintain order in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place. This minister is continually highly

Speaker: NA
Text: provocative and he does tell monstrous un-

Speaker: NA
Text: truths consistently, persistently and regularly,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he has done so today. In the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances in which you ruled out what we con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered to be a perfectly legitimate question

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Leader of the Opposition, you cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: expect the normal order to prevail when you

Speaker: NA
Text: allow this minister to continue to behave as

Speaker: NA
Text: he does, and as he has.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Let me rise to make it

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly clear that my ruling on the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition's question was consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the standing orders and in fact it did

Speaker: NA
Text: have an imputation that no occupier of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair would have tolerated; that I do not ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate anyone at the dispatch box deliber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately being deceitful; that I will not tolerate

Speaker: NA
Text: accusations of lying being levelled at any

Speaker: NA
Text: individual; that I believe the dignity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is enhanced if everyone raises the

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of their language; and that I also

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that on both my left and my right I

Speaker: NA
Text: as I have people-147 of them-who want the

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of the parliament raised and who, as

Speaker: NA
Text: rule of thumb, cooperate in making that

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. In fact, I am proud to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker of the House and I believe that there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a great deal more tolerance exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cised in the House than on some occasions

Speaker: NA
Text: when I have been in the place over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 years. The Minister for Employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: com- Workplace Relations and Small Business has

Speaker: NA
Text: the call. The matter has been dealt with and I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the minister to exercise appropriate con-

Speaker: NA
Text: straint.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Thank you, Mr Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the Meet the Press program last Sunday,

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul Bongiorno asked a question about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tristar strike. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of jobs are at stake there. Do you support

Speaker: NA
Text: the strike?

Speaker: NA
Text: And the answer was, ‘Well, I do.' And that

Speaker: NA
Text: was from the shadow minister for employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the member for Dickson.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kernot-Read the rest.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I will read the rest, ‘Well,

Speaker: NA
Text: I do support the strike.' That is what she said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me quote her exactly. She said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, I do, in that workers have a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: right to pursue their legal entitlements.

Speaker: NA
Text: You support the strike. It is as simple as that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: the call.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: It is as simple as that, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. Labor supports strikes and this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment opposes them. That is the simple

Speaker: NA
Text: truth. Labor supports strikes and this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment tries to end them. This government

Speaker: NA
Text: is extremely pleased that this particular strike

Speaker: NA
Text: is over. It was a strike against the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. It was a strike that was costing

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden alone $120 million in lost sales, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it was putting 12,000 decent Australians out

Speaker: NA
Text: of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government had two objectives in

Speaker: NA
Text: this dispute. Its first objective was to get

Speaker: NA
Text: people back to work and its second objective

Speaker: NA
Text: was to stop industry-wide pattern bargaining

Speaker: NA
Text: in support of the dangerous Manusafe pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal. As a result, in part, of this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's work, the people at Tristar are back at

Speaker: NA
Text: work. Their entitlements are protected, but

Speaker: NA
Text: not by the union controlled, job destroying

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe fund. Unfortunately, the AMWU

Speaker: NA
Text: has not given up its Manusafe campaign. It

Speaker: NA
Text: still wants to force businesses to pay up to 19

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of payroll into a union controlled

Speaker: NA
Text: fund to protect so-called entitlements which

Speaker: NA
Text: may never crystallise. This union, the

Speaker: NA
Text: AMWU, has threatened further industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: action against 600 businesses, large and

Speaker: NA
Text: small, across our economy, and that indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial action will have the full support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition never con-

Speaker: NA
Text: demned the Tristar strike. He never opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe and he never provided leadership.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported the strike; the member for Dickson

Speaker: NA
Text: supported the strike; they all supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: AMWU. They have got to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: AMWU because the unions and the party are

Speaker: NA
Text: all part of the same ACTU-Labor Inc. politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal-industrial complex, designed to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the unions, by the unions, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan-I rise under standing or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der 52, Mr Speaker. It is important for you to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain order in this place, and this minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has provocatively and deliberately misled the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament about the attitudes of various

Speaker: NA
Text: members. We know that he is in possession

Speaker: NA
Text: of the facts, because he quoted from a tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: script in which at least one of our shadow

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe, and he has never ever acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edged that. He is consistently and deliber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately misleading the House.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Manager of Opposition Business did not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a valid point of order under standing

Speaker: NA
Text: order 52. Has the minister concluded his an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Members opposite al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways support the AMWU. They cannot af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ford not to support the AMWU. In the last

Speaker: NA
Text: year for which figures are available, the

Speaker: NA
Text: AMWU gave them $680,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order that you believe you have finalised.

Speaker: NA
Text: This highlights the inconsistency of your

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling on the leader versus the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: La Trobe. The tag from the member for La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe clearly gives the hook. If you do not

Speaker: NA
Text: interpret it to be an imputation on us, the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister uses it as licence to impute lies on

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition that cannot be sustained.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition will resume his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean-I have not finished the point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have required that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition resume his

Speaker: NA
Text: seat. I remind the Deputy Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position and any who may care to listen that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a number of standing orders that

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to questions and I have endeavoured,

Speaker: NA
Text: as have my predecessors, to impartially ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ply those standing orders. There is one

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order that applies to answers-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, that the answer must be relevant to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question. I have maintained the standing or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ders consistent with all previous occupiers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the chair. If the minister has not concluded

Speaker: NA
Text: his answer, will he bring his answer rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: to a conclusion.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Members opposite have

Speaker: NA
Text: to support the AMWU because the AMWU

Speaker: NA
Text: has the largest single bloc vote inside the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan-I rise on a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker. By what manner is that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment relevant to the question?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The question asked was

Speaker: NA
Text: about Tristar, the motor industry and support

Speaker: NA
Text: or otherwise of the strike. I do believe the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister has in fact overstated the case that

Speaker: NA
Text: he was raising, but I cannot rule his answer

Speaker: NA
Text: other than relevant to the question. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: asked the minister to bring his answer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, but there is no way that in fact he

Speaker: NA
Text: could be deemed to have drawn it out with

Speaker: NA
Text: what was a very brief response before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: In any choice between

Speaker: NA
Text: the union interest and the national interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition can be relied

Speaker: NA
Text: upon to take the union interest. In any indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial conflict, the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will always stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'Keefe- Mr Speaker, I take a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. In taking my point of order, I take

Speaker: NA
Text: the lead from the comment you just made. In

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Burke

Speaker: NA
Text: will resume his seat. The minister is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding his answer.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere in this country, the Leader of the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 2.51 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Will

Speaker: NA
Text: you confirm that the deal negotiated between

Speaker: NA
Text: Tristar and its workers requires the employer

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay 1.5 per cent of their payroll for an

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance bond costing $1.4 million? Isn't it

Speaker: NA
Text: also a fact that, under Labor's employee en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titlements scheme, employers will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to pay just an additional 0.1 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: on their superannuation contributions, which

Speaker: NA
Text: would have cost just $23,000? Minister, why

Speaker: NA
Text: are you forcing employers to suffer industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: disputes and to pay more under your formula

Speaker: NA
Text: when, under our plan, the scheme will be

Speaker: NA
Text: legislated and employers will pay substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tially less?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I have no reason to doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition's statement that

Speaker: NA
Text: the company is in fact paying 1.5 per cent for

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance bond. But Manusafe, the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme that this strike was over-

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Mr Speaker, I raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order which goes to relevance very di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly. The contrast here was with the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme that we in fact support, which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe. The scheme that we support is

Speaker: NA
Text: ours. And it is $23,000 versus $1.4 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: He immediately started on an irrelevant

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in his answer.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position will resume his seat. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: had been on his feet for 21 seconds. I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: This dispute was about

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe, and Manusafe requires up to 19

Speaker: NA
Text: sit per cent of payroll. That is what the company

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected and that is what they were right to

Speaker: NA
Text: reject.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wool Industry: Stockpile

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: 2.53 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: and Forestry. I ask the minister: would he

Speaker: NA
Text: update the House on the final disposal of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's wool stockpile? Has the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment moved quickly to refund more of

Speaker: NA
Text: growers' equity?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: I am delighted to report to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that, at long last, the bottom of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's wool stockpile is in sight.

Speaker: NA
Text: it goes, the memories of another Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: failure will finally be erased for the farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. There are fewer than 2,000

Speaker: NA
Text: bales of wool left in the stockpile as we

Speaker: NA
Text: speak, and that is expected to be sold over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next few days. As a result, I introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to the House today to wind up

Speaker: NA
Text: early Woolstock Australia, the body that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been charged with managing the wool stock-

Speaker: NA
Text: pile, and so the funds can be quickly returned

Speaker: NA
Text: to those growers who have endured the pain

Speaker: NA
Text: of the interest charges and the depressed

Speaker: NA
Text: market over a long period of time. It will be

Speaker: NA
Text: a historic day when the last of the 4.7 million Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: bales from the stockpile is finally disposed

Speaker: NA
Text: of. A debt of $2.8 billion has already been

Speaker: NA
Text: fully repaid and, at last, there are some re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turns going to the wool growers.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was an extraordinary period of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian history, a legacy of remarkable policy

Speaker: NA
Text: failure by Labor when in government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of the wool debacle can be traced

Speaker: NA
Text: back to some inappropriate comments by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor agriculture minister of the day who

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyed confidence in the wool market,

Speaker: NA
Text: which immediately resulted in a depressed

Speaker: NA
Text: market and began a disastrous decade for the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool producers of Australia. As this stock-

Speaker: NA
Text: pile rolls out the door we wipe out a memory

Speaker: NA
Text: yet again of Labor's disastrous term in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate Woolstock and Don

Speaker: NA
Text: MCGauchie, his board and staff for the

Speaker: NA
Text: prompt and efficient way in which they have

Speaker: NA
Text: cleaned up this Labor Party mess. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken us six years to get rid of what Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyed over their 13 years. Wool can be

Speaker: NA
Text: traded fairly and freely in the marketplace

Speaker: NA
Text: for the first time in decades. The trading will

Speaker: NA
Text: be done without being depressed by the mas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive stockpile, which has certainly overlaid

Speaker: NA
Text: every sale and trade for more than a decade.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a new beginning for the wool industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity for that industry to take ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage of the improved market situation

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia. What they most certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want, which would undermine the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential for progress and development in the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool industry, would be a return of a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government; a return to the same sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: policies- high interest rates, high taxes-

Speaker: NA
Text: And, as and the sort of regime that damaged

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's greatest primary industry for such

Speaker: NA
Text: a long period of time. They can now look to

Speaker: NA
Text: the future with confidence as this memory of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's failure is finally rolled out the door.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: you confirm that, as a result of the deal ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: gotiated between Tristar and its workers, the

Speaker: NA
Text: employer is required to pay 1.5 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their payroll for an insurance bond which

Speaker: NA
Text: over two years costs $1.4 million? Isn't it

Speaker: NA
Text: also a fact that under Labor's employee enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlements scheme, employers will be required

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay just an additional 0.1 per cent on their

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation contributions-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: $23,000? Minister, why are you forcing em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers to suffer industrial disputes and to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay more-

Text: The Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position is now entering into an argument.

Text: when under our plan the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme will be legislated and employers will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay substantially less? That is not argument;

Text: it is a simple proposition.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Labor's scheme to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tect entitlements is Manusafe. That is the

Text: scheme that is being promoted by the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition's friend Dougie Cameron,

Speaker: NA
Text: Dougie Cameron's mate over there-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Adams interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lyons

Speaker: NA
Text: will withdraw that statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Adams-I withdraw, Mr Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan-I raise a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker. The House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Practice at page 477 makes it clear that lan-

Speaker: NA
Text: guage likely to create disorder is unparlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary-

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I will deal with mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers on my right! The Manager of Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Business has the call; he has the right to

Speaker: NA
Text: be heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan-It derives from the same

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Commons Practice which led you

Speaker: NA
Text: to rule the Leader of the Opposition's ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion out of order, Mr Speaker. If there is one

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that is likely to provoke disorder, it

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate lie like that just told by the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. He knows it is not true and he continues

Speaker: NA
Text: to repeat it. If he did not know that it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: true when he first came into the House-al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though I believe that he did-he knows now,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is also irrelevant to the question. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has deliberately misled the House and lied.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: made his point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Hoare interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Charl-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton is warned!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-I raise a point of order, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. The allegation of a deliberate lie is

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly in breach of the instruction and ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice that you gave to the House earlier today,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I ask that it be withdrawn. It is totally

Speaker: NA
Text: unparliamentary given the advices that you

Speaker: NA
Text: have provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCMullan-I withdraw the allega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that he deliberately misled the House.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I thank the Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I was asked about La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor's entitlements policy. It is Manusafe, the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of Dougie Cameron, the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's mate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Laurie Ferguson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: This parliament-if the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Reid has some difficulty with

Speaker: NA
Text: this, he may excuse himself if he wishes-

Speaker: NA
Text: has survived and has, in fact, thrived over

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 years on the basis that anyone could

Speaker: NA
Text: come in here and state whatever they

Speaker: NA
Text: believed to be the truth and in the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. If anyone believed that they were

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading the House they, too, were free to

Speaker: NA
Text: be called to put their point of view. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of the occupier of the chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister, obviously, has an obligation to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond in a manner that he believes is

Speaker: NA
Text: truthful, as do all other members. Whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the response is consistent with what others

Speaker: NA
Text: may believe is not a matter over which the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair has jurisdiction. The chair's obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: is to ensure that everyone can put their point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view and be heard. Chorusing runs

Speaker: NA
Text: is a counter to all that the standing orders stand

Speaker: NA
Text: for, that is, the right to be heard in silence. I

Speaker: NA
Text: expect every occupier of the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise courtesy and not to be provocative

Speaker: NA
Text: in the way in which they address the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: So do all other occupiers of the chair. So do

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australians. So do all members on the

Speaker: NA
Text: floor. The minister has concluded his answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean-He could not get the lie up so

Speaker: NA
Text: he had to sit down.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ramatta will resume his seat. The Deputy

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Families: Policy

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Text: 3.04 p.m.)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Services. Would the minister outline any in-

Speaker: NA
Text: novative policies to build stronger families

Speaker: NA
Text: and stronger communities across Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is the minister aware of any other policies to

Speaker: NA
Text: help Australian families?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Leo MCLeay-I raise a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker. I put it to you that the question

Speaker: NA
Text: is out of order. The member asked the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister to outline innovative policies.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Chief Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip raises a point of order, but, in fact, as

Speaker: NA
Text: members are aware, what the minister may

Speaker: NA
Text: not do is announce policy; he is able to

Speaker: NA
Text: elaborate on policy. I will listen to the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister's answer to ensure that he is doing that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Leo MCLeay-I raise a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker. The standing orders provide that

Speaker: NA
Text: a member cannot ask a minister to announce

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. The member asked the minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: outline innovative policies. If that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncing policy, I do not know what is.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I point out to the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Whip that, if the policy has al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready been announced, then the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be, in fact, announcing policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the way in which the standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: is structured. I will listen for the answer.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Robertson, who has a very keen interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting families, as indeed do all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition. We would like to see an innovative

Speaker: NA
Text: policy from the opposition-we would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to see just one. We wait for a policy, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: do the Australian public. But certainly this

Speaker: NA
Text: government is getting on with the job of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding a better deal for Australian families,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are very proud of that. Firstly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard-Anderson government is providing

Speaker: NA
Text: good economic management through lower

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates, and by providing the lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation we have had for decades, making

Speaker: NA
Text: home ownership far more affordable and

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing employment. But one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest achievements is in the area of family

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance where over 2.2 million Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families-four million children-now re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive 20 per cent more in family assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: than they ever would have got under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: You have to also ask yourself about child

Speaker: NA
Text: care. I have not had one question on child

Speaker: NA
Text: care from the opposition in the last 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months. They are silent, and why? Because

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a terrific story to tell on child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Child care today is nine per cent cheaper

Speaker: NA
Text: than it was 12 months ago, and the reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the introduction of the new taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: system and the increased affordability of

Speaker: NA
Text: child care. But the opposition have not asked

Speaker: NA
Text: one question. They are very opportunistic

Speaker: NA
Text: about child care but they have not asked one

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: This graph says it all. It is a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: document put out by Family and Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Services which shows a significant increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the funding of child care. Thirty per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: more has been spent on child care than in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last four years of the Labor government. In-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed, over the next four years, $6 billion will

Speaker: NA
Text: be spent on child care. That is why it has

Speaker: NA
Text: anbecome far more affordable, and that is why

Speaker: NA
Text: today, as opposed to a year ago when there

Speaker: NA
Text: were 450,000 children in Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: funded child care, there are 700,000 children

Speaker: NA
Text: in child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: have not increased funding for preschools

Speaker: NA
Text: since the day they were elected. Shame on

Speaker: NA
Text: them. They have frozen funding for pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: schools since they came into government

Speaker: NA
Text: back in the mid-1990s. And they claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are the family-friendly party. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: not that at all. Of course they have got no

Speaker: NA
Text: credibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler is warned!

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Another area where

Speaker: NA
Text: this government has a proud record is in our

Speaker: NA
Text: Reconnect program to help young families,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is trying to keep families together

Speaker: NA
Text: through our Stronger Families and Commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities Strategy or the fight that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: against drugs-and we know that the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's policy is totally flim-flam on that

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. Some people are asking, ‘Where is

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's plan to help Australian families?' I

Speaker: NA
Text: did find a plan, which quite surprised me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's plan came straight from the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition himself, when he said, ‘My

Speaker: NA
Text: plan is to be in the Lodge.' That is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: plan he has.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: What?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: His one plan is, ‘My

Speaker: NA
Text: plan is to be in the Lodge.' Don't pack your

Speaker: NA
Text: bags just yet, Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the shadow Treasurer addressed Mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion Australia recently, he announced a four-

Speaker: NA
Text: point plan, and this is his four-point plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order on relevance. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked for an innovative policy; we have

Speaker: NA
Text: not heard one yet.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Chief Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip does not have a point of order.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I think you had better

Speaker: NA
Text: get back on your bike, Leo. This is the four-

Speaker: NA
Text: point plan as articulated by the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer in his address to Mission Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: recently. It is Labor's four-point plan which

Speaker: NA
Text: is meant to be family friendly. Point 1 is big

Speaker: NA
Text: budget deficits. That is all they know, as eviadoption

Speaker: NA
Text: denced by the $80 billion deficit that we in-

Speaker: NA
Text: herited and that Australian families have to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for. Point 2 is raising taxes and crippling

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates, which put many Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families out of their homes. When the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition was the finance minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates were 17 per cent. Point 3 is

Speaker: NA
Text: raising unemployment to massive levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Point 4, most importantly, is do not upset the

Speaker: NA
Text: unions because they pay the bills, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen that demonstrated very amply in

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent motor industry dispute.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 3.11 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, isn't it the case that there are thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of companies in Australia that have enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prise agreements that are about to expire but

Speaker: NA
Text: that do not have protection for 100 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of workers' entitlements? Will every one of

Speaker: NA
Text: these companies and their workers have to

Speaker: NA
Text: go through negotiations which may turn into

Speaker: NA
Text: long and bitter industrial disputes before

Speaker: NA
Text: workers can get security for 100 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their legal entitlements under your formula?

Speaker: NA
Text: Isn't the only choice you leave the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community this: our plan for a national em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployee entitlements scheme or your plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: a Tristar dispute in every factory in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: All those companies to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Leader of the Opposition refers

Speaker: NA
Text: will go through the kind of bitter industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: disputation to which the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition refers only if the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's friends in the AMWU-his mate

Speaker: NA
Text: Dougie Cameron-force them to. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: simple truth. I have a letter here addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: Steve Bracks from the chief executive of one

Speaker: NA
Text: of those companies, Holden. This is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the companies which is threatened with con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuous industrial action by the friends of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party and by Dougie Cameron, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition's best mate. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hanenberger wrote about one way to address

Speaker: NA
Text: this problem. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: One avenue by which this could be achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: would be by strengthening the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's employee entitlements scheme through

Speaker: NA
Text: by those states that have not yet done so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best thing that could happen to defuse

Speaker: NA
Text: this entitlements issue would be if the state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor governments supported the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government's entitlements scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forest Products Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: FRAN BAILEY (3.14 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is addressed to the Minister for Forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: and Conservation. Would the minister advise

Speaker: NA
Text: what information he has received from

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia relating to the future ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministration and prospects for the forest

Speaker: NA
Text: products industry and its work force?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: In reporting to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: on matters that have arisen, according to the

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question, I advise the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gallop Labor government in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has now incorporated its complete

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party policy on the forest industries in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the closure of that industry. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: well known that that policy had the complete

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the Leader of the Opposition. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence, there has already been an an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement by the largest employer in the

Speaker: NA
Text: forestry industry in Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sotico, that there will be 400 redundancies

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith in that particular industry. A

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller employer of 10 persons has already

Speaker: NA
Text: lost his forest contract and has been obliged

Speaker: NA
Text: to sack all his employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard question after question to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day about the payment of redundancies. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Gallop government has refused to give any

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in the payment of redundancies to

Speaker: NA
Text: any of those workers. We are not talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about a company that was in full production

Speaker: NA
Text: and that could sell all its products, with its

Speaker: NA
Text: employees having security of employment;

Speaker: NA
Text: we are talking about workers who have lost

Speaker: NA
Text: their jobs because of political expediency, in

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the Leader of the Opposition was to-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally complicit. Those people have not gone

Speaker: NA
Text: back to work; they are finished. They cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: sell their houses. If any apology is needed in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place today, it is needed from the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition to those people and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families. As for the employer who had to

Speaker: NA
Text: sack all 10 of his employees, three of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people have got redundancy assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there are other activities going on

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia-and it is pretty interesting.

Speaker: NA
Text: You can run in this place but you cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: hide. I find in the North Eastern Advertiser, a

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper published in the remoter parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, that Senator Kerry O'Brien ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vised in a letter that the Senate passed the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's RFA legislation last year. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is pretty surprising, because I have the Han-

Speaker: NA
Text: sard record showing every Tasmanian mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber voting against it. But to help me out on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter, just two weeks later in the Burnie

Speaker: NA
Text: Advocate, the shadow minister Mr Ferguson

Speaker: NA
Text: is entreating me to reintroduce the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson-Did he talk to a newspa-

Speaker: NA
Text: per?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Yes, he did. We have it

Speaker: NA
Text: here in the newspaper. What is the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party up to? Here we are, Mr Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The minister will ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Thank you, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will-but that is not all. During the

Speaker: NA
Text: recess, the Leader of the Opposition decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to visit Eden-Monaro, and station 5AN in

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide had an interview with the Bulletin's

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony Wright relating to this visit. During that

Speaker: NA
Text: visit the Leader of the Opposition was out

Speaker: NA
Text: with his members, signing, with a big black

Speaker: NA
Text: pen, pledges to guarantee that he would not

Speaker: NA
Text: sell Telstra. I do not know how big a signa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture there was on the letter to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank employees union but, as I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: member-being a member of this place at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time-there was a signature promising

Speaker: NA
Text: never to sell more than 49 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Brad-

Speaker: NA
Text: don is warned!

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: But, after the signing, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony Wright of the Bulletin, talking of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, told 5AN's Philip

Speaker: NA
Text: Satchell as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Yesterday he was in Eden-Monaro, which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: far from Canberra ...

Speaker: NA
Text: He was, as I said, signing these Telstra guar-

Speaker: NA
Text: antees. But Mr Wright goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Interestingly, Green groups came with a very

Speaker: NA
Text: similar pledge asking him to sign that forests

Speaker: NA
Text: would be protected. But, of course, Eden-Monaro

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of those areas where there are a lot of for-

Speaker: NA
Text: est workers and he wasn't going to get into that at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. ... But, when asked to sign the one on the for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests of Eden-Monaro he put away the big black

Speaker: NA
Text: pen and got out the prolixity again.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish I had the time in this place to read the

Speaker: NA
Text: convoluted remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Yes, you can run but you

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot hide in this place. He has got a mes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sage in one place and he would not sign.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it gets worse because in many parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, particularly those associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: the pulp and paper industry, there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: an advocate group of workers known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: A-Team. They have done a wonderful job

Speaker: NA
Text: coming to my office and members' offices,

Speaker: NA
Text: asking for all assistance necessary to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain a pulp and paper industry in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and all the employment that goes with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of those areas can be found in the seat

Speaker: NA
Text: of Braddon, another can be found in the seat

Speaker: NA
Text: of Gilmore and still another can be found in

Speaker: NA
Text: the seat of MCMillan. These people have

Speaker: NA
Text: now been heavied by the CFMEU to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: band, and they thought they might need to

Speaker: NA
Text: get a bit of help from their local member of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. They have written to me:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is particularly relevant, given the unusual

Speaker: NA
Text: special relationship between the CFMEU and our

Speaker: NA
Text: local federal MP, Christian Zahra, which resulted

Speaker: NA
Text: from the union's generous financial support for

Speaker: NA
Text: him at the last election. Since his election, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Zahra has steadfastly refused to meet our delega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions on important issues, which have impacted

Speaker: NA
Text: on the MCMillan electorate. Further, he has ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended this ban on any of his constituents, who

Speaker: NA
Text: have happened to be members of the Maryvale A-

Speaker: NA
Text: Team.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in black and white, signed by a

Speaker: NA
Text: worker living in Maryvale in the MCMillan

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: I think he is now calling

Speaker: NA
Text: this fellow a liar.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Now he says I am a liar.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The minister will ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress his remarks through the chair and not

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to interjections.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Everything I have drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the House today is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: body else's words. We have got Kerry

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Brien dreaming: he actually lives in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate and thought he had passed the bill. He

Speaker: NA
Text: did not. We have got the shadow minister

Speaker: NA
Text: now thinking, ‘Golly, gosh, we've offended

Speaker: NA
Text: all these workers and the election is getting

Speaker: NA
Text: close. I wonder if I can sneak down to Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: mania and win a few of them back. I'll tell

Speaker: NA
Text: them I love them.' Then the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition gets into Eden-Monaro, and what

Speaker: NA
Text: does he do? He is asked to sign a pledge. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was prepared to kill off a thousand jobs in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia to win that election, but

Speaker: NA
Text: when he thinks he might pick up the most

Speaker: NA
Text: marginal seat in the federal election and the

Speaker: NA
Text: greenies say, ‘Will you sign a pledge for the

Speaker: NA
Text: forest?' he reverts to prolixity. He starts

Speaker: NA
Text: talking. Then we get a person who stood up

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place telling us how committed he is

Speaker: NA
Text: to his electorate but, when a group of inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent workers, who get access to my of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice as a minister whenever they want it,

Speaker: NA
Text: tried to get into his office to tell him their

Speaker: NA
Text: troubles, he was not going to put his CFMEU

Speaker: NA
Text: funding at risk: he would not let them in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations: Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: 3.24 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Employment, Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Small Business. Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, given your refusal to implement a na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional employee entitlement scheme that

Speaker: NA
Text: covers 100 per cent of employees' entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, aren't you ensuring that thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian companies will have to negotiate

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance bonds and other arrangements at

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 60 times the cost to them of La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor's employee entitlements scheme? Again

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask: why are you forcing employers to suf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fer industrial disputes and to pay more under

Speaker: NA
Text: your formula when under our plan the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme will be legislated and employers will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay substantially less?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I am trying to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses of this country from industry-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide pattern bargaining in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe instigated by the friend of the La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party, the member of the Labor Party, the

Speaker: NA
Text: mate of the Leader of the Opposition, Dou-

Speaker: NA
Text: gie Cameron. That is what I am trying to do:

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the good, decent workers and their

Speaker: NA
Text: employers of this country from the ravages

Speaker: NA
Text: of a feral union led by the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position's mate.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask that

Speaker: NA
Text: further questions be placed on the Notice

Speaker: NA
Text: Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTER FOR EMPLOYMENT,

Speaker: NA
Text: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND

Speaker: NA
Text: SMALL BUSINESS

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion of Censure

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Brand-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (3.25 p.m.)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House censure the Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment, Workplace Relations and Small Busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness for his:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) irresponsible, inflammatory and deliberately

Speaker: NA
Text: provocative intervention in the Tristar dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: pute;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calling fellow Australians “traitors” simply

Speaker: NA
Text: for conducting themselves within the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial framework established by the Coa-

Speaker: NA
Text: lition Government;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) placing the job security of every single

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian worker at risk due to his ideo-

Speaker: NA
Text: logical and dogmatic approach to workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: relations;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) exposing the economy to potentially thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands of enterprise-level disputes over the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of securing legal employee entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments through his failure to put in place a

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive system which protects 100%

Speaker: NA
Text: of employees entitlements;

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) incompetent administration of the Job Net-

Speaker: NA
Text: work system which is increasingly being

Speaker: NA
Text: marked by claims of fraud and rorting by

Speaker: NA
Text: providers seeking to comply with the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's injunction to focus on numerical

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes, not jobs in the Job Network;

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) presiding over huge drops in full-time em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment;

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) use of his office to solely focus on generat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing political advantage for the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: and his complete disregard for the living

Speaker: NA
Text: standards and economic security of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian families; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) general unfitness to occupy the office of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no question at all that this minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has as an intention to inflame industrial dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: putation around this country as a cover for

Speaker: NA
Text: the inability of his colleagues in this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to get an election campaign success-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully organised around the record of this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, when they know that every

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian understands that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: has targeted them to bear the burden of the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation system, intends to Americanise the

Speaker: NA
Text: health care system, intends to run down the

Speaker: NA
Text: public school system, does not give a darn

Speaker: NA
Text: about those in aged care and will leave them

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequately protected, and that this is not

Speaker: NA
Text: something on which they can run. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of this minister and the reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: his use of inflammatory language and,

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, his frequent lying, as we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber here today-

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: This is a censure mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. His frequent lying, as we have seen in

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber today-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! A censure mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion does not allow the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition to make that accusation. I ask him to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw it.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: I withdraw, and I sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitute ‘his constant, deliberate untruths',

Speaker: NA
Text: which we have seen reflected here in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber today. Recollect the way he an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swered every one of those questions. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: no argument. He has no argument at all that

Speaker: NA
Text: stands up. When he sees what he inflicts on

Speaker: NA
Text: employers in this country, he has no argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment against the Labor Party's scheme-

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap, certain, total coverage, with no

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial disputation to arrive at it. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: no argument against that, so therefore he has

Speaker: NA
Text: to falsely accuse the Labor Party for

Speaker: NA
Text: ostensibly going around advocating a scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: which is rendered essential or is out there in

Speaker: NA
Text: the ether because huge numbers of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country do not feel that their life savings

Speaker: NA
Text: are being adequately protected.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the same minister who, when he

Speaker: NA
Text: had the same portfolio in a lesser position,

Speaker: NA
Text: described the St Vincent de Paul Society as

Speaker: NA
Text: ignorant in their understanding of poverty.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the same minister who in the junior

Speaker: NA
Text: version of this portfolio came out and ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cused the unemployed, in a situation of fal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling job opportunities, of being in the cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances in which they found themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: because they were job snobs. That is his

Speaker: NA
Text: view. This is the same minister who has

Speaker: NA
Text: wandered about this country breaching the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed in a fashion which has ensured

Speaker: NA
Text: that some of those who are doing things

Speaker: NA
Text: hardest in this country have virtually nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: to live on. And he is the stalking horse for

Speaker: NA
Text: this Prime Minister, so everything that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: done, the calumnies he has heaped on the

Speaker: NA
Text: heads of ordinary Australians and the most

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable in the society, are at the direct

Speaker: NA
Text: behest of the Prime Minister of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: He says things in public that the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister believes but does not dare say.

Speaker: NA
Text: He knows that this Prime Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: about to be called to account. He is about to

Speaker: NA
Text: be called to account for his deceit on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian electorate when he said he would

Speaker: NA
Text: never, ever implement a GST. He is about to

Speaker: NA
Text: be called to account for his deceit when he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that no Australian worker in the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial relations system they were putting in

Speaker: NA
Text: place would be worse off. He is going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: called to account for his deceit when he said

Speaker: NA
Text: that he would preserve Medicare when his

Speaker: NA
Text: whole policy has been directed at under-

Speaker: NA
Text: mining it and producing instead a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where our health care system is being

Speaker: NA
Text: Americanised. He knows the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot answer these things on the campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: trail and failure to answer them in normal

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances will mean defeat.

Speaker: NA
Text: How do you get round it? There is a time-

Speaker: NA
Text: honoured Liberal party tradition: shift the

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda, cover it with a darn good ‘reds under

Speaker: NA
Text: the bed' campaign and focus that on indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial disputation. Every employer in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country knows that they will be hassled by

Speaker: NA
Text: this minister when they enter into a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiation with their employees not to settle

Speaker: NA
Text: but to provoke every dispute to run through

Speaker: NA
Text: to a complete confrontation with the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial relations system and place the workers

Speaker: NA
Text: at variance with directions of the Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Commission so that the onus can

Speaker: NA
Text: be turned on to them as they are out there

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting for their legitimate rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Do not forget that during the course of this

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute, when the issue was tightly con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tested, when the workers had indicated, as

Speaker: NA
Text: they always do in any industrial relations

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute, an intention to compromise and

Speaker: NA
Text: started to move in that direction, the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for industrial relations said, ‘Don't compro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mise!' Understand the context of that ‘Don't

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise!' beyond what I have already

Speaker: NA
Text: just stated. That was a part of the dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: when the workers were shifting ground. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand that that ‘Don't compromise!'

Speaker: NA
Text: stands at variance with part of the defensive

Speaker: NA
Text: cloud that he put out in January this year

Speaker: NA
Text: around his own proposition in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of workers' entitlements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The workers in Tristar were following the

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions of the minister to the letter. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me quote from the minister's pamphlet. He

Speaker: NA
Text: put it out, of course, in that context because

Speaker: NA
Text: he realised that any worker looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: full-blown implications of the entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: package put together by this minister and his

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors knew that waste would be laid

Speaker: NA
Text: to their entitlements should ever their com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies go under. So what did this minister

Speaker: NA
Text: say? He said this:

Speaker: NA
Text: [This] does not preclude the adoption of addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional measures, by particular employers and

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees. ... such an approach would place the

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation directly on the employer concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: and could deliver 100 per cent of what is owed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the employee.

Speaker: NA
Text: What sort of schemes would those be? Those

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes would be the type of scheme that

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately was adopted by the workers and

Speaker: NA
Text: the company to conclude this dispute. They

Speaker: NA
Text: would also include, by the way, Manusafe.

Speaker: NA
Text: In what way is Manusafe at variance with

Speaker: NA
Text: any of this? In no way at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: This man, at the beginning of this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: stood up in public and effectively suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: to all workers, ‘Get your schemes together.

Speaker: NA
Text: Go out there and negotiate what it is you can

Speaker: NA
Text: get.' Now, in some circumstances that will

Speaker: NA
Text: emerge in relation to insurance bonds, but

Speaker: NA
Text: there is nothing in this that talks about it

Speaker: NA
Text: simply being insurance bonds. Of course, in

Speaker: NA
Text: other circumstances it would be the type of

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes outlined by the AMWU on

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe. It ill behoves him to come into

Speaker: NA
Text: this place now and suggest that the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances that have occurred are anything other

Speaker: NA
Text: than what he cut loose at the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. There is no prescription in this;

Speaker: NA
Text: what there is in this is disaster.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around this country now-and not just in

Speaker: NA
Text: factories where the AMWU is the predomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nant union-in a multiplicity of workplaces,

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements are coming up for renegotiation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those agreements for renegotiation come

Speaker: NA
Text: under the government's own industrial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions system, which protects strike action in

Speaker: NA
Text: certain bargaining contexts, and so it is al-

Speaker: NA
Text: most invariably going to be the case where

Speaker: NA
Text: management does not agree with the workers

Speaker: NA
Text: and vice versa that that protected period is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be entertained, to the very consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able damage potentially of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy as these employers and employees

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to work their way through the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of this government's policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of that can be seen in what we

Speaker: NA
Text: have already seen in the case of Tristar: $1.5

Speaker: NA
Text: million over two years is what this will cost

Speaker: NA
Text: the employer in that case, versus the $23,000

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would cost the employer for a scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: that covers all. Why is it so much cheaper?

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously because everybody is in it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of companies around Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: em- virtually all of which will survive cheerfully

Speaker: NA
Text: for decades and decades, will cover the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: surance costs of those that go under, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: will do so very cheaply indeed. And no com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany can guarantee that they will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: numbered amongst that small minority at

Speaker: NA
Text: some point of time in the history of their

Speaker: NA
Text: company's activities over the decades.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a solution, but it is not a solution

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted by this minister. This minister wants

Speaker: NA
Text: a fight. This minister makes a confession to

Speaker: NA
Text: every gathering that he addresses in the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial relations area. We talk to the same

Speaker: NA
Text: businessmen that they do. He wanders fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently into his address to employers at Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party fundraisers and the like, always

Speaker: NA
Text: starting with this winning sentence: ‘Every-

Speaker: NA
Text: body in this room knows more about indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial relations than I do.' That is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: honest statement he makes in the entirety of

Speaker: NA
Text: his address. Indeed, they do. What no-one in

Speaker: NA
Text: that room wants is the minister's agenda that

Speaker: NA
Text: underpins that. He does not care about his

Speaker: NA
Text: ignorance of the industrial relations system.

Speaker: NA
Text: He does not care about his complete lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the lives and lifestyles of

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary Australians and what they depend

Speaker: NA
Text: upon. All he cares about is organising a fight

Speaker: NA
Text: to cover the unpopularity of his boss and the

Speaker: NA
Text: impossibility of his boss's circumstances as

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate gradually comes to grips with

Speaker: NA
Text: the consequences of the policies that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been subjected to over the course of the

Speaker: NA
Text: last five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not seen-even under the regime of

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Reith, full of conspiracy though it was

Speaker: NA
Text: against the rights of ordinary workers in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country-any minister of this or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: government stand up and describe a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: his fellow Australians as traitors for taking

Speaker: NA
Text: lawful industrial action. In factories around

Speaker: NA
Text: this country there are workers who have

Speaker: NA
Text: served this country in wartime who do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have protection of their entitlements to the

Speaker: NA
Text: tune of 100 per cent and who expect that

Speaker: NA
Text: their unions will pursue the directions of Ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: bott to secure 100 per cent coverage of their

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements through the industrial relations

Speaker: NA
Text: system. And he calls them, if they pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: those positions, traitors.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is his role: to insult ordinary working

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians in this country. Let me tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: what is at stake for them. We will go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: case that we named specifically at Tristar, of

Speaker: NA
Text: a worker of 30 years in that factory. You

Speaker: NA
Text: know what workers of 30 years are like-

Speaker: NA
Text: they are the skilled workers that keep the

Speaker: NA
Text: engine of Australian industry going. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are the men and women who have built up

Speaker: NA
Text: over years and years of experience the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to fix the problems in their

Speaker: NA
Text: train the junior workers and to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the productive system of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeds in a way that generates the wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay the personal entitlements of that

Speaker: NA
Text: minister opposite. Those people are

Speaker: NA
Text: described as traitors. In the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: instance that we cited, that gentleman had

Speaker: NA
Text: $122,000 worth of entitlements-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members-Marty Peek.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: That is right, Marty

Speaker: NA
Text: Peek. He had $122,000 worth of entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. He is the epitome of the skilled, long

Speaker: NA
Text: serving, loyal Australian worker. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: loyal to that company. These are the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women that perform that essential

Speaker: NA
Text: task not only in the workplace but in our so-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciety. They are the men and women you find

Speaker: NA
Text: manning the SES voluntary posts when

Speaker: NA
Text: bushfires come about, organising the Little

Speaker: NA
Text: Athletics on a Saturday morning and ensur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing by their voluntary endeavours that our

Speaker: NA
Text: community works. They are solid, intelli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gent, working class, skilled Australians. And

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the reward for Mr Marty Peek if this

Speaker: NA
Text: minister has his way-the man the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a traitor? What is the reward

Speaker: NA
Text: from this flaneur for Mr Marty Peek? The

Speaker: NA
Text: reward is that, if Tristar goes under, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Marty Peek will have secured $20,000. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: 47 years old, and he knows that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies of this government- which have

Speaker: NA
Text: completely collapsed full-time employment

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country, with record collapse of full-

Speaker: NA
Text: time employment in the course of the last

Speaker: NA
Text: month-his chance of a full-time job from

Speaker: NA
Text: this point on is negligible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those rotten figures that we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: over the course of the last year or two, last

Speaker: NA
Text: year in particular, on full-time jobs-and it

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be said their performance was not all

Speaker: NA
Text: that great before then, but what was not a

Speaker: NA
Text: great performance has become a disastrous

Speaker: NA
Text: performance-are what is driving one of

Speaker: NA
Text: those awful statistics in this country, which

Speaker: NA
Text: sees us now as a nation where men in their

Speaker: NA
Text: fifties have the lowest participation rate in

Speaker: NA
Text: the workforce in the Western world. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know this: if he is sacked and has to go

Speaker: NA
Text: without his entitlements, that $122,000 is all

Speaker: NA
Text: he has got to pay off his mortgage and all he

Speaker: NA
Text: has got to sustain his retirement. But Mr Ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: bott does not give a darn, because Marty

Speaker: NA
Text: firms, to Peek is an opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Marty Peek is not a human being; he is a

Speaker: NA
Text: political opportunity for this minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover for his worthless Prime Minister, who

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have the basic intestinal fortitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: do his own dirty work when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the public and when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with St Vincent de Paul. This Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister clearly hates them, but he would not

Speaker: NA
Text: dare say it because there would be a royal

Speaker: NA
Text: public reaction, so he sends Mr Abbott in to

Speaker: NA
