Text: tell St Vincent de Paul, one of the most ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fective charities in this community, that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in fact ignorant of the issues of poverty in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. Mr Abbott does it; the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister does not. The Prime Minister does

Speaker: NA
Text: not want to be connected with a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: that the unemployed who can find no work

Speaker: NA
Text: in a country where full-time employment has

Speaker: NA
Text: collapsed only fail to do so because they are

Speaker: NA
Text: job snobs. The Prime Minister would dearly

Speaker: NA
Text: love to say that, but he has his dirty work

Speaker: NA
Text: merchant to do it instead-this minister op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite. He is out there to deliver the insults

Speaker: NA
Text: and to inflame the situation-that is his job.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not how Australia is meant to be.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not how Australia is meant to be gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: erned. This is not how Australians will have

Speaker: NA
Text: restored to them a sense of security.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had good growth in this commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity over the course of the last eight years.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had good growth until last year. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have good growth on the hard yards made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party when we were in office, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which the government has been the benefici-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary. These days as I go around, one comment

Speaker: NA
Text: is made to me constantly, ‘If the economy is

Speaker: NA
Text: so good, why don't I and my family feel it?'

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not feel it. The increasing inequality

Speaker: NA
Text: in our society continues apace. One of the

Speaker: NA
Text: significant influences on that increasing ine-

Speaker: NA
Text: quality is the operation of the industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: tions system, put in place by this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It has had its most savage effect on

Speaker: NA
Text: women's wages, but it has had a pretty awe-

Speaker: NA
Text: some impact on the job security of bread-

Speaker: NA
Text: winners of both genders. They do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they will be able to sustain levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: family debt-no matter what the interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates are- when their employment and their

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements are not secure. And he has done

Speaker: NA
Text: it!

Speaker: NA
Text: He performed another task. There is not

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient time for me to go into it, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: say this: it is all unravelling for him now. As

Speaker: NA
Text: this government collapsed employment pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams, which were the only chance for many

Speaker: NA
Text: people in regional Australia in particular, it

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced measures that it said were alter-

Speaker: NA
Text: natives that would work at about one-tenth of

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of what was there and working. To

Speaker: NA
Text: defend intuitively such nonsense, it had to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce a set of statistics. We find now that

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which the statistics were produced

Speaker: NA
Text: under this minister has induced widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: fraud in the system. They have tumbled. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has been tumbled. The people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been disbenefited are the most vulnerable in

Speaker: NA
Text: this society. This minister is not fit to hold

Speaker: NA
Text: office. His undergraduate mentality, his

Speaker: NA
Text: childish and deceitful attitude, which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen manifest here today, and his

Speaker: NA
Text: worthless insulting attacks on ordinary Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians deserve his censure and removal.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Nehl)-Is

Speaker: NA
Text: the motion seconded?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bevis-I second the censure motion

Speaker: NA
Text: and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Workplace Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business) (3.47 p.m.)-We have just

Speaker: NA
Text: seen a rambling and hysterical speech from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition, who has

Speaker: NA
Text: proven today yet again that he cannot handle

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure. Under the pressure of the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign, the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition is revealing something that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: long suspected-a nasty streak which shows

Speaker: NA
Text: a fundamental weakness of character and a

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental lack of ticker.

Speaker: NA
Text: You have to ask yourself this question:

Speaker: NA
Text: relawhy are members opposite so sensitive?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why are they so affronted by anything that

Speaker: NA
Text: involves the union movement? It is because

Speaker: NA
Text: the union movement owns them lock, stock

Speaker: NA
Text: and barrel. It owns them heart and soul. The

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement provides every single

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Labor Party with membership

Speaker: NA
Text: of the union movement. The union move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has produced Labor's frontbench, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: produced their backbench and it has pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced their party officials. Sixty per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their frontbench are former union officials.

Speaker: NA
Text: will After the next election, they will have no

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer than three ACTU presidents on their

Speaker: NA
Text: frontbench.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last year for which figures are

Speaker: NA
Text: available, the union movement gave the La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party no less than $5 million. The union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement controls 60 per cent of the votes

Speaker: NA
Text: at every Labor Party conference. The dregs

Speaker: NA
Text: of the union movement include people such

Speaker: NA
Text: as the current state secretary of the AMWU

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria, who is currently facing charges

Speaker: NA
Text: of riot and affray arising out of a most ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: palling incident at a factory in Victoria. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the person who controls the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: bloc vote inside the Victorian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why are members opposite reacting so

Speaker: NA
Text: hysterically? They are reacting the way they

Speaker: NA
Text: are because they know that the union link is

Speaker: NA
Text: the soft underbelly of the Labor Party, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is now threatening what they thought was

Speaker: NA
Text: their easy ride to power. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition was crying crocodile tears today

Speaker: NA
Text: over the strikes that he thinks will break out

Speaker: NA
Text: at hundreds of factories in the weeks ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me make it very clear: this government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not support strikes. This government

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks that strikes should be, at most, an ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: solute last resort. Members opposite support

Speaker: NA
Text: strikes, and they have demonstrated that time

Speaker: NA
Text: and time again over the last week. This strike

Speaker: NA
Text: at Tristar was supported by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hotham, the Deputy Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion; it was supported by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dickson, the shadow minister for employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment; and it was never opposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has never opposed Manusafe.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition, for once in his

Speaker: NA
Text: life, was completely silent during this dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: on the matters that put 12,000 workers out of

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us be very clear what this strike was

Speaker: NA
Text: about. This strike was about Manusafe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe is not a 1.5 per cent levy on pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll. That is how it started, but it finished

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 per cent levy on payroll. Even at 1.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of payroll, Manusafe means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry alone will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay $550 million into a fund that is ironclad

Speaker: NA
Text: controlled by the union movement. That will

Speaker: NA
Text: cost at least 10,000 jobs in the motor indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members opposite have been saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not support Manusafe. Of course

Speaker: NA
Text: they support Manusafe; of course ALP pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy supports Manusafe. I am reading from

Speaker: NA
Text: the documents of the ALP conference last

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Employers are not required to make additional

Speaker: NA
Text: payments for benefits already protected by trusts

Speaker: NA
Text: or other appropriate means.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also in this policy, passed by the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party conference last year, is support for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry-wide strikes in support of pattern bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining, such as the industry-wide strike now

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened by the AMWU in support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me make it very clear that workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements deserve protection. Any worker

Speaker: NA
Text: facing the loss of his or her entitlements de-

Speaker: NA
Text: serves sympathy, help and support. Workers

Speaker: NA
Text: facing the loss of their entitlements are fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing one of the gravest calamities that anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: can face, and they certainly deserve the sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of this government-and they have it.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the first government ever to put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place a scheme to protect workers' entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let us put this problem in perspective.

Speaker: NA
Text: In any one year, just one-half of one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of businesses go out of business, go broke. In

Speaker: NA
Text: any one year fewer than one-tenth of one per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of employees lose their jobs because

Speaker: NA
Text: their company has gone out of business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even fewer than one-tenth of one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: can expect to lose their entitlements. The

Speaker: NA
Text: beauty of this government's scheme is that it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not cost jobs, it does not provide any-

Speaker: NA
Text: one with the encouragement to ramp up enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlements and, unlike Labor's scheme-unlike

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe-it does not amount to a confis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of the working capital of ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's scheme is Manusafe. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme to which Labor Party policy is ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately directed. That is the scheme that La-

Speaker: NA
Text: as a bor Party policy ultimately supports. But

Speaker: NA
Text: whether you look at Manusafe, a levy on

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll of up to 19 per cent, or whether you

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the no-frills scheme sometimes men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned by the Leader of the Opposition, all

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's schemes amount to a tax on jobs. All

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's schemes amount to a compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: levy on 100 per cent of payroll, 100 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of jobs, to support one-tenth of one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of workers who have this entitlement prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem. I will now quote from someone who is

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to know. I will quote from

Speaker: NA
Text: someone whose company is directly threat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ened by the Manusafe campaign now threat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ened against the motor industry and the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry and supported to the

Speaker: NA
Text: hilt by members opposite. Peter Hanenber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ger, the chairman and MD of Holden, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Implementation of any scheme requiring signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant financial contribution by employers will

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore amount to the imposition of a cost im-

Speaker: NA
Text: post on business which will greatly exceed the

Speaker: NA
Text: quantum of the problem it seeks to address.

Speaker: NA
Text: He also said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Second, the concept of requiring all businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: those over a certain size to effectively fund the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential failure of the very few rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: viding a government supported safety net to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: those isolated incidents is, in our view, simply

Speaker: NA
Text: unsustainable.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there you have it: Peter Hanenberger-a

Speaker: NA
Text: boss of a company that is employing tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of Australians and is generating

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of millions of dollars of sales,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is generating hundreds of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars of exports every year-says that La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor's schemes are unsustainable and that

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be a government supported

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net to cover the isolated incidents

Speaker: NA
Text: where workers lose their entitlements.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not apologise at all for telling people

Speaker: NA
Text: not to compromise on the Manusafe issue

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will never apologise for opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: strikes against the national interest. This

Speaker: NA
Text: government did everything it could to stop

Speaker: NA
Text: this strike, even indicating repeatedly that we

Speaker: NA
Text: would seek leave to intervene before the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission in support of a return to work

Speaker: NA
Text: order. We constantly wanted to stop this

Speaker: NA
Text: strike-unlike members opposite, who con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantly supported this strike, constantly sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported the AMWU and constantly support

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe.

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw from the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: this afternoon a non-stop tirade of personal

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse that would have been worthy of his

Speaker: NA
Text: former boss, Paul Keating. It was a constant

Speaker: NA
Text: litany of contemptuous abuse which demeans

Speaker: NA
Text: him and demeans his office and is unworthy

Speaker: NA
Text: of this parliament. I do not know what I have

Speaker: NA
Text: done to get under his skin, but I have cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly done something or this government

Speaker: NA
Text: has done something. I think what is getting

Speaker: NA
Text: under his skin is the knowledge that this

Speaker: NA
Text: election is slipping away from him-the

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge that what he thought was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bag is now slipping away from him.

Speaker: NA
Text: I concede that I am far from perfect as an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual and that I have made many mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: takes. Over the years, I have even made, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure, some mistakes as a minister. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly defend my record as a hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: man being and a minister against that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition. Let us not forget

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was the defence minister responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Collins class subs; the communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: or tions minister responsible for the Optus-

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra $4 billion cable duplication; the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: proployment minister when unemployment hit

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 per cent-a post war record; and the fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nance minister who ran up $30 billion worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of government debt in just two years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition was the worst de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence minister ever, the worst communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions minister ever, the worst employment

Speaker: NA
Text: minister ever and the worst finance minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ever-and now he wants to be Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. But the Australian public are waking up

Speaker: NA
Text: to him. They know that he is all sound and

Speaker: NA
Text: fury. They know that he is all wind. They

Speaker: NA
Text: know he is a sanctimonious windbag, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not going to vote for him.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will also defend the record of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister against the record of the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition. This has been a great gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, led by an outstanding Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister. This is the government which banned

Speaker: NA
Text: semiautomatic weapons after 13 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: inaction from members opposite. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: government which secured the liberation of

Speaker: NA
Text: East Timor after 13 years of betrayal from

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite. This is the government

Speaker: NA
Text: which has had the guts to put in place tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reform after members opposite squibbed

Speaker: NA
Text: from the challenge. This is the government

Speaker: NA
Text: which has reformed the workplace relations

Speaker: NA
Text: system and has given workers a fair go. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is the government that brought in Work for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dole, which gives Australians in need a

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to show what they can do.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that many members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: and on my own side of the House know more

Speaker: NA
Text: about industrial relations in a technical sense

Speaker: NA
Text: than I do. I am sure that, as a former union

Speaker: NA
Text: official, the member for Brisbane knows

Speaker: NA
Text: more in a technical sense about some aspects

Speaker: NA
Text: of workplace relations. But I believe that I,

Speaker: NA
Text: as minister, have a better set of principles. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that this government has a better set

Speaker: NA
Text: of principles. We support workers; members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite support unions. We support free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom; members opposite support union con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol. We support higher pay for the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: workers of this country; members opposite,

Speaker: NA
Text: in 13 years of government, proved that they

Speaker: NA
Text: support reducing wages for the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: workers of this country. We believe in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people, and we want to focus on

Speaker: NA
Text: what they can do. Deep down, members op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite mistrust and even despise the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian people and constantly focus on what

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot do.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have supported the Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity in the five years that we have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We have delivered for the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian community. We have cut unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, boosted wages, boosted growth and

Speaker: NA
Text: raised productivity. The Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition cried crocodile tears over the plight of

Speaker: NA
Text: mature age workers. Mature age unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was eight per cent when he left office;

Speaker: NA
Text: it is four per cent now. It has been well said

Speaker: NA
Text: by a better Labor member than most now

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, by Kim Beazley Sr, that he joined

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party when it was full of the cream

Speaker: NA
Text: of the working class and left it when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: full of the dregs of the middle class. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we have seen today from the Labor Party is a

Speaker: NA
Text: middle-class dreg in full flight. I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after ‘that' be omitted with

Speaker: NA
Text: view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘The House censures the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition for his failure to condemn irresponsible

Speaker: NA
Text: strike action in the manufacturing industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: for his continuing policy failure to promote the

Speaker: NA
Text: national interest over the union interest.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the amendment to the House.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Text: Brisbane) (4.02 p.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: last few weeks have demonstrated conclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sively to the Australian people a few things

Speaker: NA
Text: about this minister and this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They remember his comments a month ago

Speaker: NA
Text: on Four Corners, when he told the world

Speaker: NA
Text: that people who are in poverty are there by

Speaker: NA
Text: choice. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: But we can't abolish poverty because poverty in

Speaker: NA
Text: part is a function of individual behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: His view expressed to the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: was: when you find yourself in poverty, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: member that you made the choices. He then

Speaker: NA
Text: went on and enumerated some of them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people found that out in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: month. But there is another thing they found

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the last week. As workers in this land,

Speaker: NA
Text: they want to have their rights protected.

Speaker: NA
Text: They want to know that their entitlements are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be there if the company goes belly-

Speaker: NA
Text: up. They know that they now have two

Speaker: NA
Text: choices: they can have Stan Howard running

Speaker: NA
Text: the company, or they can have Kim Beazley

Speaker: NA
Text: as Prime Minister. Australian workers now

Speaker: NA
Text: know that that is the only way their wages

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to be secure if the company be-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes insolvent. To date, the only people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who have had their entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: fully protected are the workers at National

Speaker: NA
Text: Textiles-the special Stan-alone top-up; the

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off payment to Stan Howard. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment have dodged questions about that all

Speaker: NA
Text: week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike the minister at the table and the

Speaker: NA
Text: former minister, on a number of occasions I

Speaker: NA
Text: went to National Textiles and visited the

Speaker: NA
Text: workers and spoke to them and their fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies. They were not statistics, they were peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple. Many of them had worked in that indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try and for that company all their lives. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: total life savings were their accrued long-

Speaker: NA
Text: service leave, annual leave and redundancy

Speaker: NA
Text: pay and the very modest house that they

Speaker: NA
Text: lived in. Those were their total life savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: a If they had been able to get only the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of this government's employee scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: those workers would have got well under

Speaker: NA
Text: one-third of the entitlement that was due to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. Their life savings were evaporating in

Speaker: NA
Text: front of their eyes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another thing that the past couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks have demonstrated to us all is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister has a lot of trouble telling the truth.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has a lot of trouble telling the truth in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber, and he seems to have greater diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty with it outside the chamber. Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: remind people of one of the comments he

Speaker: NA
Text: made a little while ago here in the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: at question time when dealing with Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian workplace agreements. The minister was

Speaker: NA
Text: at pains to tell the parliament that if you are

Speaker: NA
Text: on an AWA, you are actually better off. ‘You

Speaker: NA
Text: get more money on an AWA,' he said. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, in the next question he immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: found out the truth of the matter, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: that the average Australian worker on an

Speaker: NA
Text: AWA today earns $55.10 a week less than

Speaker: NA
Text: they would if they were on a union agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. If the minister cannot tell the truth here

Speaker: NA
Text: at question time, in answer to a dorothy dix

Speaker: NA
Text: question that was prepared in his office, what

Speaker: NA
Text: hope is there that he is able to adhere to the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts or to tell the truth when issues like

Speaker: NA
Text: Tristar come along?

Speaker: NA
Text: Not telling the truth would have been bad

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, but the minister set out to fuel the

Speaker: NA
Text: fire. At every opportunity over the last week,

Speaker: NA
Text: this minister has simply opened his mouth to

Speaker: NA
Text: change feet-from one disaster to the next.

Speaker: NA
Text: He attacked those workers as being guilty of

Speaker: NA
Text: treason. The headline in the Australian was

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Car strike treason to spread'. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: alleges that those people are guilty of trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son-for what? It is because they were on

Speaker: NA
Text: strike. They were stopping the operations of

Speaker: NA
Text: that company and, the minister would say,

Speaker: NA
Text: causing problems in other parts of the car

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. He knows, even with his limited

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of industrial relations, that those

Speaker: NA
Text: workers were taking totally lawful action in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with his legislation. More than

Speaker: NA
Text: that, they were taking action not only in ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cordance with his industry legislation but

Speaker: NA
Text: also in accordance with what he said they

Speaker: NA
Text: should do to protect their entitlements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister might remember this docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Protection of employee entitlements on

Speaker: NA
Text: employer insolvency. It is subtitled ‘A rebut-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal of Labor's supposed alternatives'. It took

Speaker: NA
Text: them 18 months, with the whole government

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy behind them, to produce a cri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tique of our policy, which the minister knows

Speaker: NA
Text: is not Manusafe. He knows that to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: case, and throughout question time today he

Speaker: NA
Text: made comments to the contrary. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: document that he released, knowing that

Speaker: NA
Text: their scheme is flawed and to try and cover

Speaker: NA
Text: himself, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The government scheme is a safety net scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: and does not preclude the adoption of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: measures by particular employees and employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is precisely what those workers did.

Speaker: NA
Text: They took this government's advice: ‘If you

Speaker: NA
Text: want to protect your entitlements above our

Speaker: NA
Text: shoddy little basement scheme, this so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net, you've got to go out there and

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate it company by company.' And do

Speaker: NA
Text: you know what? You cannot get it arbitrated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this government's industrial relations

Speaker: NA
Text: laws, the Industrial Relations Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot make a decision. Here is the rub: the

Speaker: NA
Text: government give you a second rate scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: which, for most people, gives them a small

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of what was all theirs to begin

Speaker: NA
Text: with. That is what they give you for your

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements, and then they say, ‘But if you

Speaker: NA
Text: want more, go and negotiate it.' But then

Speaker: NA
Text: they put in place an industrial relations sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem that does not allow the umpire to give it

Speaker: NA
Text: to you. The only way you can get it is to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ercise your rights to collective action. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what the workers at Tristar did, in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the law that this government

Speaker: NA
Text: put down. For their trouble in taking this

Speaker: NA
Text: minister's advice earlier this year, following

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation that the government had put

Speaker: NA
Text: down, they were charged with treason and

Speaker: NA
Text: told they were traitors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister might like to make a journey

Speaker: NA
Text: up to Tristar next week and have a talk with

Speaker: NA
Text: the workers. I will tell him what sort of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ception he will get. I know what they said

Speaker: NA
Text: about him when they met last weekend. He

Speaker: NA
Text: thought he was going to fix the problem by

Speaker: NA
Text: threatening them. The response of the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers at their meeting on the weekend was an-

Speaker: NA
Text: ger towards this minister. His behaviour to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards them was as inflammatory in the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: pute as the issue that caused it in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place-and his failure to apologise to them is

Speaker: NA
Text: a disgrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that the minister test my veracity

Speaker: NA
Text: on this to see whether I am telling the truth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Go up there next week, Minister. Go up there

Speaker: NA
Text: and confront those workers at Tristar. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: come with you. You and I together can go

Speaker: NA
Text: and talk to the workers up there. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that management will not object. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: Dougie Cameron will not object. The minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and I can go up to Tristar next week and

Speaker: NA
Text: let us see what the workers say to this min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister about the way he has conducted him-

Speaker: NA
Text: self.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, let us see what management says

Speaker: NA
Text: about the way he conducted himself. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: content with inflaming the situation by tell-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing these people that they are guilty of trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son, he then turned around and said to the

Speaker: NA
Text: company, ‘Don't negotiate. Don't compro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mise.' Now, there is a novel approach for a

Speaker: NA
Text: minister trying to solve a dispute-‘Don't

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate.' I cannot think of a precedent of a

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, supposedly acting as the honest

Speaker: NA
Text: broker in a dispute, telling one side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: argument, ‘Look, don't talk to them. Don't

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise.' He then tells the other side,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘The only way this is going to be solved is if

Speaker: NA
Text: you back down and give up on what you

Speaker: NA
Text: want.'

Speaker: NA
Text: If the company had taken the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: advice, we would still have the dispute today

Speaker: NA
Text: and the workers would still have no protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. That is what the situation would be to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day. I suggest that next week the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and I find time in our diaries and make that

Speaker: NA
Text: trip. It will be an education for you, and you

Speaker: NA
Text: need it, because you rightly referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact a minute ago that there are many people

Speaker: NA
Text: in this parliament who know more about in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial relations than you do. And there are.

Speaker: Dr MARTIN
Text: Everyone.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Text: My colleague the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cunningham is correct; probably every-

Speaker: NA
Text: one in this parliament knows more about

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations than does the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the minister's approach to the job

Speaker: NA
Text: is novel. It is a novel approach to the job to

Speaker: NA
Text: commence your presentations to audiences

Speaker: NA
Text: of business executives by telling them that

Speaker: NA
Text: they all know more about the subject than

Speaker: NA
Text: you do. Your message has got through. They

Speaker: NA
Text: actually understand that. If they did not un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand it before this week, they sure do

Speaker: NA
Text: now. However, I think that the message got

Speaker: NA
Text: through before this week. In the recess, I

Speaker: NA
Text: visited a great many business functions and

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, at which business executives

Speaker: NA
Text: were in attendance, to talk about industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations. At one of those gatherings, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: am happy to say was sold out two weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: before the event occurred, they were at pains

Speaker: NA
Text: to point out to me that many more people

Speaker: NA
Text: had come along to listen to me than came to

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to you at a similar function. That might

Speaker: NA
Text: have something to do with the fact that you

Speaker: NA
Text: stand up in front of them and tell them that

Speaker: NA
Text: you haven't got a clue what you are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about. I was a little surprised at one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: gatherings when one of the senior executives

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘You know, I was at a thing about two

Speaker: NA
Text: or three weeks ago and he still started out by

Speaker: NA
Text: saying, “Everyone in this room knows more

Speaker: NA
Text: about industrial relations than me,” to which

Speaker: NA
Text: people shook their heads and asked, “Why is

Speaker: NA
Text: he in the job?”' Minister, that is a question

Speaker: NA
Text: all workers in Australia are entitled to ask,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the answer is that you should not be in

Speaker: NA
Text: the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not just a critique from the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party or the trade unions about your behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour. Let us have a look at the behaviour of

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister as reported in an editorial in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Age earlier this week which was headed

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Tony Abbott and his entitlements'. It said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Abbott seems to believe that all industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: action is wrong, even though his laws allow it,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that no union is capable of acting decently.

Speaker: NA
Text: He appears to see his role as being the nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: chief union basher.

Speaker: NA
Text: That editorial of the Melbourne Age got you

Speaker: NA
Text: in one. The editorial went on to talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue in dispute and said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's proposed scheme, which caps

Speaker: NA
Text: payouts at $20,000 and hands the bill to the tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers, seems inadequate and the Labor states are

Speaker: NA
Text: probably right not to sign up to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dead right. They had made the correct deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion on that. The Financial Review also

Speaker: NA
Text: found it amusing that you should rail the way

Speaker: NA
Text: you have at workers doing no more than

Speaker: NA
Text: following your laws and your plan for how

Speaker: NA
Text: they should secure their entitlements. It said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony Abbott, the self-confessed new boy of

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace relations, may call it a crime against

Speaker: NA
Text: the national interest or industrial and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: treason, but the strike which has shut down Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's car making industry is entirely consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the law and logic of our enterprise bargain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing system.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the journalists understood that law, it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair request that the minister should under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand it as well, but you have exhibited no

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that you understand any of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us turn to the issue of the protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: those workers' entitlements. As I said, you

Speaker: NA
Text: put out a report on the various options. I as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sume you read your report. So you know that

Speaker: NA
Text: your claims in question time today were to-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally false. The report talks about Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and I felt like we had been flogged

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proverbial wet lettuce after I had

Speaker: NA
Text: read it. After 18 months, you have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to find any hole in the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was heartened in that context to see what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian newspaper said in the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: of this dispute in their editorial on 4 August

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001. Having described the problems in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, the government's half-baked

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and the claim by the union for

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe, they said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Against this background, Labor's proposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: levy a 0.1 per cent surcharge

Speaker: NA
Text: perannuation Guarantee system looks more and

Speaker: NA
Text: more attractive. At a minimal cost to employers,

Speaker: NA
Text: it would create a scheme that is simple and can

Speaker: NA
Text: use existing administrative infrastructure. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would offer most workers comprehensive protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that existing schemes lack.

Speaker: NA
Text: The editorial writer in the Australian under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stands where the protection is for ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian workers. As you cannot under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the legislation, Minister, you might at

Speaker: NA
Text: least try reading some of the newspapers;

Speaker: NA
Text: you could pick up a few clues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government have urged on these

Speaker: NA
Text: workers a system that is divisive and disrup-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. That is your system. You have urged on

Speaker: NA
Text: the company a practice where they should

Speaker: NA
Text: not negotiate, even though under your sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem we supposedly have a negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: framework. What has been the result of that?

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out,

Speaker: NA
Text: the company, under pressure from this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, decided they would not sign up to

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe. Had they signed up to Manusafe,

Speaker: NA
Text: they would have had to pay out $174,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the manufacturing workers scheme; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not our scheme. It is a trust fund model,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a legitimate model. Indeed, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are other trust funds that operate in a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of industries, and there is nothing wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: with that model. Instead of doing that, they

Speaker: NA
Text: signed up to an insurance bond. So it is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: trust; it is simply an insurance bond. At least

Speaker: NA
Text: in the trust fund model, the money is there to

Speaker: NA
Text: come back out, but this is an insurance bond.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of paying $174,000 a year, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to pay $700,000 a year. Of course, if

Speaker: NA
Text: we were in government, they would have a

Speaker: NA
Text: national scheme, and they would pay

Speaker: NA
Text: I think this is no contest. I say to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ister and to those opposite that, as the weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: and months unfold and as employers under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that your system requires this to be

Speaker: NA
Text: replicated not just in the manufacturing sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor but in every company in the land, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will very quickly come to understand what

Speaker: NA
Text: the editorial in the Australian said. The fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture for Australian workers to have their en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titlements protected is with a Beazley led

Speaker: NA
Text: government, which will legislate to fix this

Speaker: NA
Text: mess, and it will do it early in the next term.

Speaker: NA
Text: on the existing Su- (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Text: La Trobe) (4.17 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to defend the integrity of this minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a good minister in a good government

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been good for Australia. The mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Brisbane said, ‘If we had been in

Speaker: NA
Text: government'-well, if you had been in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, heaven help us. The minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed that we not censure the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Workplace Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business-because he does not de-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve censure-but instead censure the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition.

Speaker: NA
Text: During his very emotive diatribe, the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: lix Leader of the Opposition said of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, ‘This is not how Australia is sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to be governed'. We are governing

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia fearlessly, free of outside influence,

Speaker: NA
Text: free of domination by outside organisations,

Speaker: NA
Text: free of financial influence by financial sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters of our two great political parties-

Speaker: NA
Text: free of all that. But what would we have if

Speaker: NA
Text: Jennie George was successful? Who would

Speaker: NA
Text: we have sitting on the Treasury benches on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House if, at the next election,

Speaker: NA
Text: the prolix Leader of the Opposition managed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be successful? We would have three for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mer ACTU presidents sitting on the front

Speaker: NA
Text: bench, occupying the Treasury benches,

Speaker: NA
Text: dominating cabinet and using trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to determine the policy position and

Speaker: NA
Text: parameters of any Beazley led Labor gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. That does not sound to me like the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that I want Australia governed, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, and I suspect that you

Speaker: NA
Text: would not want it governed that way either,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I know that the Australian people do not.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will tell you about this censure motion. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a lot of hot air, hype and hyperbole. We

Speaker: NA
Text: minhave fire and brimstone leading really to no

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome. All this contrived pity and concern

Speaker: NA
Text: for so-called ordinary Australians is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: but a contrivance. Labor had 13 years to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring in a scheme to protect employee enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlements. This is an important national issue;

Speaker: NA
Text: I accept that and I have participated in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate over a number of years in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: and outside it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have essentially a range of options to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with the problem of a company that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes bankrupt, becomes insolvent, ceases to

Speaker: NA
Text: trade and has not the funds in the bank to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: nor the assets to support paying workers their

Speaker: NA
Text: legal entitlements, including pay, holiday

Speaker: NA
Text: pay, accrued long service leave and redun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dancy funds agreed to in their workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement-that is, whatever built-up enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlements there are. If the company goes

Speaker: NA
Text: broke and cannot pay those, it is right and

Speaker: NA
Text: proper that that money should be paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: those individuals. One of the problems is this

Speaker: NA
Text: question: ‘Why don't you amend the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany law and put employees first in front of

Speaker: NA
Text: secured creditors?' Even the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: have not proposed that. In their 13 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: benign neglect on this issue, they certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: never proposed that. The reason they did not

Speaker: NA
Text: was that we would have a great deal of diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty in attracting investment in viable in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and commerce to this country, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have the jobs that we need to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port Australians and the jobs that Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: want to support themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: Putting employee entitlements at the top

Speaker: NA
Text: of the list just is not viable. We have a few

Speaker: NA
Text: other options. We could ask the taxpayers to

Speaker: NA
Text: pick up the bill on behalf of their fellow

Speaker: NA
Text: zens for the very few who actually lose their

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs when companies dissolve, become in-

Speaker: NA
Text: solvent, cease trading and do not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to pay out what they legally owe to the

Speaker: NA
Text: employees, and where the liquidator or ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministrator is unable to recover funds from

Speaker: NA
Text: the personal accounts of the directors of the

Speaker: NA
Text: companies to help cover what the employees

Speaker: NA
Text: are owed. So we can say that the public

Speaker: NA
Text: purse is the right and proper place for that to

Speaker: NA
Text: occur and that such payment would have the

Speaker: NA
Text: least total effect on Australian society as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole and particularly on Australian busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness, which we need to sustain employment

Speaker: NA
Text: and our great lifestyle. That is, in fact, what

Speaker: NA
Text: the government scheme is all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, except for South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the Northern Territory, the states

Speaker: NA
Text: have not come on board for this scheme. So

Speaker: NA
Text: employees of those companies which have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone under, and where there have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient funds to pay out what they owed,

Speaker: NA
Text: will receive a payment from the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth government. But do they see also a

Speaker: NA
Text: corresponding payment from the state Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: governments which are ideologically driven

Speaker: NA
Text: to support the Leader of the Opposition? The

Speaker: NA
Text: answer is no, they do not. The states have not

Speaker: NA
Text: come on board the scheme, and that makes it

Speaker: NA
Text: less than desirable. So if a company goes

Speaker: NA
Text: belly up in South Australia, those workers

Speaker: NA
Text: can be assured that they are going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: much better taken care of than their compa-

Speaker: NA
Text: triots in the states of Victoria and New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales or, for that matter, Queensland and

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I asked the minister in question time today

Speaker: NA
Text: whether there are other proposals around.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are. One proposal is to have a national

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance scheme for all industry. Every vi-

Speaker: NA
Text: able company, those that are doing the right

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, trading profitably, paying their taxes,

Speaker: NA
Text: paying their employees, have good safety

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and are contributing to the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian economy and the welfare and benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: all of us, would have to kick in for the few

Speaker: NA
Text: rotten eggs in the barrel. I do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the best way to approach the issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it would be one heck of a lot less expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive than this Manusafe scheme, that is for

Speaker: NA
Text: sure. I am advised that were we to put one-

Speaker: NA
Text: cititenth of one per cent into a national insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance scheme of all companies-which I

Speaker: NA
Text: think is what the Australian Labor Party are

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing, but I am not real clear because I

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been able to read their policy any-

Speaker: NA
Text: where-that would cost industry some $250

Speaker: NA
Text: million a year. I am also advised, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: that if this Manusafe scheme promoted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the AMWU were imposed in the manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing industry alone, that would cost those

Speaker: NA
Text: companies $550 million a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Danby-What about the $700,000 in-

Speaker: NA
Text: surance bond?

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Text: How much employment

Speaker: NA
Text: do you get for 550 million bucks? You get a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot, don't you? I am also advised that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: government scheme were fully implemented,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the states joined the scheme and everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: came on board, we took care of all those

Speaker: NA
Text: companies that went under and there was no

Speaker: NA
Text: sudden national catastrophe like a flood or

Speaker: NA
Text: drought, the cost would be in the order of

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 million. So we are talking peanuts to

Speaker: NA
Text: megabucks. Guess who wants to spend the

Speaker: NA
Text: megabucks? The Labor Party and the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement to whom the Labor Party is

Speaker: NA
Text: beholden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Danby-What about the firm that had

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay megabucks this week? Tell us about

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance bond they had to pay?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Nehl)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Melbourne Ports!

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Text: The individual compa-

Speaker: NA
Text: nies do have another option. They could cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate trust funds, couldn't they? Each of them

Speaker: NA
Text: could create an individual trust fund for its

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I tell you that if you take that

Speaker: NA
Text: much money out of the economy, put it into

Speaker: NA
Text: trusts and lock it up, so you cannot invest it

Speaker: NA
Text: and you cannot use it for productive pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses, you will make Australian industry less

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive than it should be. I point out to

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite that the last two reports on

Speaker: NA
Text: trade balances have been absolutely out-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing: two quarters in a row where we

Speaker: NA
Text: sold more to the rest of the world than we

Speaker: NA
Text: bought from the rest of the world. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: not quite made it with the current account

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit yet because we still have not paid

Speaker: NA
Text: back all the money that the Hawke and

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating governments borrowed over 13

Speaker: NA
Text: years, but we have made a $60 million dent

Speaker: NA
Text: in it. When we get that wound down, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: can keep going the way we are going in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of our trade balance, we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: solved the balance of payments problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is positive. But if we accept

Speaker: NA
Text: union scheme called Manusafe, to take 1.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the wages bill of every company

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country and lock it up in an unpro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductive fund, we are asking for those com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies to be less productive, to employ fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: people, to pay less in the way of taxes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Danby-What happened to Tristar?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Ports is warned.

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Text: That mob over there is

Speaker: NA
Text: the high taxing lot-high taxing and high

Speaker: NA
Text: spending. That is what Labor governments

Speaker: NA
Text: always do-rake the money in and spend it

Speaker: NA
Text: as fast you can. But I tell you that you cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: rake it in if you cannot collect the taxes be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the companies are not profitable. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996, when the coalition came to govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, we have had a remarkable turnaround

Speaker: NA
Text: in improvement in real wages for working

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. I am proud of that. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have any accord with the ACTU, no accord

Speaker: NA
Text: with the trade union movement. What we

Speaker: NA
Text: have got instead is individuals out there im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving their companies' productivity and

Speaker: NA
Text: the companies rewarding them with better

Speaker: NA
Text: wages, better conditions and a better living,

Speaker: NA
Text: and everybody is happy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will tell my friends on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House something: when you get to the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign, tell your constituents what

Speaker: NA
Text: has happened to their standard of living, to

Speaker: NA
Text: their real wages, to their comfort zone, to

Speaker: NA
Text: their interest rates and to a well run economy

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1996, and then ask them if they really

Speaker: NA
Text: want to trust that mob over there who want

Speaker: NA
Text: to get stuck into their pockets again. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what this debate is all about. This debate is

Speaker: NA
Text: an attempt to censure a good minister, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is nothing but a phoney debate, because what

Speaker: NA
Text: they are on about is trying to sneak their way

Speaker: NA
Text: into government so the ACTU can come

Speaker: NA
Text: back and try to run the country again. If that

Speaker: NA
Text: happened, we would have secret deals with

Speaker: NA
Text: the ACTU, and we would have three former

Speaker: NA
Text: presidents of the ACTU sitting right here on

Speaker: NA
Text: the government front benches. Really, can

Speaker: NA
Text: you imagine one of them, Simon Crean, run-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning Treasury? I cannot for the life of me

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine that that would be a scenario that

Speaker: NA
Text: this idiotic Australians could embrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a debate we did not really need to

Speaker: NA
Text: have today. We should be talking about the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. If I remember rightly, the opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion were going to propose the following

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance today:

Speaker: NA
Text: The failure-

Speaker: NA
Text: or the so-called failure-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government to adequately protect the liv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing standards and economic security of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families.

Speaker: NA
Text: No wonder the opposition tried to get out of

Speaker: NA
Text: that. They would have looked pretty silly

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to debate that issue, wouldn't they? I

Speaker: NA
Text: can just imagine that debate going out over

Speaker: NA
Text: the airwaves and all those hundreds of thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands of Australians listening on PNN to it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: can just imagine them trying to figure what

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Prolix' was on about with his statements

Speaker: NA
Text: that we had a ‘poor economy, poor living

Speaker: NA
Text: standards and terrible interest rates'. Oh, my

Speaker: NA
Text: goodness, we should wring our hands,

Speaker: NA
Text: shouldn't we!

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Employment, Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations and Small Business is a good min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister. He follows a good minister before him

Speaker: NA
Text: in the portfolio. This is a good government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It governs for all Australians, not just the

Speaker: NA
Text: select and privileged few who happen to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: big money into the coffers of the ALP-

Speaker: NA
Text: money which happens to largely come out of

Speaker: NA
Text: union dues by the overencouragement of

Speaker: NA
Text: people to join trade unions. Even though we

Speaker: NA
Text: are supposed to have got past the ‘no ticket,

Speaker: NA
Text: no start' situation, we have not quite got

Speaker: NA
Text: there yet. One of these days, perhaps we will.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will be delighted when that day comes, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I will be delighted when the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has the guts and the intestinal

Speaker: NA
Text: fortitude to divorce his political party from a

Speaker: NA
Text: labour movement that is doing no good for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I congratulate the minister on the

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent job that he is doing, and I support

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment to the censure motion. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Question put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendment ( Mr Abbott's) be agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House divided. [4.36 p.m.]
