Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Brand-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (4.43 p.m.)- Mr Speaker, I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: In the course of his re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks in answer to a question in question

Speaker: NA
Text: time, the Treasurer indicated that I had an

Speaker: NA
Text: intention to impose a levy in order to support

Speaker: NA
Text: Knowledge Nation activities. We have no

Speaker: NA
Text: such intention planned, secret or otherwise.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a completely incorrect allegation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I have a second matter.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: In the course of his re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks, the Minister for Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted from a transcript, allegedly of mine,

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that I was ‘bound for the Lodge'. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that was the expression he used, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: used it as a direct quote. That was an answer

Speaker: NA
Text: from me to a question: ‘Do you intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: live, if you are Prime Minister, in Kirribilli

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Lodge?' to which I responded, ‘The

Speaker: NA
Text: Lodge.'

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: Dickson) (4.45 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: I wish to complete the

Speaker: NA
Text: incomplete quotation that the minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: employment attributed to me.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: No. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dickson must indicate where she was mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: represented in order for me to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: whether she has a matter of misrepresenta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that she can correct.

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: I have two matters. One

Speaker: NA
Text: is on what I said on the Meet the Press pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I am in no way seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: to frustrate the member for Dickson. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to indicate to her that she must indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate where she was misrepresented.

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: I am trying to do that, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. Obviously I misunderstand you.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister incompletely quoted from a

Speaker: NA
Text: transcript of the program, which leads to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong conclusion in the point he was mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It does not support the conclusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I do not need the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of assistance I am getting from both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the House. I am endeavouring to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist the member for Dickson. I suggest to

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Dickson that if she cares to

Speaker: NA
Text: consult with the Leader of the Opposition or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition I will

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise her in a few minutes.

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: Melbourne Ports) (4.46

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)- Mr Speaker, I wish to make a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: On Tuesday in question

Speaker: NA
Text: time the minister for education made the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: likely claim that I was not supporting schools

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate. He asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: How is the member for Melbourne Ports ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaining his decision to risk payments of $16,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to Alia College?

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the minister's own document

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘New schools payment of establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: grants', the Alia School, item 16610, is in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact located at 13 Victoria Road, East Haw-

Speaker: NA
Text: thorn. That is in the electorate of Kooyong,

Speaker: NA
Text: not in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions on Notice

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, under standing order 150, would

Speaker: NA
Text: you mind writing to the Treasurer asking for

Speaker: NA
Text: an explanation for delay in responding to

Speaker: NA
Text: questions No. 2223 placed on the Notice Pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: per on 6 December 2000 and No. 2430

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on the Notice Paper on 6 March this

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I will follow up the

Speaker: NA
Text: matters as the standing orders provide.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: Dickson) (4.48 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Ms KERNOT
Text: I have two matters, the

Speaker: NA
Text: first one being the minister's assertion that I

Speaker: NA
Text: supported the Manusafe scheme. I quote

Speaker: NA
Text: from my words:

Speaker: NA
Text: No, we don't, because it is only for one industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are still pushing for our national scheme, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a 0.1 per cent levy added to the superannu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation guarantee charge.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the second point, the minister's asser-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that I supported an illegal strike, I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to add to the incomplete quotation he used:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... and they are only striking in a period in which

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation allows them to-a fixed term for en-

Speaker: NA
Text: terprise bargaining.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I am happy to hear from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House if he wishes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! I would remind

Speaker: NA
Text: all members of the House of their status in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: MCMillan) (4.49 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: Yes, on two separate occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: On 27 June in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Forestry and Conservation

Speaker: NA
Text: accused me of not knowing anything in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the FISAP program and of not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding any assistance to my constituents in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to that program. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Members from Victoria are currently given appliresume

Speaker: NA
Text: cants information and asking them if they can

Speaker: NA
Text: offer assistance-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan will resume his seat. I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith- Mr Speaker, my understand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is that where a person wishes to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: leave under this process they must do so in a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably timely and expeditious way, and

Speaker: NA
Text: 27 June is going back a while and we were

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting after that.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Given that the House in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact did not sit in July, I would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that the member for MCMillan's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quest was unreasonable. I would, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: require the member for MCMillan to come

Speaker: NA
Text: instantly to the point where he was misrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: His problem is that he did not know, and, worse, answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: he did not care.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 9 September 1999 I organised a briefing

Speaker: NA
Text: in my office on the Victorian Forest Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Structural Adjustment Program, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: circulated to all timber mills and forest in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries in my electorate, thus proving the

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to be incorrect.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan need prove nothing. He has indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated where he was misrepresented. He will

Speaker: NA
Text: come to the next item.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: I have a second instance

Speaker: NA
Text: where I have been misrepresented. In ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion time today the Minister for Forestry and

Speaker: NA
Text: Conservation suggested that I had received

Speaker: NA
Text: money from the union which covers workers

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Maryvale plant of PaperlinX. The

Speaker: NA
Text: main union which covers workers in that

Speaker: NA
Text: plant is the Pulp and Paper Workers Union

Speaker: NA
Text: Branch of the Forestry Division of the

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU. I have never received one single

Speaker: NA
Text: cent from this union, and the implication that

Speaker: NA
Text: the money from that-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan will resume his seat.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: union has been used to

Speaker: NA
Text: buy-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan is now insulting the chair and will

Speaker: NA
Text: his seat or I will deal with him. I en-

Speaker: NA
Text: deavour to be helpful to the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan. I do not expect the response to be

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse of the standing orders.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions on Notice

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Text: 4.51 p.m.)- Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: question No. 2622 to the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the dishonesty or incompetence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lowe

Speaker: NA
Text: does not need to indicate what the question

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to-merely the number and the date

Speaker: NA
Text: on which it was submitted.

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Text: On 4 June it appeared on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Notice Paper re Dr Mal Colston. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: be very, very grateful if you would write to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attorney-General and seek reasons why

Speaker: NA
Text: he has not replied to that question, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the public interest is screaming out for an

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I will follow up the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter as the standing orders provide. I, too,

Speaker: NA
Text: would be very, very grateful for a somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: more succinct reference to standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: Member for MCMillan: Misrepresentation

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: 4.52 p.m.)-I have a

Speaker: NA
Text: question of you, Mr Speaker. It arises out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement which has just been made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for MCMillan relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresentation of his position during

Speaker: NA
Text: question time. You have witnessed the events

Speaker: NA
Text: that took place today-you have heard it all.

Speaker: NA
Text: You heard the minister not just misrepresent

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for MCMillan but, in fact, tell a

Speaker: NA
Text: very direct lie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith interjecting-

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: Excuse me. I am asking

Speaker: NA
Text: a question-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Burke

Speaker: NA
Text: will be required to resume his seat and not be

Speaker: NA
Text: heard at all unless he learns to direct his re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks through the chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith- Mr Speaker, I ask that the al-

Speaker: NA
Text: legation be withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House makes a reasonable request. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Burke will withdraw the impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation that a member lied to him deliberately.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: Mr Speaker, I seek your

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance on this. I am not attempting to defy

Speaker: NA
Text: your ruling. If you insist I withdraw, I will.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I did not say that the minister was a liar.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Crosio interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Member for Prospect,

Speaker: NA
Text: as an occupier of the chair, how can you pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibly not understand the fundamental courte-

Speaker: NA
Text: sies that the standing orders oblige all of us

Speaker: NA
Text: to exercise one to the other?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith- Mr Speaker, my point of or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der is that you have asked the member to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw. Under the guise of discussing your

Speaker: NA
Text: request, he simply attempts to repeat the al-

Speaker: NA
Text: legations he has made in a different way. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask you, as a matter of fairness, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: that he not be allowed to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Crosio-I raise a point of order, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. Further to the point of order as

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by the Leader of the House, the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that I uttered and was reprimanded by

Speaker: NA
Text: you for, sir, was: how can the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House take a point of order on the member in

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament who questioned what your

Speaker: NA
Text: direction would be?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is not assisting the chair. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Prospect is well aware that one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of the House designed, in fact, to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tect the dignity of the House and the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the chair exercises its decisions at all

Speaker: NA
Text: times is the facility that members have to

Speaker: NA
Text: take points of order, a facility that I think is

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes abused. It does not alter the obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation that I have to hear any point of order.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: As I was saying-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I will deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Burke. I do not need any help

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Leader of the House unless he re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quests it from the dispatch box.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: This situation, as you

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard and as the member for MCMillan

Speaker: NA
Text: has attempted to cover under the standing

Speaker: NA
Text: orders, is what I would describe as more than

Speaker: NA
Text: a misrepresentation; it is a very direct state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that was an untruth. As such, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCMillan has stood-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ronaldson- Mr Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. You have made a quite spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cific request for the member for Burke to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw the comment which you found un-

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary. It is not a matter that requires

Speaker: NA
Text: debate; it is a matter that requires immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Burke

Speaker: NA
Text: was, in fact, directing a question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. I was endeavouring, in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of impartiality, as do all occupiers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair, to hear him out. He would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitating the chair by being succinct with

Speaker: NA
Text: his question instead of deliberately drawing

Speaker: NA
Text: it out, and there are members on my right

Speaker: NA
Text: who would facilitate the chair by allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: me to get to the point at which I can rule on

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Burke's point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith- Mr Speaker, you said quite

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically that it was appropriate for him to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw and, under the conventions of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House, when people are asked to withdraw

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not stand and say ‘if this' and ‘if

Speaker: NA
Text: that'. This is simply an abuse of an opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity provided to members-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bevis interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Bris-

Speaker: NA
Text: bane is warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-to ask the Speaker questions

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to matters within the Speaker's ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministration. This is yet another example of a

Speaker: NA
Text: question designed to go over a matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: had arisen during question time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Adams interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lyons

Speaker: NA
Text: is also warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-I ask you, Mr Speaker, in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: formity with your request, that you confirm

Speaker: NA
Text: your request for him to withdraw; otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: he should be asked to be seated.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: I am very happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw if that will assist you and will en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able me to complete the question I am asking

Speaker: NA
Text: of you. Do you want me to withdraw?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I do require the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Burke to withdraw. I thought I had made

Speaker: NA
Text: that perfectly evident all of about 10 minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: ago.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: I withdraw.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke's question is?

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: The question that I was

Speaker: NA
Text: three-quarters of the way through was: in this

Speaker: NA
Text: situation where it was not just a misrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation but a very direct untruth-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. This question is totally inappropriate.

Speaker: NA
Text: This member is attempting to make a debat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing point against a minister. That is an incorpressing

Speaker: NA
Text: rect form. If people want to make substantive

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations, the standing orders make it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: how they should so proceed. I put it to you

Speaker: NA
Text: that this question is totally out of order and

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be countenanced.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Burke

Speaker: NA
Text: will succinctly come to his point, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently getting very drawn out.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: I am asking for guidance

Speaker: NA
Text: from you, Mr Speaker, about a member who

Speaker: NA
Text: correctly used the standing orders provided

Speaker: NA
Text: to correct a misrepresentation, as occurred,

Speaker: NA
Text: but was required by you to conclude at the

Speaker: NA
Text: point at which you felt he had corrected the

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresentation. When that misrepresenta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is very serious and is, in fact, more

Speaker: NA
Text: a misrepresentation, I believe it is in order

Speaker: NA
Text: for the member to be given the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to more fully explain his situation. I am ask-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing you: would you give consideration to

Speaker: NA
Text: some further scope for the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan to fully complete his rebuttal of

Speaker: NA
Text: the untruth made about him?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ronaldson-The cattle will be put-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting bacon and eggs on for breakfast if this

Speaker: NA
Text: keeps on going-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Chief Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip will resume his seat. If ever there was

Speaker: NA
Text: an exercise in absolute absurdity, the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia just witnessed it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'Keefe interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Burke

Speaker: NA
Text: is warned. I am on my feet. If the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Burke was seriously asking me whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not I am in fact prepared to intervene to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent people freely expressing their view

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber, the answer is no. I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: facility, nor does any other occupier of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair have any facility, to pass judgment on

Speaker: NA
Text: the accuracy of what is being said. This

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber is built on the fundamental right of

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody's right to an opinion and the right

Speaker: NA
Text: to be heard, and on the responsibility they of

Speaker: NA
Text: course have to exercise those rights in a way

Speaker: NA
Text: that they believe is entirely honourable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have in no way thwarted the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the member for MCMillan to express a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view under the standing orders, nor

Speaker: NA
Text: will I in any way prevent a minister ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of view under the standing

Speaker: NA
Text: orders, so long as both expressions are en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely parliamentary. To do otherwise would

Speaker: NA
Text: be to put at risk the whole system of free

Speaker: NA
Text: speech and the whole system of parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary privilege on which this institution is

Speaker: NA
Text: founded. That fundamental lesson must be

Speaker: NA
Text: understood by everybody in this chamber,

Speaker: NA
Text: almost prior to election.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask, on be-

Speaker: NA
Text: half of Mr Zahra, indulgence from you. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Zahra has effectively been accused of cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruption by the minister. He said he received a

Speaker: NA
Text: donation and then certain things followed

Speaker: NA
Text: and certain behaviours were expected of him.

Speaker: NA
Text: It appears the donation was not made. That

Speaker: NA
Text: than was a very serious allegation and I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: under indulgence, he ought to be allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer it.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I would point out-be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore I recognise anybody-to the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition that, as he would have ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected, the member for MCMillan was not

Speaker: NA
Text: only able to correct any misrepresentation

Speaker: NA
Text: but indicated that no donation had been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived. The provision under the standing

Speaker: NA
Text: orders to correct a misrepresentation had

Speaker: NA
Text: been fully and appropriately discharged. I at

Speaker: NA
Text: no stage obliged the member for MCMillan

Speaker: NA
Text: to resume his seat until he entered into a

Speaker: NA
Text: ond area which had, from what I could see,

Speaker: NA
Text: no further resemblance to whatever he was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying because he had made it perfectly clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that he had not been in receipt of any dona-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The Hansard will reinforce that point.

Speaker: NA
Text: Member for MCMillan: Misrepresentation

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: 5.03 p.m.)-I have a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to you, Mr Speaker. In question time

Speaker: NA
Text: today, you said, and I wrote it down, that you

Speaker: NA
Text: will not tolerate anybody at the dispatch box

Speaker: NA
Text: being deliberately deceitful. I would argue

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this instance the Minister for Forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: and Conservation has been deliberately de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceitful.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan will resume his seat. As any

Speaker: NA
Text: reader of the standing orders is well aware-

Speaker: NA
Text: and anyone who cares to peruse House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Practice-no-one comes

Speaker: NA
Text: into this House and has any opportunity to be

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately deceitful. I will not enter into

Speaker: NA
Text: any further negotiation, argument or discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of this matter as referred by the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for MCMillan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith- Mr Speaker, I ask that the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement made by the member for MCMillan

Speaker: NA
Text: be withdrawn. ‘Deliberately deceitful' is

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly unparliamentary and it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: Mr Speaker, the question

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was going to ask-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan will withdraw the inference.

Speaker: Mr ZAHRA
Text: I withdraw, Mr Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I had not asked you the question

Speaker: NA
Text: which I wanted to ask you before you asked

Speaker: NA
Text: me to resume my seat. I would counter in

Speaker: NA
Text: this instance that the minister has made this

Speaker: NA
Text: implication of me-it is a substantial allega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of corruption-and he has provided no

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence at all in his remarks.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan will resume his seat. The matter

Speaker: NA
Text: has been dealt with. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan has, as the standing orders pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide, had the opportunity to ensure that any

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresentation has been corrected. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not believe there is any need for any further

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Seyffer, Mr John: Parliamentary Pass

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Text: 5.05 p.m.)-Earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: secthis week, Mr Speaker, I asked you a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion regarding the request for a security pass

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr John Seyffer and you said you would

Speaker: NA
Text: come back to the House with that informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Are you in a position to be able to give

Speaker: NA
Text: us that information before the House rises

Speaker: NA
Text: today?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: In response to the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Whip's question, I can indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have made inquiries and that details on

Speaker: NA
Text: pass application forms and pass usage are

Speaker: NA
Text: confidential. That is hardly surprising be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of course they are kept confidential in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to protect the privacy of pass holders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such detail can only be released on the

Speaker: NA
Text: authority of the security controller and is

Speaker: NA
Text: only released in relation to serious security

Speaker: NA
Text: threats to the parliament or the occupants of

Speaker: NA
Text: the building. The request by the Chief Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Whip for information on a pass which

Speaker: NA
Text: may have been issued to Mr Seyffer does not

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be in relation to a serious security

Speaker: NA
Text: threat and therefore such details, if they ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ist, cannot be provided.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Text: Mr Speaker, do I

Speaker: NA
Text: take it from your answer then that a pass has

Speaker: NA
Text: been issued to Mr Seyffer?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: In response to the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Whip, I have no idea whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: pass has or has not at any time in his occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pancy of the chair or mine been issued to Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Seyffer.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Text: Would you ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain from the security controller whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: request for a pass for Mr Seyffer was made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister for Sport and Tourism?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have no intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: taking the matter any further, as there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: threat to the building's security in this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular instance or the security of occupants

Speaker: NA
Text: of the building.

Speaker: NA
Text: Member for MCMillan: Misrepresentation

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: 5.07 p.m.)- Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a further question to you. While it re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lates to the matter we were discussing earlier,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in a different context, and I am hastening

Speaker: NA
Text: to assure you of that before I ask it. Given

Speaker: NA
Text: what you have ruled in relation to what was

Speaker: NA
Text: stated and the member for MCMillan's op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to respond to it, my question to you

Speaker: NA
Text: is: what forms of the parliament are available

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rest of today that would enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCMillan to have what you

Speaker: NA
Text: would call a fair and equal opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: In the time that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in this parliament-in fact I am bold

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to suggest in the time the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has been in this parliament-

Speaker: NA
Text: the forms provided today are the same forms

Speaker: NA
Text: for directing misrepresentation as have been

Speaker: NA
Text: available for the member for MCMillan to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day, and he has discharged them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Seyffer, Mr John: Parliamentary Pass

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Text: 5.08 p.m.)-I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: pull up on the question asked by the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Whip, Mr Speaker. The normal

Speaker: NA
Text: process by which questions are asked to you

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to questions of administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. Classically, questions of admini-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration of a department go to whether this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular activity occurred within that de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment and, if so, who was responsible, et

Speaker: NA
Text: cetera. Unless it is commercial-in-confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: or national security, the proper course is for

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister to supply an answer. On what

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds are you saying to the Chief Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Whip that an inquiry as to whether an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual has received a pass and whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister for sport was the person who

Speaker: NA
Text: applied for that pass is not a proper matter to

Speaker: NA
Text: be answered to this House and not a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: matter about which the House is entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: gain information from you? I do not under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the basis upon which you think this is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a proper question to which you ought

Speaker: NA
Text: give a reply to the House.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have nothing to add to

Speaker: NA
Text: my earlier comments as recorded in Han-

Speaker: NA
Text: sard. The issuing of passes is a confidential

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. It has been for successive Speakers in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, certainly for as long as we have

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied this building and, I suspect, for as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as we occupied the former building-as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as passes have been issued. While we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been in this building it has been a mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter that is kept in confidence. It is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: business of anyone who comes and goes

Speaker: NA
Text: from this building or signs someone in or out

Speaker: NA
Text: of this building unless matters of security are

Speaker: NA
Text: at risk. The matter referred to by the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Whip is not deemed to be a mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of building or personal security. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent, I gather, with rulings made by my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors on the advice that I have from

Speaker: NA
Text: the security office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Seyffer, Mr John: Parliamentary Pass

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, is it a fact that photographic secu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity passes which are issued to people in this

Speaker: NA
Text: building have the name of the person, the

Speaker: NA
Text: person's photograph and the office that that

Speaker: NA
Text: person is working in on the front of the pass?

Speaker: NA
Text: How can it be commercial-in-confidence or a

Speaker: NA
Text: private matter if the person's office is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: front of the pass accompanied by their pho-

Speaker: NA
Text: tograph?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: As I have indicated to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, my response is entirely consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the actions taken by previous occupiers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the chair. If there is any inconsistency, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will come back to the Chief Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip and report to him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Text: 5.11 p.m.)-During ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion time today the Minister for Foreign Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fairs was blowing kisses and using offensive

Speaker: NA
Text: hand movements to me across the chamber. I

Speaker: NA
Text: and the member for Franklin found it very

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive, and I would like to know if it is

Speaker: NA
Text: unparliamentary. As you are aware, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I have seen you privately regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: the actions of the Minister for Foreign Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fairs towards me in this chamber, and I now

Speaker: NA
Text: raise it publicly.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: standing orders specifically cover the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which gestures may or may not be passed

Speaker: NA
Text: between members across the chamber, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: have in fact, as the member for Fowler

Speaker: NA
Text: knows, raised the issue she is concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about with the Minister for Foreign Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I would intervene again if I felt he was

Speaker: NA
Text: doing something that was offensive. If what

Speaker: NA
Text: she alleged occurred, my failure to intervene

Speaker: NA
Text: is simply because I did not see the minister.

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Text: I do appreciate that. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would be wonderful if we could see it on the

Speaker: NA
Text: video. He was actually doing the same thing

Speaker: NA
Text: to me in this chamber as he did-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The member for Fowler

Speaker: NA
Text: will resume her seat.

Text: Families: Government Policy

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have received a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Leader of the Opposition proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: that a definite matter of public importance be

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted to the House for discussion,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The failure of the Government to adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the living standards and economic security

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian families.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Works Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: Fisher-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Finance and

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration) (5.18 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, in accordance with the provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Public Works for consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration and report: Proposed Christmas Island

Speaker: NA
Text: common-use infrastructure items.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of Transport and Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Services proposes to upgrade common-use

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure to support the proposed space

Speaker: NA
Text: centre project on Christmas Island. The pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed upgrade will be in the form of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provements to the airport, a new freight off-

Speaker: NA
Text: loading facility on the east coast and a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: necting road. Australia needs to pursue ag-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressively strategic investment proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: which help ensure Australia acquires leading

Speaker: NA
Text: edge technologies and skills that help de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velop and add value to our resources. In so

Speaker: NA
Text: doing, sometimes there may be a need to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide specific incentives to secure a strateconsultation

Speaker: NA
Text: gic investment for Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The airport improvements include runway

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening, reconstruction and extension

Speaker: NA
Text: of the southern end by 500 metres, taxiway

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion and new emergency services. This

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrade is required to enable use by Boeing

Speaker: NA
Text: 747s, Antonovs, Airbus and Beluga aircraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new freight off-loading port facility is

Speaker: NA
Text: be constructed on the east coast. Predomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nantly during the wet season the swell runs

Speaker: NA
Text: in from the north-west and forces the closure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the current port facilities. This new loca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will allow for all year off-loading of

Speaker: NA
Text: ships and will save the community the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: convenience and cost of delay to ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: An upgraded road from the new freight

Speaker: NA
Text: off-loading facility to Lily Beach Road is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be constructed. This will provide a safe ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess from the alternative port and will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the bypass of the main settlement areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: minimising impact on the local community

Speaker: NA
Text: of the transport of industrial or dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: goods. The upgrading of the common-use

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure would achieve the following. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would support the objectives of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for Christmas Island. It would provide

Speaker: NA
Text: all-weather port infrastructure, which will

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid the costly carryover of freight at the

Speaker: NA
Text: current port facilities during the wet season

Speaker: NA
Text: shutdown. It would allow for a more flexible

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to air services for the Indian Ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories by increased strength and length

Speaker: NA
Text: of runway. It would secure for Australia the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's first commercially constructed satel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lite launch facility, which would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: dation for an Australian space industry, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it would create shortand long-term job op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunities for the local community to help

Speaker: NA
Text: relieve unemployment and develop the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: base on the island.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed upgrades are designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: balance the commercial and social benefit to

Speaker: NA
Text: all Christmas Islanders in this unique Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth territory. The proposed upgrades

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be designed to ensure the new infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure balances the commercial and social

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits with the optimal protection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: marine and terrestrial environment. All

Speaker: NA
Text: works will be undertaken to ensure that any

Speaker: NA
Text: potential environmental damage to the area

Speaker: NA
Text: is minimised. A comprehensive community

Speaker: NA
Text: program will be implemented

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the planning and development

Speaker: NA
Text: stages of the proposed common-use infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure upgrading and will involve the

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas Island administration,

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders and the local community. The

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated cost of the common-use infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure upgrade is $68.6 million. Subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: to parliamentary approval, tenders are sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: uled to be called for in the first half of the

Speaker: NA
Text: next year. I commend the motion to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Northern Territory)

Speaker: NA
Text: (5.22 p.m.)-I wish to add some comments to

Speaker: NA
Text: those which have been made by the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Secretary to the Minister for Fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nance and Administration. I should point out

Speaker: NA
Text: that he has made a mistake: the estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of the common-use infrastructure up-

Speaker: NA
Text: grade is $68.6 million, not $68.0 million.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: I said $68.6 million.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: No, you did not-but,

Speaker: NA
Text: in any event, we will fix it up.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Both members are

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the courtesy which requires them to

Speaker: NA
Text: address their remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: On behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community of Christmas Island, I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased as their federal member to welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposal of the Department of Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: and Regional Services to upgrade common-

Speaker: NA
Text: use infrastructure to support the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: space centre on Christmas Island. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: the community do not want to be hostage to

Speaker: NA
Text: foun- the APSC or the federal government while

Speaker: NA
Text: all the while being assured that things will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen. It is their view that the upgrades and

Speaker: NA
Text: new facilities should happen anyway.

Speaker: NA
Text: The community know from experience

Speaker: NA
Text: that talk about the future development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: island is often cheap. They have already

Speaker: NA
Text: waited over three years for some action to

Speaker: NA
Text: reopen the resort/casino. They have been

Speaker: NA
Text: kept waiting with assurances that it is likely

Speaker: NA
Text: that the resort will reopen as a casino, but to

Speaker: NA
Text: date nothing has happened. Yet, just this

Speaker: NA
Text: week, in the Senate on Tuesday evening,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Lightfoot said that the resort will

Speaker: NA
Text: used for accommodation for the 400 people

Speaker: NA
Text: required to establish the space facility. A

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary view has, of course, been expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: because there has been a suggestion that a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of houses were built on another site

Speaker: NA
Text: on the island. The question of the casino re-

Speaker: NA
Text: opening is still up in the air. Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: foot did not know, and he is the Chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Joint Standing Committee on the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Capital and External Territories, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which Christmas Island is a part. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity do not want the same thing to happen

Speaker: NA
Text: with this infrastructure upgrade. Given what

Speaker: NA
Text: has happened on the island in recent years,

Speaker: NA
Text: the community is entitled to be suspicious. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have spoken before about the need for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Christmas Island to be kept fully

Speaker: NA
Text: informed and to be involved in all aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: developments concerning the island commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. The consultation process has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate to date, and I have commented

Speaker: NA
Text: about this in this place. Indeed, the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible has done nothing but treat the

Speaker: NA
Text: island community with contempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I want to emphasise the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Christmas Island often do

Speaker: NA
Text: without what other Australians take for

Speaker: NA
Text: granted. That is why the community wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes the $68.6 million for the upgrade of

Speaker: NA
Text: the common-use facilities which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: identified. They should be going ahead re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gardless of the progress of government ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: gotiations over the space facility. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal for a new freight off-loading port

Speaker: NA
Text: facility to be constructed on the east coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would be most welcomed by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. For three months of the year the

Speaker: NA
Text: community is at the mercy of what the local

Speaker: NA
Text: calls the ‘swirly season', when the current

Speaker: NA
Text: port may be closed due to ocean swells. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the mainland we have come to depend on

Speaker: NA
Text: overnight services for all manner of deliver-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies: mail, spare parts for cars, commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: and industrial equipment, important docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, et cetera. On Christmas Island there

Speaker: NA
Text: a weekly service if the people are lucky-the

Speaker: NA
Text: swirls may close the port and the weekly air

Speaker: NA
Text: service carries limited freight that may be

Speaker: NA
Text: offloaded in Perth because of some emer-

Speaker: NA
Text: gency such as a medical priority. The people

Speaker: NA
Text: on Christmas Island can wait weeks for basic

Speaker: NA
Text: services. A restaurant can be left with no

Speaker: NA
Text: be bulk supply of flour. The photocopier can be

Speaker: NA
Text: inoperable due to the lack of a $5 part. The

Speaker: NA
Text: list goes on and on. An all-weather port is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed now for the people of Christmas Is-

Speaker: NA
Text: land-it is long overdue. It is the same story

Speaker: NA
Text: with the airstrip. With or without the space

Speaker: NA
Text: facility, there is a need for an upgrade for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lightreasons of tourism, defence and general

Speaker: NA
Text: emergencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Remember that this is a community of

Speaker: NA
Text: some 1,500 people who, every few weeks,

Speaker: NA
Text: can be expected to play host to a large num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of unauthorised immigrants-sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: numbered in the hundreds-who put an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous strain on the existing resources of

Speaker: NA
Text: the island. Imagine what would happen if the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT had an extra 50,000 suddenly appear in

Speaker: NA
Text: the community with immediate human needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of food and shelter. Proportionately, this is

Speaker: NA
Text: what happens on Christmas Island-the food

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies on the island are dwindled and

Speaker: NA
Text: community halls become hostels. It is a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: of life. When talking to the people on

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas Island and Cocos Island, it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not take long for the conversation to get

Speaker: NA
Text: around to air services. As the federal mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, it sometimes even precedes social cour-

Speaker: NA
Text: tesies. A constant refrain is, ‘What's going

Speaker: NA
Text: on with the air service?' That is a constant

Speaker: NA
Text: question that is asked in every office, club,

Speaker: NA
Text: cafe, verandah and home in our Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: Ocean territories. The issues with the air

Speaker: NA
Text: service are many. A commitment to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: a the airstrip to handle larger aircraft will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move some issues that stand in the way of

Speaker: NA
Text: improving the air service.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of interest to me is the fact that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has announced expenditure of up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 million in connection with this space

Speaker: NA
Text: facility, yet today we have seen a reference

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Public Works Committee of works

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated to cost only $68.6 million. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: only assume that the other $32.4 million,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is not accounted for in this reference,

Speaker: NA
Text: is money that will be given to the Asia Pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: is cific Space Centre-the proponents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: launch facility. If this is the case, it leaves

Speaker: NA
Text: open the question as to what the money is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be used for. It is important that we

Speaker: NA
Text: know exactly what this money has been ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriated for. We have identified the $68.6

Speaker: NA
Text: million, but we do not know what the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: maining $32.4 million is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: it very difficult to understand why these

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys were not appropriated in the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are clearly matters of public infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure, yet the money is coming out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contingency fund. The contingency fund, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are led to believe, is for emergencies. What

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of emergency was there? We are told it

Speaker: NA
Text: is an allowance to cover items that could not

Speaker: NA
Text: be accurately costed at budget time. I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: government: why weren't these matters re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the Public Works Committee be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore? Why weren't these matters raised

Speaker: NA
Text: within the budget context? Why are we

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with them in this way? They were

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities which were required by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity in any event.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand the government's position in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to supporting the space facility, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important that we recognise that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: bring substantial benefits to the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: including large numbers of jobs: 400 in the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction phase of the launch facility and

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 during its operational phase-although,

Speaker: NA
Text: to be fair, we have no idea where the person-

Speaker: NA
Text: nel for these jobs will come from. It is likely

Speaker: NA
Text: that most of the 500 in the operational phase

Speaker: NA
Text: will be offshore residents. I support this re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferral to the Public Works Committee, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: do need more explanation from the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and we certainly need greater consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with the Christmas Island community.

Speaker: NA
Text: To date it has been farcical.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 5.30

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m., I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: Mr Speaker, I require that

Speaker: NA
Text: the question be put forthwith without debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the negative.

Speaker: NA
Text: INTERNATIONAL MARITIME

Speaker: NA
Text: CONVENTIONS LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 2001

Speaker: NA
Text: Main Committee Report

Text: Bill returned from Main Committee with

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments; certified copy of bill and

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule of amendments presented.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the bill be taken into consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: used for. I find eration forthwith.

Text: Main Committee's amendments-

Text: (1) Schedule 3, item 10, page 32 (after line 21),

Text: or

Text: (5A) For the purposes of this section, dam-

Text: (a) deterioration resulting from failure

Speaker: NA

Text: or

Text: (b) defects that develop during the nor-
