Speaker: NA
Text: Cabramatta

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Text: Fowler) (5.32 p.m.)-Last

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday, the television program 60 Minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: contained a segment on law and order. In his

Speaker: NA
Text: opening remarks the presenter, Ray Martin,

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed the viewers with this statement: ‘If

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody in your family or maybe a friend

Speaker: NA
Text: is using heroin, blame Cabramatta. If an ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dict has robbed your home or a dealer is

Speaker: NA
Text: selling drugs outside your kid's school, again

Speaker: NA
Text: blame Cabramatta.' As the representative of

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabramatta in this parliament, I found that

Speaker: NA
Text: remark offensive and untrue. But in a world

Speaker: NA
Text: of media hype, where the only thing that

Speaker: NA
Text: counts is the ratings, you would not worry

Speaker: NA
Text: too much about the impact on a community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The program followed the release of a report

Speaker: NA
Text: by the New South Wales Legislative Council

Speaker: NA
Text: General Purpose Standing Committee No. 3

Speaker: NA
Text: on its inquiry into Cabramatta policing. That

Speaker: NA
Text: report dealt mainly with police management

Speaker: NA
Text: issues at the Cabramatta local area command

Speaker: NA
Text: and its recommendations stressed a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of initiatives to improve drug law enforce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Apart from noting the health and

Speaker: NA
Text: community services measures announced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales Premier in March of

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, the report concentrated on drug

Speaker: NA
Text: enforcement as the solution to Cabramatta's

Speaker: NA
Text: problems. In short, the committee believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that a crackdown on drug dealers will solve

Speaker: NA
Text: the drug problem in Cabramatta, and, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: believe Ray Martin, Australia's drug prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem will be solved.

Speaker: NA
Text: I just wish it were that simple. ‘Take away

Speaker: NA
Text: the supply of drugs and the demand will dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appear; lock up the dealers and throw away

Speaker: NA
Text: the key' is the advice that I often get. It's that

Speaker: NA
Text: simple. Anyone would think that it has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been tried here or in other countries. But

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone who thinks that that is the solution

Speaker: NA
Text: knows nothing about addiction and nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: about the illegal drug market. You have only

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at the recent National Crime Author-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity report into organised crime in Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: realise that there are no simple solutions. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the strategy that sees 80c in every

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar spent on the drug program going to

Speaker: NA
Text: law enforcement, and only 20c going to

Speaker: NA
Text: health measures. When you look at federal

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for Cabramatta, it is even less. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have told the House before, last year, out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the $50 million in this government's Tough

Speaker: NA
Text: on Drugs policy, Cabramatta received a mere

Speaker: NA
Text: $75,000. Talk about taking your eye off the

Speaker: NA
Text: ball. This government must have been

Speaker: NA
Text: wearing a blindfold when it allocated fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for Cabramatta.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do have a serious drug problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabramatta, and the diverse ethnic mix of

Speaker: NA
Text: the population makes dealing with the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem that much harder. We do have some

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful, dedicated groups who, despite a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of resources, are determined to help

Speaker: NA
Text: those in our community who are drug de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent. But we are flat out trying to help

Speaker: NA
Text: our own without adding to the burden of oth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers from all over New South Wales. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: hear about a community that wants to shut

Speaker: NA
Text: down a methadone clinic, or refuses to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: a rehab centre, I know where the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: will finish up-in Cabramatta. When drug

Speaker: NA
Text: users cannot get methadone or they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: get into rehab, they catch the next train to

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabramatta. Last year, more than 40 young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who took that trip did not get to use

Speaker: NA
Text: their return ticket. Most of them did not

Speaker: NA
Text: come from Cabramatta and they did not

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the dark side of the moon, either.

Speaker: NA
Text: They came from communities that did not

Speaker: NA
Text: law care-communities that were happy to dump

Speaker: NA
Text: their problems on Cabramatta. I am sick and

Speaker: NA
Text: tired of communities that want to dump their

Speaker: NA
Text: problems on Cabramatta. We are flat out

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with our own problems. Even if we

Speaker: NA
Text: had extra resources to help people from

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere, having rehabilitation facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabramatta would be like having an AA

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting in a brewery.

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Blame Cabramatta,' says Ray Martin, as

Speaker: NA
Text: though one suburb were the root cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's drug problem! In spite of Ray

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin and all the rest of the negative media

Speaker: NA
Text: stories, Cabramatta is determined to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: back. I recently moved my electorate office

Speaker: NA
Text: to the heart of Cabramatta, and I am looking

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to playing my part to build public

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in this special community. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that job is made harder by commentators

Speaker: NA
Text: who know little about the area and care even

Speaker: NA
Text: less. By contrast, I congratulate the local

Speaker: NA
Text: media, the Fairfield Advance and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfield City Champion. Their positive re-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting on Cabramatta this week shows a

Speaker: NA
Text: clearer understanding of the problem and

Speaker: NA
Text: real concern for the people of Cabramatta.

Speaker: NA
Text: Robertson Electorate: Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Rugby League Team

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Text: Robertson) (5.36 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Back in late 1997, I began actively lobbying

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of all Central Coast residents for

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of a world-class sports stadium

Speaker: NA
Text: in the city of Gosford. Obviously, the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: such a stadium was going to be consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able-in fact, $28 million. The Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: has a population of 300,000, and at that time

Speaker: NA
Text: it did not have a sports stadium of any note.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most importantly, I said that, if we were

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide a stadium which would meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of the NRL for holding first

Speaker: NA
Text: grade rugby league matches, that would en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able the relocation of the then North Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Bears to the Central Coast, giving the Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral Coast its own NRL rugby league team.

Speaker: NA
Text: After much hard work which was sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported by most of the Central Coast commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity-and I am very pleased to note that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Sport and Tourism is at the table

Speaker: NA
Text: this evening, because she assisted greatly in

Speaker: NA
Text: lobbying the government to obtain the

Speaker: NA
Text: money we needed to make the stadium a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ality-we were eventually rewarded back in

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1998 when $12 million from the Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenary of Federation Fund was allocated by

Speaker: NA
Text: the federal government towards the project.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was quickly matched by the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales government, with the balance being

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed by Gosford City Council. Gra-

Speaker: NA
Text: in ham Park Stadium became a reality on 6

Speaker: NA
Text: February 2000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the North Sydney rugby

Speaker: NA
Text: league team was not allowed to continue in

Speaker: NA
Text: the NRL first grade division and we had the

Speaker: NA
Text: merger of the North Sydney rugby league

Speaker: NA
Text: team with Manly to become the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Eagles. They were embraced by the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast and the stadium was opened by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, John Howard, at the first

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Eagles v. Newcastle match of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 season in front of a capacity 22,000

Speaker: NA
Text: crowd. It was a great night and a great

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement for the Central Coast. Unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, with the demise of the Northern Ea-

Speaker: NA
Text: gles at the end of this season, the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast has a magnificent sports stadium, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not have a first division rugby team of

Speaker: NA
Text: its own. The Central Coast of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, with 300,000 people, deserves to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a rugby league team in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales of its own, a team that it can call its

Speaker: NA
Text: own, and a team which young players can

Speaker: NA
Text: aspire to represent and to represent the Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am privileged to be patron of the Kin-

Speaker: NA
Text: of cumber Junior Rugby League Club on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast. There are 4,500 young players

Speaker: NA
Text: in the junior rugby league competition on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast. The crowds at NorthPower

Speaker: NA
Text: Stadium, as it is now known, over the season

Speaker: NA
Text: able have averaged 12,000 for each match played

Speaker: NA
Text: at the stadium. The attendances at other

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds for the Northern Eagles have been

Speaker: NA
Text: less than that. It shows that rugby league is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important game on the Central Coast of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and it shows that the Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral Coast deserves to be allowed by the NRL

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a stand-alone team on the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast in the NRL competition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Central Coast community are not go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to sit back quietly. The community are

Speaker: NA
Text: gathering their forces and they will be rally-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. We will do everything we can to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the NRL allows us to have a stand-alone

Speaker: NA
Text: team in next year's rugby league competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I will be supporting the hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of people on the Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: who I know want this team to become a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ality. It is about much more than just rugby

Speaker: NA
Text: league; it is about giving the young people of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Coast an identity and something

Speaker: NA
Text: to strive for.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a former president of Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Junior Hockey. I understand how important

Speaker: NA
Text: junior sport is to the Central Coast of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. It is important for the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity of the Central Coast that we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: stand-alone rugby league team in the NRL

Speaker: NA
Text: competition next year and we will do every-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing we can to ensure that all of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that the Central Coast is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: region which deserves to have its own rugby

Speaker: NA
Text: league team in next year's NRL competition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications: Telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: Connections

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Text: Oxley) (5.41 p.m.)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight to raise a matter of great concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: me, and a matter which I believe should be

Speaker: NA
Text: of great concern to all members in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, and to the community. A young fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily with five children in my electorate has

Speaker: NA
Text: recently moved into a home. When they

Speaker: NA
Text: moved in, they found that they needed to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the phone connected. They rang Telstra to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the phone connected, but they were

Speaker: NA
Text: informed by Telstra that, as the phone line

Speaker: NA
Text: was rented by Optus, they would need to

Speaker: NA
Text: contact Optus. They set about contacting

Speaker: NA
Text: Optus and were informed that Optus would

Speaker: NA
Text: not connect the line on the basis that the

Speaker: NA
Text: vious tenants had not disconnected the phone

Speaker: NA
Text: and had not paid their debt. They were told

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would therefore not get a phone on

Speaker: NA
Text: that basis. There would be no phone. The

Speaker: NA
Text: family then asked Telstra how they might get

Speaker: NA
Text: around the procedure and this problem and

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra informed this young family that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was nothing it could do because the phone

Speaker: NA
Text: line was effectively owned by Optus as it

Speaker: NA
Text: was being rented by Optus. That left this

Speaker: NA
Text: young family with five children unable to get

Speaker: NA
Text: a phone. I find it unbelievable that this could

Speaker: NA
Text: occur. It is extremely disturbing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to place on the record tonight what

Speaker: NA
Text: took place in an attempt to rectify this situanothing

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and the pressure, and breaches of pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vacy, ethics and responsibility which this

Speaker: NA
Text: young family faced in their attempts to get

Speaker: NA
Text: their phone connected, which is a right that

Speaker: NA
Text: every Australian, regardless of where they

Speaker: NA
Text: live, should have. Optus required this family

Speaker: NA
Text: to find the name and contact details of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prior tenants, who were unknown to the new

Speaker: NA
Text: tenants, and to furnish those details to Optus

Speaker: NA
Text: or they would not get a phone connection.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I first heard this, I did not believe it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: did not think that that was possible. I investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gated the situation. My office contacted Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: tus and confirmed that to be a fact: unless

Speaker: NA
Text: this family took it upon themselves to rectify

Speaker: NA
Text: the debt which was the responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prior tenant, they would not get a line. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was the bottom line. The bottom line from

Speaker: NA
Text: Optus was, ‘Unless we can settle the debt

Speaker: NA
Text: with the prior tenants, you won't get a phone

Speaker: NA
Text: unless you purchase a new line from Telstra

Speaker: NA
Text: to go into the phone.' As you can imagine,

Speaker: NA
Text: this caused this young family a lot of stress.

Speaker: NA
Text: They took it upon themselves to try to rectify

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation, as they needed a phone con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nection. You can imagine that, with five

Speaker: NA
Text: young children, a phone connection would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a necessity which most people could not

Speaker: NA
Text: go without.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gets worse. They set about finding the

Speaker: NA
Text: details and found they had to supply Optus

Speaker: NA
Text: with the tenancy agreement-evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were the new tenants-so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: could prove, in fact, that the other tenants

Speaker: NA
Text: had moved out and that they were the occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pants legally of this house. They did so. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: just stated, Optus then demanded that they

Speaker: NA
Text: prefurnish the private details of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: tenants to which they were not privy. They

Speaker: NA
Text: did not know who the prior tenants were. So

Speaker: NA
Text: they went about asking where they could get

Speaker: NA
Text: this information. I am just shocked. I am in

Speaker: NA
Text: disbelief over the process that these people

Speaker: NA
Text: had to go through. While I do not condone it,

Speaker: NA
Text: they actually did get the private details of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prior tenants. They supplied this information

Speaker: NA
Text: to Optus. Optus, believe it or not, lost the

Speaker: NA
Text: information. The family used a call centre

Speaker: NA
Text: number, a 1300 number, to find out what was

Speaker: NA
Text: going on. We found out later that the call

Speaker: NA
Text: centre was in Melbourne. Melbourne set

Speaker: NA
Text: about trying to rectify the problem, but

Speaker: NA
Text: happened. So this family rang again,

Speaker: NA
Text: got a different call centre and discovered that

Speaker: NA
Text: Optus had in fact lost the information. Optus

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘Go and get the information and give it

Speaker: NA
Text: to us again or you will not get a phone line.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure members in the chamber are sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting here tonight saying, ‘This can't be pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible; this is not true. How can Optus have

Speaker: NA
Text: the power to do this?' They certainly do not.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe this not only constitutes an incredi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble breach of privacy of the person that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: bad debtor but has placed unbelievable pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure, obligation and responsibility on this

Speaker: NA
Text: innocent family that has no responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever to actually find this information

Speaker: NA
Text: and to become either a debt collector, an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formant or a private investigator. I find it

Speaker: NA
Text: outrageous and totally untenable. (Time ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Taxation Office: Product

Speaker: NA
Text: Rulings

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Text: Curtin) (5.46

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I rise to speak tonight on a matter that

Speaker: NA
Text: has received some coverage in the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: and business press, and that is the current

Speaker: NA
Text: state of the investment industry, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: as it relates to agricultural products, specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally timber growing companies. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a recent instance of the appointment of

Speaker: NA
Text: a voluntary administrator to a managed in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment group, Australian Plantation Tim-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber Ltd, which has timber plantations in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia. There was some good

Speaker: NA
Text: news on that front today, as the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank, the financier of the company,

Speaker: NA
Text: has agreed to accommodate the company, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand it, in respect of this season's

Speaker: NA
Text: plantings.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a concern in the investment

Speaker: NA
Text: community that there is confusion and mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: apprehension about the current taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory regime as it applies to the current

Speaker: NA
Text: tax effective investments, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: timber plantation industry. I think it is most

Speaker: NA
Text: important for consumer confidence and for

Speaker: NA
Text: investor confidence that the current product

Speaker: NA
Text: rulings system of the Australian Taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: Office be more widely understood. A product

Speaker: NA
Text: rulings system was introduced by the ATO in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1998. Essentially, product rulings were in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduced to provide the certainty to potential

Speaker: NA
Text: investors as to the tax-deductible status of a

Speaker: NA
Text: product. They are public rulings. That is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling applies to a class of persons-those

Speaker: NA
Text: who invest in a particular investment prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: uct. Once gazetted, it is a binding ruling.

Speaker: NA
Text: binding on the commissioner as to the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of investing in that product.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is important to note that a ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: is binding only in relation to the arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: that is ruled upon, so it must be carried out,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite self-evidently, in accordance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospectus or the arrangement described in

Speaker: NA
Text: the ruling, and it cannot be materially differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent in that a different tax consequence would

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise flow from any change. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: important point is that a product ruling re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lates only to the tax consequences of invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the product. It is not a guarantee or a

Speaker: NA
Text: sanction of the product as an investment, as

Speaker: NA
Text: such; it is not an assurance as to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial viability of the product. In the case

Speaker: NA
Text: of each managed investment that has a prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: uct ruling, investors must still make their

Speaker: NA
Text: own assessment of the commercial and fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial viability of the product, including

Speaker: NA
Text: matters such as the track record of the man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agers, the projected returns or the reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: ableness of the charges or any other aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial or commercial viability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: project. One would not want the ATO to, nor

Speaker: NA
Text: does it, give any assurance on such matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the establishment of the product

Speaker: NA
Text: rulings regime, I understand that about 300

Speaker: NA
Text: projects have received product rulings. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, this is designed to give certainty to the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax status of such projects. It is a vast im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement on the previous regime and, while

Speaker: NA
Text: it might be illogical that the introduction of a

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme designed to give confidence and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty as to the tax consequences of proj-

Speaker: NA
Text: ects should do otherwise, there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of media reporting on the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: regime of private rulings and on the actions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ATO to disallow tens of thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: deductions claimed in respect of products in

Speaker: NA
Text: which investments were made prior to 1998.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some fear that this reporting on the pre-1998

Speaker: NA
Text: investments when product rulings were not

Speaker: NA
Text: available has caused investors to be confused

Speaker: NA
Text: as to the tax consequences and the tax status.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I make it clear that there are two sepa-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate scenarios: pre-1998 investments without

Speaker: NA
Text: product rulings and post-1998 investments

Speaker: NA
Text: with product rulings which are not caught up

Speaker: NA
Text: It is in the current ATO crackdown. It is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known that the ATO has disallowed tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of claims for tax deductibility in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to a vast number of projects, and

Speaker: NA
Text: these are known as the mass marketed

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes. There has been considerable criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism of the ATO-from me, amongst oth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers-as to the time taken by the ATO to

Speaker: NA
Text: make its views on these schemes known and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the inaction on the part of the ATO that

Speaker: NA
Text: enabled this industry to flourish in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: to mid 1990s. As to whether these projects

Speaker: NA
Text: will ultimately be deemed to be legal is a

Speaker: NA
Text: question currently before the Federal Court.

Speaker: NA
Text: But two factors came into play in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990s: the introduction of the self-

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment regime in 1992 and the prolifera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of these mass marketed schemes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not go into that matter any further

Speaker: NA
Text: this point, but it is a scenario that must be

Speaker: NA
Text: resolved in the interests of those genuinely

Speaker: NA
Text: involved and in the interests of the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment community generally. I conclude by

Speaker: NA
Text: giving my support to the product rulings re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gime and to the timber plantation industry. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not giving commercial advice here, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: support projects-and the investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: projects-with product rulings that have

Speaker: NA
Text: positive environmental outcomes on the log-

Speaker: NA
Text: ging of old-growth forests, on greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gases and the like. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Nursing Homes: Standards of Care

Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland) (5.51 p.m.)-On

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday I moved a private member's motion

Speaker: NA
Text: condemning the government's performance

Speaker: NA
Text: in the aged care area. I emphasised that aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care is about precisely that-care for our

Speaker: NA
Text: frail older Australians. Aged care is not

Speaker: NA
Text: about shifting the blame or responsibility; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is about taking stock of the situation, identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fying the future needs of an ageing popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and then planning to meet those needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This planning should include the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: older Australians, the providers, health and

Speaker: NA
Text: allied health professionals, the workers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, the state governments and all those

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the aged care industry. Unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, the government members who spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: in the debate proceeded to blame the previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous Labor government, the states, the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viders and anyone they could think of.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's approach to aged care

Speaker: NA
Text: is even more graphically illustrated when

Speaker: NA
Text: you examine some of its initiatives. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently, the Minister for Aged Care indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: to providers within the community or not-

Speaker: NA
Text: for-profit sector that she thought they were

Speaker: NA
Text: gambling on the fact that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: would not question the classification of

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home residents' care levels. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, she accused these providers- people

Speaker: NA
Text: who care and who offer genuine quality care

Speaker: NA
Text: for their residents-that they were cheating

Speaker: NA
Text: the system. They found it highly offensive,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I do too. This must have been the moti-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation for the minister establishing audit

Speaker: NA
Text: teams to review these classifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review teams are paper-only review

Speaker: NA
Text: teams. The audits are going to be conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: at by an audit team that will look at a piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: paper that will have some information,

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe partially complete or fully complete;

Speaker: NA
Text: and, based on that piece of paper, a decision

Speaker: NA
Text: will be made as to whether or not to reclas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sify a resident. There will be no consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: with relatives, carers, GPs or anyone. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: be purely a paper-only audit. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment hopes to claw back $71 million. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, is the motivation for the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's policy the care for those people in

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing homes? Or would it be more reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to assume that it is about cost cutting,

Speaker: NA
Text: not providing care? If the purpose is to claw

Speaker: NA
Text: back $71 million, the motivation of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in this instance would really have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be questioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Monday I emphasised the draconian

Speaker: NA
Text: effect the government's policies were having

Speaker: NA
Text: on nursing homes, with the increased oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating costs associated with the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: reform packages and an inadequate funding

Speaker: NA
Text: formula that is leading, in an average 60-bed

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home, to a reduction of one staff

Speaker: NA
Text: member per year over the next six years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since Monday, St Joseph's nursing home has

Speaker: NA
Text: had to reduce its staffing by 15 hours a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another nursing home on the Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: has been forced into a position where it has

Speaker: NA
Text: had to cut its staff by one-a registered

Speaker: NA
Text: nurse. All this is affecting the level of care

Speaker: NA
Text: residents are receiving in nursing homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then I heard this week of a very sad case

Speaker: NA
Text: of an elderly resident who had been in hostel

Speaker: NA
Text: care and, in a period of under 24 hours, was

Speaker: NA
Text: moved from the hostel to a nursing room.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was told that if she did not go she would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to go to hospital. This case is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: being reviewed by the complaints resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: unit. This woman, who died within 22 days

Speaker: NA
Text: of being moved, was in possession of all her

Speaker: NA
Text: faculties. She was frail and had physical

Speaker: NA
Text: abilities. As a consequence of poor commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nication caused by a lack of staffing, she is

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer with us. These are the kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: problems that are being faced by older peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple all the time in our community. (Time ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pired

Speaker: NA
Text: Employee Entitlements Support Scheme

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Text: Barker) (5.56 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been considerable discussion over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last two weeks about the protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: workers' entitlements in the unfortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances that businesses employing

Speaker: NA
Text: them go into liquidation. It must be

Speaker: NA
Text: remembered that, comparatively speaking,

Speaker: NA
Text: very few workers will be faced with this

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. In fact, in any one year just one in

Speaker: NA
Text: 200 businesses will go bankrupt and one in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,000 employees will face the possible loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of entitlements. This fact brings most people

Speaker: NA
Text: to the conclusion that using Manusafe-

Speaker: NA
Text: although it is fairly vague at this stage as

Speaker: NA
Text: how it would work-would seem, to coin a

Speaker: NA
Text: cliche, to be using a sledgehammer to crack a

Speaker: NA
Text: nut. Why penalise the 99½ per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses each year which are not going

Speaker: NA
Text: bankrupt with reduced cash flows and extra

Speaker: NA
Text: costs when they are hardly necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems to me that certain sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement are more concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: empire building with a whole new bureauc-

Speaker: NA
Text: racy than worrying about the estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 jobs that would be lost as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: all businesses being forced to fund this vague

Speaker: NA
Text: Manusafe proposal. Ten thousand jobs could

Speaker: NA
Text: be lost in the motor industry alone, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: patently a stupid risk to take when we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had such good news as that from Mitsubishi

Speaker: NA
Text: announced recently by the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only that, but we need to define what

Speaker: NA
Text: dis- entitlements are. Frankly, to include sick

Speaker: NA
Text: leave in the equation is ridiculous because

Speaker: NA
Text: employees do not get paid for unused sick

Speaker: NA
Text: leave when they are working. Why should it

Speaker: NA
Text: suddenly become an entitlement upon liqui-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation when it is not one when they are em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed? It is also not defensible to include

Speaker: NA
Text: long service leave when the required time

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been served with the company to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach entitlement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding those concerns, at least

Speaker: NA
Text: two governments have agreed to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government's scheme, which relies

Speaker: NA
Text: on taxpayers' support in the instance of busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness failure. It comes as no surprise that

Speaker: NA
Text: these governments are the Liberal or coali-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion governments federally and in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Not one Labor state government or

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition has committed to supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: workers' entitlements with this scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Labor government of 13 years did

Speaker: NA
Text: to absolutely nothing to protect workers' rights,

Speaker: NA
Text: which makes a lie of their hollow mantra of

Speaker: NA
Text: being the party of the worker.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to put forward a different

Speaker: NA
Text: type of proposal to protect workers' entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in the event of a company going into

Speaker: NA
Text: liquidation. It may seem simple, but I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: is worth consideration by all concerned. To

Speaker: NA
Text: give some-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 6 p.m.,

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate is interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 6.00 p.m.
